questions.text: A 25 y/o male presents to the emergency after a sports injury involving a sudden pivot on his left knee. An MRI reveals a tear in the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Which statement regarding the knee ligaments is true?

choices.text: Lateral collateral ligament attaches to the patella.
The medial meniscus is wider anteriorly.
PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur.

 

Explanation:

The PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur and posterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed, making it essential for knee stability.

 

Extracapsular Ligaments

Intracapsular Ligaments
  • Ligamentum Patellae:
    • Attaches from the lower border of the patella to the tibial tuberosity.
    • Continuation of the quadriceps femoris tendon.
  • Lateral (Fibular) Collateral Ligament: (Option B ruled out)
    • Cord-like structure attaching from the femur's lateral condyle to the fibula's head.
    • The Popliteus tendon is located between this ligament and the lateral meniscus.
  • Medial (Tibial) Collateral Ligament:
    • Flat band connecting the medial condyle of the femur to the medial surface of the tibia.
    • Firmly attached to the medial meniscus.
  • Oblique Popliteal Ligament:
    • Tendinous expansion from the semimembranosus muscle, strengthening the posterior capsule.
  • Medial Meniscus
    • Semicircular, wider posteriorly than anteriorly. (Option C ruled out)
    • The peripheral margin adheres to the deep part of the tibial collateral ligament; posterior fibres are continuous with the transverse ligament.
  • Lateral Meniscus
    • Circular.
    • The posterior end is attached to the medial condyle of the femur via two meniscofemoral ligaments; separated from the fibular collateral ligament by the popliteus tendon.
  • Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL): (Option A ruled out)
    • It attaches to the anterior intercondylar area of the tibia and ascends to the posterior part of the lateral femoral condyle.
    • Prevents posterior displacement of the femur and anterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed.
    • It is extrasynovial.
  • Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL):
    • It attaches to the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia and extends to the anterior part of the medial femoral condyle.
    • Prevents anterior displacement of the femur and posterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed.
    • It is extrasynovial.

Intercondylar area attachments

 

Classification of Ligaments and Menisci by Location and Synovial Relation

  • Intracapsular and Intrasynovial: Menisci (lie within the joint capsule and are bathed by synovial fluid).
  • Intracapsular but Extrasynovial: Cruciate ligaments (located within the joint capsule but outside the synovial cavity).
  • Extracapsular and Extrasynovial: Collateral ligaments (outside both the joint capsule and synovial cavity).

questions.text:
Match the following EEG wave types with  associated activities.


	
		
			
			Type of Wave
			
			
			Activity During
			
		
		
			
			1) Beta
			
			
			i) Deep sleep
			
		
		
			
			2) Alpha
			
			
			ii) Relaxation, eyes closed
			
		
		
			
			3) Theta
			
			
			iii) Alert and active thinking
			
		
		
			
			4) Delta
			
			
			iv) Light sleep, emotional stress in adults
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 - B - iii, 2 - A - ii, 3 - D - iv, 4 - C - i

Explanation:

Type of Wave

Activity During

Beta

Alert and active thinking

Alpha

Relaxation, eyes closed

Theta

Light sleep, emotional stress in adults

Delta

Deep sleep

questions.text:
Match the following terms and definitions with


	
		
			
			Terms
			
			
			Definitions
			
		
		
			
			1. Demographic Burden
			
			
			a) Period of decrease in the dependency ratio
			
		
		
			
			2. Demographic Bonus
			
			
			b) Indicates a rise in the total dependency ratio
			
		
		
			
			3. Demographic Window
			
			
			c) Increase in economic growth rate
			
		
		
			
			4. Demographic Dividend
			
			
			d) Peak working-age population phase
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Explanation:

  • Demographic Burden
    • Refers to the increase in the proportion of the dependent population relative to the economically productive population.
    • It signifies the societal challenge of supporting a larger dependent population, which typically occurs due to aging demographics.
  • Demographic Bonus
    • A phase in a nation's demographic evolution in which the proportion of the dependent population relative to the working-age population declines.
    • This is often associated with economic growth opportunities as more people are in the workforce than dependents.
  • Demographic Window: Refers to a period in a nation's demographic structure when the proportion of the population in the working-age group is at its highest.
  • Demographic Dividend: An increase in economic growth driven by a growing proportion of working-age individuals in the population.

questions.text: Which of the following factors will not potentiate the effect of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypercalcemia, Alkalosis

Explanation:

Both hypercalcemia and alkalosis can reduce the effectiveness of neuromuscular blockers thus shortening their effects.

 

Factors That Potentiate the Effect of Neuromuscular Blockade

  1. Physiological changes in older adults
  2. Hypothermia (Option B ruled out)
  3. Hypermagnesemia (Option B ruled out)
  4. Hypocalcemia
  5. Acidosis
  6. Antimicrobials (aminoglycosides, tetracyclines, polymyxins, clindamycin) (Option C & D ruled out)
  7. Inhaled anesthetics
  8. Lithium (Option C ruled out)
  9. Local anaesthetics (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with developmental delay, ataxic gait, and frequent inappropriate laughter. Genetic testing reveals a deletion in the 15q11-q13 region of the maternal chromosome. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Disorder with paternal uniparental disomy

 

Explanation:

​​​​​​​

  • Angelman disorder is a disorder with paternal uniparental disomy.
  • Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic phenomenon (alteration in DNA without any change in nucleotide sequence) where certain genes are expressed in a parent-of-origin-specific manner.
  • The maternal or paternal allele is silenced, while the other is expressed.
  • This gene silencing is commonly linked to DNA methylation.

Angelman syndrome (AS) is caused by the loss of function of the maternally inherited UBE3A gene in the 15q11-q13 region.

  • This can occur through various mechanisms, including deletions, mutations, or imprinting defects.
  • The key features of AS include developmental delay, ataxic gait, and inappropriate laughter, all of which are present in this patient.

 

Feature

Angelman Syndrome

Prader-Willi Syndrome

Genetic Cause

Deletion or mutation of the maternal UBE3A gene on chromosome 15q11-q13.

Deletion or mutation of the paternal region on chromosome 15q11-q13, or maternal uniparental disomy.

Developmental Milestones

Severe developmental delay; speech is often minimal or absent.

Mild to moderate developmental delay; speech and motor skills are delayed.

Physical Features

Microcephaly, frequent smiling/laughter, ataxia, seizures.

Hypotonia, obesity, short stature, small hands and feet.

Behavioral Characteristics

Happy demeanor, hyperactivity, fascination with water.

Food-seeking behavior, temper tantrums, compulsive behaviors.

Intellectual Disability

Severe to profound intellectual disability.

Mild to moderate intellectual disability.

Seizures

Common and often severe.

Rare, typically not a prominent feature.

Growth Patterns

Normal or mildly affected growth; often underweight.

Hyperphagia leading to obesity if not managed.

Sleep Disturbances

Frequent, often severe sleep disturbances.

Common, often associated with excessive daytime sleepiness.


 

Disorder with maternal uniparental disomy(Option A):

  • While PWS also involves the 15q11-q13 region, it results from the loss of paternally expressed genes in this region with maternal disomy.
  • PWS presents with hypotonia, obesity, and cognitive impairment, which don't match the given clinical picture.

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) (Option C):

  • BWS is an overgrowth disorder caused by dysregulation of imprinted genes on chromosome 11p15.5.
  • It typically presents with macrosomia, macroglossia, and an increased risk of embryonal tumors, which are not described in this case.

 

Silver-Russell syndrome (SRS) (Option D):

  • SRS is a growth restriction disorder associated with imprinting defects on chromosomes 7 and 11.
  • It is characterized by intrauterine growth restriction, postnatal growth failure, and body asymmetry, which don't align with the presented symptoms.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of mitral valve replacement (on warfarin) and trigeminal neuralgia (on carbamazepine) has been prescribed clarithromycin for a chest infection. Her regular medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. Her INR is 1.3 (target > 3 for mechanical heart valve). Which drug most likely interacted with warfarin to give this INR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carbamazepine

Explanation:

  • Carbamazepine is a strong enzyme inducer, particularly of CYP2C9 and CYP3A4, which are responsible for metabolizing warfarin.
     
  • Enzyme induction leads to increased metabolism of warfarin, resulting in reduced plasma levels and a lower INR (as seen in this case: INR 1.3).
     
  • This is dangerous in patients with mechanical heart valves who require INR > 3 to prevent thromboembolic complications.
     

Mechanism table:

Drug

Effect on Warfarin

Mechanism

Carbamazepine

↓ INR (↓ warfarin effect)

CYP inducer → ↑ warfarin metabolism

Clarithromycin

↑ INR (↑ warfarin effect)

CYP inhibitor → ↓ warfarin metabolism

Amlodipine

No significant effect

No major CYP interaction

Atorvastatin

Mild unpredictable changes

Competes with warfarin at CYP enzymes

Pharmacokinetics of Warfarin:

Parameter

Details

Absorption

Oral

Kinetics

Zero-order kinetics at high doses

Excretion

Excreted in bile, safe in renal failure

Protein Binding

99% bound to albumin

Dialysis Removal

Not dialyzable due to high protein binding

Important Drug Interactions with Warfarin:

Enzyme Inhibitors (↑ INR) – Mnemonic: SICKFACES.COM

Drug

Sodium Valproate

Isoniazid

Cimetidine

Ketoconazole

Fluconazole

Alcohol (binge)

Chloramphenicol

Erythromycin

Sulfonamides

Ciprofloxacin

Omeprazole

Metronidazole

Enzyme Inducers (↓ INR) – Mnemonic: CRAP GPS

Drug

Carbamazepine

Rifampin

Alcohol (chronic)

Phenytoin

Griseofulvin

Phenobarbital

Sulphonylureas

 

Amlodipine (Option A): Incorrect. No major effect on INR or warfarin metabolism.
 

Atorvastatin (Option B): Incorrect. May have minor interactions but not a strong inducer/inhibitor.
 

Clarithromycin (Option C): Incorrect. Would increase INR, not decrease it.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a cough and difficulty breathing. The mother reports that the child has been lethargic and unable to drink or breastfeed. On examination, you find that the child's oxygen saturation is 88%, and there is stridor when the child is calm. The AVPU scale indicates a response to painful stimuli only. Based on the signs observed, how should this child's condition be classified?

choices.text: Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

 

Explanation:

Assessment and Classification of the Sick Child (Age 2 Months Up to 5 Years)

  • Initial Assessment: A thorough history from the mother is essential
  • Check for General Danger Signs:

Ask

Look

Action
  • Able to drink or breastfeed?
  • Does the child vomit everything?
  • H/O convulsions during this illness?
  • Lethargic or unconscious?
  • Currently convulsing?
  • If any danger signs are present, the child needs URGENT attention.

 

  • Look for chest in-drawing
  • Look and listen for stridor, wheeze
  • Check for central cyanosis
  • Check oxygen saturation
  • Check the AVPU scale (Alert, Voice, Pain, Unresponsive)
  • Assess for possible asthma/TB if wheezing with chest in-drawing or fast breathing is present.

 

Classify the cough:

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

Any general danger sign

OR

  • Oxygen saturation <90%
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin & Gentamicin.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent low blood sugar.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia

Chest indrawing in calm child

OR

Fast breathing

AND

No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablet.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow up in 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia: Cough or Cold

No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease
  • Treat wheeze if present - salbutamol for 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male with a history of HIV infection presents to the ED with headache, fever, photophobia, and neck stiffness. His CD4 count is 80 cells/mm³. Lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, low glucose, and elevated protein levels. India ink staining of the cerebrospinal fluid showed the following picture. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Amphotericin B and Flucytosine

 

Explanation:

The patient's presentation is consistent with cryptococcal meningitis, as indicated by the encapsulated yeast cells on India ink staining, most commonly caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. The recommended initial treatment is a combination of amphotericin B and flucytosine for induction therapy, followed by fluconazole for consolidation.

 

Fungal meningitis:

Causes
  • Cryptococcus neoformans (most common)
  • Candida
  • Histoplasma
  • Blastomyces
  • Coccidioides
  • Sporothrix

Risk factors

Immunocompromised patients

Clinical features
  • Headache
  • Altered mental status, lethargy
  • Fever
  • Neck stiffness
  • Nausea and vomiting.

Investigations
  • Lumbar Puncture: Low glucose and high protein levels. White cell count can be normal or higher than 20 microL and have a lymphocyte predominance.
  • India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells.
  • CSF ELISA for CRAG (Cryptococcal Antigen).

Treatment

(Options A, C & D ruled out)
  • LAMB (Liposomal Amphotericin-B) and 5-Fluorocytosine (Flucytosine) for 2 weeks
  • Fluconazole is given subsequently for 8-10 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is being demonstrated in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nikolsky's sign

Explanation:

The above image shows a firm sliding tangential pressure with a finger separating superficial epidermis layer from basal epidermis , producing an erosion called the Nikolsky sign.

 

Disease process

Associated diseases

True Nikolsky’s sign

Acantholysis

Pemphigus foliaceous, Pemphigus Vulgaris, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

Pseudo Nikolsky’s sign

Necrosis of keratinocytes

Toxic epidermal Necrolysis

Stevens-Johnson syndrome

Bulla spread (Option B): Slow and careful unidirectional pressure applied by a finger to the bulla causes the bulla to extend beyond the original margin as shown below. Extension of bulla is in V Shape in Pemphigus Vulgaris and Oval shape in Bullous Pemphigoid

Auspitz sign (Option C): Removal of the thinned supra papillary epidermis by gentle scraping (K/a Grattage test) will reveal vascular bleeding points as seen in Psoriasis. Its is sue to inflamed blood vessels in papillary dermis which are present below epidermis psoriatic scales

 

Koebner phenomenon (Option D) refers to the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin in patients with certain skin diseases, such as psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo.

Pseudokoebner phenomenon: seen due to autoinocculation in warts (HPV) , Molluscum contagiosum

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with persistent eye discomfort, redness, and watering. On examination, the left eye is diffusely tender, sclera appears uniformly reddened and swollen without localized thinning areas. There are no systemic signs of vasculitis or autoimmune disease on further investigation. Which type of anterior scleritis is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-necrotizing anterior diffuse scleritis

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical presentation of persistent eye discomfort, watering, diffuse redness, and tenderness without localized necrosis or thinning is characteristic of non-necrotizing anterior diffuse scleritis.

Clinical classification:

  • Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis: Pain, redness, watering, discharge, and bluish or brownish discoloration.
    • Diffuse
    • Nodular (Option C): One or more dark red or bluish nodules, which later become purple and semitransparent like porcelain.
  • Necrotizing anterior scleritis
    • With inflammation
    • Without inflammation

Necrotizing anterior scleritis with inflammation​​​​​​​: (Option A)

  • Severe form of scleritis
  • Red, painful eye, and progressive worsening of symptoms

Scleromalacia perforans (Option D): Necrotizing, painless form seen in rheumatoid arthritis patients with scleral thinning

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant with a history of vomiting, irritability, and developmental delay. The onset of symptoms coincided with the introduction of formula feed. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and signs of encephalopathy. Blood tests revealed elevated ammonia levels and high glutamine, uracil, and orotic acid concentrations. Citrulline levels were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type 2 Hyperammonemia

 

Explanation:

The infant's symptoms and laboratory findings with the timing of symptom onset after the introduction of the formula are highly suggestive of Type 2 Hyperammonemia.

 

Feature

Type 1 Hyperammonemia

Type 2 Hyperammonemia

Defective Enzyme

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS1)

Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mechanism

The inability to synthesize carbamoyl phosphate blocks the urea cycle.

Accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria, which then spills over into the cytoplasm.

Metabolic Consequences
  • Elevated ammonia and glutamate
  • Normal orotic acid and uracil
  • Low citrulline. (Option A)
  • Elevated ammonia, glutamate, and glutamine.
  • High uracil and orotic acid (excess carbamoyl phosphate enters pyrimidine synthesis).
  • Normal citrulline.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms coincide with increased protein intake.
  • CNS: Lethargy, drowsiness, coma, Convulsions, vomiting, respiratory stimulation, hyperventilation.
  • Similar to Type 1.
  • Hepatomegaly.


 

Citrullinemia and Argininosuccinate aciduria (Option C and D) would result in elevated citrulline levels, contradicting the normal citrulline finding in this scenario.

questions.text:
Which of the following is most likely based on the lab values given?


	Blood pH: 7.32
	Na+: 130mEq/L
	K+: 2.8 mEq/L
	Cl: 110 mEq/L
	HCO3: 12 mEq/L
	Urea: 25 mg/dL
	Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
	Urinary pH: 9.4
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - RTA 1:

  • Report shows metabolic acidosis with hypokalemia. This will rule out RTA 4. Now we have to select between RTA 1 and RTA 2 as both have hypokalemia with metabolic acidosis.
  • In RTA 1 due to inability to acidify urine, patient will have urine pH> 5.5 in spite of acidemia. Since urine pH given is 9.4, the answer is RTA 1
  • In contrast RTA 2 has bicarbonate loss in urine causing so much of depletion of bicarbonate in body that urine pH remains less than 5.5.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided chest pain, which started 5 hours ago, radiating to the left arm and doesn’t get relieved on taking rest. An ECG is taken immediately which is given below. Which of the following is the drug for definitive management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reteplase

 

Explanation:

  • The above ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, which suggests ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI - inferior MI in this case).
  • Reperfusion should be the definitive treatment; hence, reteplase (thrombolytic) should be ideal.
  • Management of MI:

Definitive management

Reperfusion therapy:

  • Primary percutaneous coronary intervention: If it presents within 12 hours.
 

(door to balloon time <90 minutes)

 
  • Thrombolysis: If it presents more than 12 hours or has no access to PCI within 2 hours of presentation.
 
  • Recombinant tissue plasminogen activators: alteplase, reteplase, and tenecteplase.
 

(door to needle time <30 minutes)

 

Nitroglycerin (Option A): Incorrect, as it provides symptomatic relief but does not reperfuse myocardium.

Aspirin & ticagrelor (Option C): Incorrect alone; they are adjunctive antiplatelet agents but do not restore vessel patency alone.

Morphine (Option D): Incorrect, as it only manages pain but does not affect the underlying occlusion.

questions.text: A 3 year old child presents with swelling and pain in the region of the parotid gland, accompanied by ear discharge. Examination of the external auditory canal (EAC) reveals signs of infection. Which bony anatomical structure is responsible for the spread of infection between the EAC and the parotid gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Foramen of Huschke

 

Explanation:

  • Foramen of Huschke: A deficiency in the anteroinferior bony EAC, present in some children under four and occasionally into adulthood.
  • It allows infection to spread between the parotid gland and the EAC. (Option B)
  • Fissures of Santorini: Two gaps in the cartilage of the outer EAC that allow infection to pass between the parotid glands and the EAC.
  • Isthmus: A narrowing in the bony EAC, about 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane. It is not an opening but a constriction in the canal. (Option C)

Tympanic membrane (Option D):

  • The tympanic membrane separates the external ear from the middle ear and is not involved in spreading infections to the parotid gland.

Mastoid Air Cells (Option A):

  • Mastoid air cells are a series of air-filled spaces located within the mastoid process of the temporal bone, adjacent to the middle ear.
  • While infections in the middle ear (otitis media) can spread to the mastoid air cells (causing mastoiditis), they do not directly connect the EAC to the parotid gland.
  • Thus, they are not responsible for the spread of infection between these two areas.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with symptoms of muscle weakness, fasciculations, and myotonic jerks. The patient has a history of smoking and has been taking a cholinesterase inhibitor for a recent injury. The treating physician suspects that the patient's symptoms are due to the effects of the cholinesterase inhibitor. Which of the following receptors is most likely involved in the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nm Receptors

 

Explanation:

  • Symptoms like muscle weakness, fasciculations, and myotonic jerks suggest nicotinic receptor overstimulation, implicating Nm receptors in the patient's condition.

Characteristics of subtypes of nicotinic receptors:

 

NM (Option A)

NN (Option C)

Location and function subserved
  • Neuromuscular Junction:
  • Depolarization of the muscle end plate-contraction of skeletal muscle
  • Autonomic ganglia: Depolarization - postganglionic impulse
  • Adrenal medulla: catecholamine release
  • CNS: site-specific excitation or inhibition

Nature

Has an Intrinsic ion channel, a pentamer of 𝛂2, 𝜷, 𝛾, or 𝝴 and 𝜹 subunits

Has an intrinsic ion channel, a pentamer of only 𝛂 or 𝛂𝜷 subunits

Transducer mechanism

Opening of cation (Na+ K+) channels

Opening of cation (Na+, K+, Ca2+) channels

Agonists

Phenyl trimethyl ammonium (PTMA), Nicotine

Dimethylphenylpiperazinium (DMPP), Nicotine

Antagonists

Tubocurarine, 𝛂-Bungarotoxin, Atracurium, Vecuronium

Hexamethonium, Trimethaphan, Mecamylamine

 

M3 receptors (Option B):

  • Muscarinic receptors are found in the peripheral nervous system, including the neuromuscular junctions of skeletal muscles, and are involved in the transmission of signals from parasympathetic neurons to smooth muscles and cardiac muscles.

 

Adrenergic receptors (Option D):

  • Receptors for the neurotransmitter norepinephrine transmit signals from sympathetic neurons to smooth muscles and cardiac muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the pathways of complement activation?

choices.text: The classical pathway is triggered by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 and does not require antibodies.
The alternative pathway is initiated by the binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose residues on pathogens.
The lectin pathway involves the binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes, leading to the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC).
All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

Explanation:

The convergence of the pathways at C3 convertase is crucial for activating the complement cascade, regardless of the pathway triggered. This is a key feature of the complement system, allowing for a unified response to pathogen invasion.

 

Complement System:

  • Definition: A complex network of at least 30 proteins in the blood, crucial for innate and acquired immunity.
  • Functions:
    • Lysis: Directly kills pathogens by forming membrane pores.
    • Opsonization: Coats pathogens to enhance recognition and uptake by phagocytes.
    • Immune Clearance: Removes immune complexes from circulation.
    • Inflammation: Triggers release of mediators, recruiting immune cells.

Pathways of Complement Activation:

 

Pathway

Trigger Mechanism

Key Components Involved

Classical Pathway

Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes (Option A ruled out)

C1q, C3 convertase, Membrane Attack Complex (MAC)

Alternative Pathway

Direct binding of complement proteins to pathogens (Option B ruled out)

C3, factors B and D, C3 convertase

Lectin Pathway

Binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose (Option C ruled out)

MBL, MASP1, MASP2, C4, C2, C3 convertase

 

Key Points:

  • Convergence: All pathways converge at the formation of the C3 convertase.
  • C3 Convertase: Cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b, leading to the formation of C5 convertase and, ultimately, MAC.
  • Regulation: The complement system is tightly regulated to prevent excessive activation and damage to host tissues.
  • Regulatory Proteins: Include inhibitors and inactivators that control the cascade.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who recently joined the radiology department was instructed to wear the device shown in the image. Which of the following statements about this device is incorrect?

choices.text: Assess the amount of radiation exposure
Should be sent for dose monitoring every 3 months
It is worn over the lead apron

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is worn over the lead apron

The image depicts a TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge which is worn beneath the lead apron to accurately measure the radiation dose (Option A) that penetrates the body.

TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge

Purpose

It is worn by individuals in radiation-exposed environments, such as medical imaging or nuclear facilities, to track their radiation dose and ensure it stays within safe limits.

Location

Worn beneath the lead apron (as lead apron cuts off some radiation)

Duration

According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, TLD badges are generally replaced and analyzed every 3 months to assess cumulative radiation exposure. (Option C)

Composition

Thermoluminescent phosphor crystals: (Option B)

  • Calcium sulfate dysprosium
  • Lithium fluoride
  • Lithium borate
  • Berrylium oxide
Principle

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents for her routine prenatal check-up. She is currently 11 weeks pregnant and feeling anxious about her pregnancy due to her age and the risk of chromosomal abnormalities associated with it. During a fetal aneuploidy screening, risk of Trisomy 21 is increased. What would be the levels of Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) and Pregnancy-associated Plasma Protein-A (PAPP-A) in Trisomy 21?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increased hCG and Decreased PAPP-A.

Explanation:

Trisomy 21 is characterized by increased hCG and decreased PAPP-A.

 

First Trimester Aneuploidy screening includes:

  • Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  • Pregnancy-associated Plasma Protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Nuchal Translucency (NT) on UltraSonoGram (USG)

 

Increased NT is more commonly associated with cardiac abnormalities than trisomies. Therefore, a fetal echocardiogram is recommended when NT measurement is >3.5 mm.
 

Trisomy 18 and 13 are characterized by decreased hCG and decreased PAPP-A. (Option B ruled out).

questions.text: All the following statements about the systemic effects of inhalational agents are correct except:

choices.text: Isoflurane can be safely used in patients with head injury
Halothane is the anesthetic agent of choice in patients with ischaemic heart disease
Almost all inhalational agents cause bronchodilation
Sevoflurane is the anesthetic of choice in bronchial asthma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Halothane is the anesthetic agent of choice in patients with ischaemic heart disease.

Explanation:

Halothane is contraindicated in patients with ischaemic heart disease.

  • Halothane decreases cardiac output, BP, and PR
  • Halothane causes hypotension by direct myocardial depression
  • Halothane causes bradycardia by blunting carotid body receptor response
  • Halothane is a common inhalational agent used in the respiratory system (due to maximum bronchodilation) while Isoflurane is the common inhalational agent used in CNS and CVS

Central Nervous System:

  • Inhalational agents are CNS depressant
  • They reduce cerebral metabolic rate
  • Commonly used inhalational agent is isoflurane
  • They increase the cerebral blood flow thereby increasing the ICP, so they are avoided in head injury and neurosurgery (maximum with halothane)
  • Isoflurane is an inhalational agent of choice in head injury as it decreases the ICP (Option A)
  • Most epileptogenic agent: Enflurane (increases ICP and also causes epilepsy)

Respiratory system

  • Almost all inhalational agents cause bronchodilation (Option C)
  • Reduces the Respiratory rate
  • Causes decreased mucociliary function (except ether)
  • Maximum bronchodilation is seen with halothane, therefore 2nd best inhalational agent for bronchial asthma is halothane.
  • Best inhalational agent for bronchial asthma: Sevoflurane (Option D)

Cardiovascular system

  • Reduces heart rate, BP, and systemic vascular resistance
  • Halothane increases the sensitivity of the myocardium toward catecholamines
  • Halothane, isoflurane, enflurane - prolong QT interval

Gastrointestinal system:

  • Reduces the liver blood flow
  • Halothane hepatitis: maximally metabolized produces trifluoroacetic acid as an end product that reacts with liver cells (immunologically) causing acute fulminant hepatic necrosis.

Uterus:

  • All agents are good uterine relaxants so there is a high chance of PPH

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with recurrent abdominal pain undergoes an endoscopic biopsy of the small intestine. The pathologist observes cells with prominent eosinophilic secretory granules located in the deeper parts of the intestinal crypts. These cells are known to produce substances that destroy bacteria. Which of the following cell types is the pathologist most likely observing as shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Paneth cells

Explanation:
The cells located in the deeper parts of the intestinal crypts having prominent eosinophilic secretory granules are Paneth cells, which produce lysozyme that destroys bacteria and other microorganisms in the small intestine.

Cells in Small Intestine

Cell Type

Location

Function

Characteristics

Absorptive Columnar Cells (Enterocytes) (Option A)

Luminal surface (villi)

Absorption of amino acids, carbohydrates, and lipids

- Oval nucleus in lower part

- Striated border (microvilli)

- Junctional complexes and desmosomes

Goblet Cells

Scattered among columnar cells, increasing in number towards ileum

Mucus secretion

- Expanded upper part with mucin granules

- Flattened nucleus near base

- Abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum

Undifferentiated Cells

Walls of intestinal crypts

- Proliferate and migrate to villi

- Differentiate into absorptive or goblet cells

- Columnar cells

Paneth Cells (Zymogen Cells)

Deeper parts of intestinal crypts

- Produce lysozyme (destroys bacteria)

- May produce other enzymes

- Prominent eosinophilic secretory granules

- Considerable Golgi apparatus

- Rough endoplasmic reticulum

Endocrine Cells (Argentaffin/Enterochromaffin Cells) (Option D)

Epithelial lining, most numerous near lower ends of crypts

Secrete endocrine substances

- Membrane-bound vesicles with neuroactive substances

- Granules stain with silver salts

M Cells (Option B)

Overlying Peyer's patches

- Engulf and transport microbes to basolateral surface

- Stimulate gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT)

-Antigen-presenting function

- Microfolds instead of microvilli

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought by her family. They report that over the past year, she has been using increasing amounts of opioids, initially prescribed for chronic back pain. The patient admits to using opioids in larger amounts than intended and has made several unsuccessful attempts to cut down. She has given up her hobbies and often misses work due to opioid use. Recently, she was arrested for stealing prescription pads from her doctor's office. Despite these issues, she continues to use opioids daily. Which of the following statements BEST characterizes this patient's condition based on the information provided?

choices.text: The patient meets criteria for opioid dependence, with evidence of tolerance and withdrawal
The patient exhibits opioid abuse but does not meet the full criteria for dependence due to the absence of physiological symptoms
The patient meets the criteria for opioid dependence, with prominent features of impaired control and social impairment
The patient's behavior suggests opioid misuse rather than dependence, as the initial use was medically sanctioned

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The patient meets the criteria for opioid dependence, with prominent features of impaired control and social impairment

Explanation:

The behavioral and clinical features of the patient align with the diagnostic criteria for substance dependence according to DSM-5, as given below:

  1. Impaired control: The patient uses opioids in larger amounts than intended and has made unsuccessful attempts to cut down.
  2. Social impairment: She has given up hobbies and often misses work due to opioid use.
  3. Continued use despite consequences: She continues to use despite legal problems (arrested for stealing prescription pads) and negative impacts on her life.

 

Dependence:

Dependence is a state where a person exhibits both physical and psychological symptoms related to substance use.

 

Type of Dependence

Definition

Behavioral Dependence

Focuses on substance-seeking behaviors and the patterns of pathological use.

Physical Dependence

Refers to the physiological effects that result from repeated episodes of substance use.

Psychological Dependence

Also called habituation, characterized by a persistent or occasional craving to avoid dysphoria.

 

Substance Use Disorder Criteria (DSM-5):

The criteria for diagnosing substance dependence can be grouped into four main categories:

  1. Impaired Control:
    • Using larger amounts or for longer periods than intended
    • Persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control use
    • Spending excessive time obtaining, using, or recovering from the substance
    • Experiencing intense cravings or urges to use the substance
  2. Social Impairment:
    • Failing to fulfill major role obligations due to substance use
    • Continuing use despite persistent social or interpersonal problems
    • Giving up important activities because of substance use (Progressive Neglect)
  3. Risky Use:
    • Recurrent use in physically hazardous situations
    • Continued use despite knowledge of physical or psychological problems caused or exacerbated by the substance (Persistence)
  4. Pharmacological Criteria:
    • Tolerance: Needing increased amounts to achieve desired effects or experiencing reduced effects with the same amount
    • Withdrawal: Experiencing characteristic withdrawal symptoms or using the substance to relieve withdrawal.

 

(Option A): While the patient likely meets the criteria for opioid dependence, the scenario doesn't provide explicit evidence of tolerance or withdrawal.

(Option B) is incorrect because the patient's presentation goes beyond abuse and meets the criteria for dependence.

(Option D) is incorrect because the origin of use (medically sanctioned) doesn't prevent a diagnosis of dependence. The pattern of use, loss of control, and continued use despite significant problems all point to dependence rather than mere misuse.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication of expectant management of unruptured tubal pregnancy?

choices.text: The initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L
Gestation sac size less than 4 cm
No evidence of bleeding on USG

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L


Explanation:
Indications for expectant management of ectopic pregnancy (only monitoring hCG levels without any interventions):

  • Initial serum hCG level is less than 1,500 IU/L and subsequent levels are decreasing.
  • Gestational sac size is less than 4 cm (Option C)
  • Absence of fetal heartbeat detected (Option B) on transvaginal ultrasound (TVS).
  • No evidence of bleeding (Option D) or rupture on transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with a newly diagnosed left-sided breast mass on routine mammography. Core needle biopsy shows the following findings. Further molecular study revealed the involvement of the CDH1 gene. Which of the following statements are incorrect concerning this type of breast cancer?



1) Increased E-cadherin expression is observed in tumor cells.

2) Minimal desmoplasia and fibrosis were observed on microscopy.

3) A contralateral breast examination is usually required due to bilateral involvement.

4) It is associated with a poor prognosis compared to other types of breast cancer.

5) Metastatic spread affects leptomeninges and retroperitoneum.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) 1,4

 

Explanation :

Invasive lobular breast carcinoma:

  • CDH1 gene mutation: Decreased E-cadherin levels (also seen in signet ring gastric adenocarcinoma). (Statement 1)
  • Clinically: Bilateral and multicentric lesions; if one breast has ILC, both breasts should be examined. (Statement 3)
  • Microscopy Features:
    • The tumor cells are dyscohesive, present back to back, and are called Indian file pattern.
    • Shows minimal desmoplasia and fibrosis. (Statement 2)
  • Metastatic spread to the retroperitoneum and leptomeninges is called carcinomatous meningitis. (Statement 5)
  • Excellent prognosis because it usually belongs to Luminal A and B categories.(Statement 4)

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and difficulty walking. His parents report a family history of similar symptoms. A detailed history was obtained, and a pedigree analysis was done, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis and the inheritance pattern seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: D) Duchenne muscular dystrophy, X-linked recessive
 

EXPLANATION:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease.

 

X-linked recessive disorders:

  • Females (XX) are carriers.

Males are affected by the disease.

Examples of X-linked recessive disorders:

Mnemonic

Diseases

Wise
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

AB
  • Hemophilia A, B
  • Ocular albinism

B
  • Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia
  • Becker muscular dystrophy

C
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Color blindness (Red-green)

D
  • Duchenne Muscular dystrophy

E
  • Lesch Nyhan syndrome

F
  • Fabry disease
  • Fragile-X syndrome (X-linked recessive > X-linked recessive)

G
  • G-6-PD deficiency

H
  • Hunter’s disease

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct match of brainstem components with the respective cranial nerve nuclei that originate from them?

 


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			a. Midbrain
			
			
			1. Trigeminal nerve
			
		
		
			
			b. Pons
			
			
			2. Oculomotor nerve
			
		
		
			
			c. Medulla oblongata
			
			
			3. Glossopharyngeal nerve
			
		
		
			
			d. Pontomedullary junction
			
			
			4. Facial nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) a-2, b-1, c-3, d-4

Explanation:

Components of brainstem

Cranial nerves nuclei

Midbrain

Oculomotor (III) and trochlear (IV)

Pons

Trigeminal (V)

Medulla oblongata

Glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), cranial accessory (XIcr) and hypoglossal (XII)

Pontomedullary junction

Abducens (VI), facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII)

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the OPD with severe pain, redness, and swelling in his right knee. Examination reveals tender swelling and redness at the base of the right 1st toe. Serum urate levels are normal, but arthrocentesis reveals negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarised light. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this acute attack?
questions.solution:
Oral colchicine is the drug of choice for the management of acute gout attacks.

 

Management of acute gout attack

Colchicine

(Option B)
  • Microtubule inhibitor, which prevents microtubule assembly in neutrophils, thus reducing inflammation.
  • Colchicine disrupts the function of the cytoskeleton by inhibiting the polymerization of beta-tubulin into microtubules.
  • This prevents the formation and function of microtubules, which are essential for various cellular processes.
  • By disrupting microtubule formation, colchicine inhibits the activation, degranulation, and migration of neutrophils, which are key players in the inflammatory response. This reduces the inflammatory cascade associated with conditions like gout.
  • Colchicine does not prevent phagocytosis of uric acid crystals, but it inhibits the release of an inflammatory glycoprotein from phagocytes. This contributes to its anti-inflammatory action in conditions like gout.
  • Colchicine blocks metaphase in dividing cells by disrupting mitotic spindle formation.
  • DOC for acute attacks of gout.
  • Dose: 0.6 mg TID - introduced after 2-3 days when swelling reduces.
  • Side effects: Nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • Avoided in elderly patients and those with renal impairment.

NSAIDs
  • It is effective when used early in an attack of gout.
  • Indomethacin 25-50 mg TID / Naproxen 500 mg BID / Ibuprofen 800 mg TID
  • Avoided in elderly patients and those with renal impairment

Glucocorticoids

(Option C)
  • It can be used as an intramuscular injection for multi-articular involvement or intra-articular injection for mono-articular involvement, or orally.
  • Safe to use in elderly patients and those with renal impairment.

Other treatments

  • Ice therapy: Reduces swelling and inflammation
  • Canakinumab (IL-1 β inhibitor) (Option A)
  • Anakinra: Reserved for resistant cases

Urate lowering agents

  • Drugs: Allopurinol, Febuoxostat, Probenecid and Pegloticase
  • Contraindicated in acute attacks.
  • Rapidly reduces serum urate level, which causes the dissolution of organised monosodium urate crystals.
  • Causes an inflammatory reaction towards the shed crystals.

 

Allopurinol (Option D) is a urate-lowering agent that inhibits xanthine oxidase, reducing urate production from hypoxanthine and xanthine. It is not recommended during active gout flares, as it can exacerbate the attack. While it lowers serum urate levels and promotes the dissolution of monosodium urate crystals, this may trigger an inflammatory reaction to the released crystals.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with intermittent flank pain and occasional gross hematuria. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests show normal renal function. A renal biopsy of a mass lesion reveals a mixture of mature adipose tissue, thick-walled blood vessels, and bundles of smooth muscle cells. All are true regarding this condition except?

choices.text: It is commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis.
It is more prevalent in males than females.
It is mostly a benign tumor.
It has a high susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:  B)It is more prevalent in males than females.

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Renal angiomyolipoma:

 

  • A benign neoplasm consisting of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat originating from perivascular epithelioid cells. (Option C)
  • It is most often detected incidentally and has a female preponderance. (Option B)
  • They are present in 25% to 50% of patients with tuberous sclerosis. (Option A)
  • It has a high susceptibility for bleeding (can present as loin pain).
  • Morphology:

Histology: Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures.

questions.text: You are required to disinfect a well using Horrock’s apparatus. The well has a diameter of 1.5 meters and a depth of 10 meters. Considering 2 grams of bleaching powder (calcium hypochlorite) is needed per cubic meter of water for effective disinfection, how much bleaching powder is required to disinfect this well?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 35 grams

Explanation:

1. Calculate the volume of the well:

  • Volume of a cylinder = π × (radius)² × height (or) V= π x (diameter/2)² x height
  • Radius = Diameter / 2 = 1.5 meters / 2 = 0.75 meters
  • Height = Depth of the well = 10 meters

Volume = π × (0.75 meters)² × 10 meters

→ Volume ≈ 3.14 × 0.5625 × 10

→ Volume ≈ 17.67 cubic meters

2. Calculate the amount of bleaching powder needed:

  • Bleaching powder required = Volume of the well × Amount of bleaching powder per cubic meter

⇒ 17.67 cubic meters × 2 grams per cubic meter

  • Bleaching powder required ≈ 35.33 grams

Rounding off, the required amount of bleaching powder is approximately 35 grams.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			1) Pneumocystis pneumonia
			
			a) 
			
		
		
			2) Blastomycosis
			
			b) 
			
		
		
			3) Aspergillus
			
			c) 
			
		
		
			4) Measles
			
			d)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a

Explanation:

Pneumocystis jirovecii:

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus that causes Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP).
  • PCP primarily affects immunocompromised individuals.
  • Gomori’s methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii.
    • The cysts resemble black-coloured crushed ping-pong balls against the green background.

 

Blastomycosis:

  • Blastomycosis is a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis found in moist soil.
  • Morphology:
    • In the normal host, the lung lesions of blastomycosis are suppurative granulomas.
    • Macrophages have a limited ability to ingest and kill B. dermatitidis, and the persistence of the yeast cells leads to the recruitment of neutrophils.
    • In tissue, B. dermatitidis is a round, 5- to 15-μm yeast cell divided by broad-based budding.
    • It has a thick, double-contoured cell wall and visible nuclei.

Aspergillus:

  • Aspergillosis is an invasive and allergic disease caused by a hyaline mould named Aspergillus.
  • Glucocorticoid use is the most important risk factor for aspergillosis.
  • Pulmonary aspergillosis is the most common form.
  • KOH (10%) mount or histopathological staining of specimens reveals characteristic narrow septate hyaline hyphae with acute angle branching.

Measles:

  • The measles virus is a single-stranded RNA virus of the Paramyxoviridae family.
  • It causes measles, an acute, highly contagious childhood disease characterised by fever and respiratory symptoms followed by a typical maculopapular rash.
  • Virus isolation: Cytopathic effect may be observed after 7–10 days of inoculation into cell lines characterised by multinucleated giant cells (Warthin-Finkeldey cells) containing intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.
  • It can cause giant-cell pneumonitis (Hecht’s pneumonia) in immunocompromised children and HIV-infected people.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with a history of hyperlipidemia is being managed on a lipid-lowering therapy regimen. His current medications include atorvastatin for cholesterol management. During a follow-up visit, the patient's lipid profile indicates the need for additional triglyceride lowering, and the clinician considers adding a fibrate to his treatment plan. Which of the following fibrate drugs must be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gemfibrozil

Explanation:

  • Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that significantly increases the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis when combined with statins like atorvastatin. This is due to its strong inhibitory effect on the CYP2C8 and CYP3A4 enzymes, which are involved in the metabolism of many statins. As a result, it increases the plasma concentration of statins, leading to an increased risk of muscle toxicity.
  • Fibrates Mechanism: Activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α).

 

Fenofibrate (Option A): Most suitable fibrate for combining with statins because it minimally affects statin metabolism as it has no CYP action (less risk of myopathy).

Clofibrate (Option B): Clofibrate is an older fibrate associated with an increased risk of gallstone formation.

Bezafibrate (Option C): A second-generation fibric acid derivative with the least risk of myopathy.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male is undergoing chemotherapy for the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. During his treatment, he developed pancytopenia, characterized by anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. The oncologist reviews the patient's medication list to determine which drug might be responsible for the patient’s lab results. All of the following drugs could be responsible for the patient’s condition except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vincristine

Explanation:

The patient’s pancytopenia is probably due to bone marrow suppression caused by his anti-cancer drugs.

  • Vincristine, a vinca alkaloid, specifically targets cells during the M phase (mitosis).
  • It binds to tubulin and inhibits microtubule formation.
  • This disruption primarily affects cells with high mitotic activity but has a preferential effect on neural tissues due to their microtubule-dependent processes and has very little effect on bone marrow cells.

Other anticancer drugs which do not cause bone marrow suppression include:

  • Asparaginase
  • Bleomycin
  • Chlorambucil

Cyclophosphamide (Option A) is an alkylating agent very well known to cause bone marrow suppression.

MOA of Alkylating agents causing cell death:

 

Methotrexate (Option B) is a folate analog that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) needed for DNA synthesis and repair, causing bone marrow suppression.

Doxorubicin (Option C) causes bone marrow suppression by DNA Intercalation, Topoisomerase II Inhibition, and free radical formation causing DNA damage.

 MOA:

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by the United Nations in 2015?

choices.text: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education for all
Promote sustainable consumption and production patterns

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Achieve world peace and disarmament

Explanation: 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), adopted by the United Nations and UNDP in 2015, aim to eradicate poverty, ensure prosperity, and protect the planet by 2030. There are 17 goals:

  1. End poverty everywhere in all its forms. (Option A ruled out)

  2. Zero hunger- Achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.

  3. Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages.

  4. Provide inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities. (Option B ruled out) 

  5. Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls. 

  6. Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all.

  7. Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all.

  8. Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work.

  9. Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.

  10. Reduce inequality within and among countries.

  11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable

  12. Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns. (Option C ruled out) 

  13. Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts. 

  14. Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources. 

  15. Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity. 

  16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions. 

  17. Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with new-onset headaches, seizures, and progressive unilateral weakness. Brain MRI reveals a cerebral mass with irregular borders and heterogeneous contrast enhancement. Biopsy shows GFAP-positive glial cells. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Astrocytoma

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and biopsy showing GFAP (Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein) positivity indicates a Glial cell tumor, Astrocytoma, the most common primary brain tumor in children.

 

Classification of Brain tumors based on origin

Origin

Tumors

Glial Cell

Astrocytoma (Option A), ependymoma, oligodendroglioma

Undifferentiated Cell

Medulloblastoma (Option C)

Neuronal Cell

Neurocytoma (Option B), Ganglioglioma, Ganglioneuroma

Meningeal Cell

Meningioma (Option D)

questions.text: 30 year old  female presents with complaints of progressive weakness of lower limbs, numbness, difficulty walking and recent onset forgetfulness. On examination, bilateral loss of vibration sense is noted , bilateral ankle jerks are absent with bilateral babinski sign. Romberg sign is present with eyes closed. Peripheral blood smear done was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Subacute combined demyelination of Spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Subacute combined demyelination of Spinal cord

 

Explanation:

This clinical scenario is classic for Subacute Combined Degeneration  due to Vitamin B12 deficiency, which affects both the dorsal columns (causing loss of vibration sense, positive Romberg sign) and the lateral corticospinal tracts (causing weakness and bilateral Babinski sign). The presence of absent ankle jerks with extensor plantar response suggests a mixed UMN and LMN picture seen in SACD as it involves both peripheral nerves and dorsal column. 

Note that neurological features can exist without hematological featuers. 

Incorrect options 

Tabes dorsalis also affects dorsal columns and can cause sensory ataxia, but there is no UMN involvement (Babinski sign would not be present). 
Friedreich’s ataxia has onset in adolescence and has cardiomyopathy, and a family history, which are not mentioned.
Brown-Séquard syndrome presents with  ipsilateral motor and vibration loss with contralateral pain loss not a bilateral symmetrical presentation as seen here.

questions.text: A 45-year-old professional singer presents with complaints of vocal fatigue and difficulty producing high-pitched sounds for the last 3 months. She denies any difficulty in swallowing or breathing. On laryngoscopic examination, no significant abnormalities are seen, and one vocal cord appears to be in normal resting position while other vocal cord is in abducted position . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Unilateral SLN palsy

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the patient is a professional singer who reports difficulty with high-pitched sounds, which is a hallmark of unilateral SLN palsy.
  • The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords, crucial for producing high-pitched sounds.
  • In unilateral SLN palsy, the patient does not experience breathing or swallowing difficulties, and laryngoscopic examination may appear normal.

 

Unilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Cricothyroid muscle - decreased ability to tense the vocal cord.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cord on the affected side.
  • Vocal Cord Position: The affected vocal cord appears shortened and wavy; may exhibit flapping due to loss of tension.
  • Other Features:
    • Askew position of the glottis with the anterior commissure rotated towards the healthy side.
    • Voice changes such as weakness and inability to raise pitch, affecting singing ability.
  • Treatment: Primarily voice therapy to improve vocal function and manage symptoms.

 

Bilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Both cricothyroid muscles - bilateral loss of vocal cord tension.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cords bilaterally.
  • Vocal Cord Position: Both vocal cords may be shortened and lack tension, potentially leading to difficulties with voice production.
  • Other Features:
    • Inhalation of food and secretions resulting in coughing and choking.
    • The voice is weak and husky.
  • Treatment:
    • Tracheostomy with a cuffed tube and esophageal feeding tube, if aspiration is severe.
    • Epiglottopexy (reversible) - close laryngeal inlet - to protect the lungs from aspiration.
    • Voice pitch improvement through surgical approximation of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages.

 

Bilateral SLN palsy (Option A):

  • The patient would have more pronounced symptoms, including a monotonous voice, significant difficulty with high-pitched sounds, and aspiration due to poor sensation in the upper larynx.

 

Unilateral RLN palsy (Option C)

  • Causes hoarseness and, on laryngoscopy, shows one vocal cord in a paramedian position.
  • In contrast, this patient's difficulty is specifically related to high-pitched sounds, pointing to SLN involvement rather than RLN.

 

Bilateral RLN palsy (Option D):

  • It is a severe condition that typically results in stridor or significant respiratory difficulty due to both vocal cords being fixed in the paramedian position.
  • The absence of breathing or swallowing problems in this patient rules out bilateral RLN palsy.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and heart failure presents to the emergency department after experiencing lightheadedness and near syncope. On examination, he is alert but pale, with a heart rate of 43 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg. The ECG is shown below. He remains hypotensive and symptomatic despite the IV administration of a maximum dose of atropine. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dopamine IV infusion

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and ECG suggesting sinus bradycardia without evidence of heart block are consistent with symptomatic sinus bradycardia with hypotension.
  • After atropine fails, the next step in the management is dopamine infusion.

 

Adult bradycardia algorithm

Epinephrine IV bolus (Option A): The recommendation is IV infusion and not as a bolus administration of the drug.

 

Amiodarone IV infusion (Option B) and digoxin IV bolus (Option D): They are not used in treating bradyarrhythmias.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes with recurrent episodes of loss of consciousness, tremors, excessive sweating, and confusion. A tumour of the pancreas is suspected, and the serum proinsulin level (on a 72-hour fasting test) is raised. Which of the following investigations would be most preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS)

Explanation:

The clinical scenario points to insulinoma for which the main investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is endoscopic ultrasound.

Clinical Diagnosis of Insulinoma:

Presence of Whipple’s triad:

  • Hypoglycemia (plasma glucose < 50 mg/dL).
  • Neuroglycopenic symptoms.
  • Relief of symptoms upon glucose administration.

Biochemical diagnosis is made by the following:

  • Plasma glucose: low.
  • Insulin/glucose ratio: raised.
  • C-peptide: raised.
  • Proinsulin during a 72-hour fasting test: raised.
  • Sulfonylurea (metabolites): absence in urine and plasma.

Non-Invasive Imaging Techniques for Insulinoma Localization

Invasive Diagnostic Modalities for Insulinoma
  • Transabdominal ultrasonography
  • CT (Option A)
  • MRI (Option B)
  • Somatostatin scintigraphy
  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)
    • Considered the primary diagnostic tool.
  • EUS-guided Fine-Needle Aspiration (FNA)
  • Angiography with Arterial Secretagogue Venous Sampling (ASVS)
  • Manual Palpation and Intraoperative Ultrasound (Option C)

Management:

  • Severe hypoglycemia can be challenging to manage.
  • Medications:
    • Diazoxide is historically used to inhibit insulin release but may cause sodium retention and nausea. It is used when preop or intraop localisation is not required.
    • Everolimus is effective in improving glycemic control and may induce insulin resistance and have an antitumor effect.
    • Somatostatin analogues like octreotide normalize blood glucose levels but need to be carefully used as these may worsen hypoglycemia.
  • In high-risk patients, the following may also be done:
    • Alcohol ablation
    • Radiofrequency embolization
    • Embolization

Surgical treatment:

  • Surgical resection is recommended in the absence of metastatic disease:
    • Enucleation is done for exophytic or peripheral insulinomas.
    • Pancreatoduodenectomy for tumours in the head of the pancreas.
    • Distal pancreatectomy with spleen preservation for smaller tumours not involving splenic vessels.

questions.text: A 15 year old patient presents with anemia with splenomegaly. P. Smear is shown below. Comment on the Peripheral smear shown below
questions.solution:
Correct answer id d: Pyropokilocytosis

The image shows marked poikilocytosis with microspherocytes, schistocytes, and elliptocytes. Looks similar to smear in severe burns.

Pyropoikilocytosis is a rare form of hereditary elliptocytosis characterized by extreme red blood cell shape abnormalities and marked thermal sensitivity of the RBC membrane. It is autosomal recessive and occurs when a person inherits two abnormal spectrin alleles.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for ICD implantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • While Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome can lead to arrhythmias, it is typically amenable to catheter ablation, making ICD implantation unnecessary in the absence of other risk factors.

Indication for ICD implantation

  • Ischemic, Non-ischemic, Hypertrophic (Option C ruled out), and Familial cardiomyopathy 
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia
  • Cardiac sarcoidosis
  • Brugada syndrome
  • Long-QT syndrome (Option D ruled out)
  • Catecholaminergic polymorphic VT (CPVT)
  • LV noncompaction
  • Chagas disease (dilated cardiomyopathy due to infection) (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A rural clinic generates biomedical waste daily with no nearest biomedical waste treatment facility nearby. What is the most appropriate method for disposing of biomedical waste in this situation?

choices.text: Use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Deep Burial

 

Explanation:

Deep Burial:

  • Indication: No common biomedical waste treatment facility (CBWTF) is available nearby.
  • 2 metres deep.
  • Common practice in PHCs.
  • Biomedical waste should not be disposed of in regular landfills (Option A) due to its hazardous nature and potential for environmental contamination.

 

The use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste (Option C) does not ensure proper treatment of biomedical waste and may lead to contamination of municipal waste streams, posing risks to waste handlers and the public.

questions.text: Which muscle is the first to regain function after muscle relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Diaphragm

Explanation:

The diaphragm, a central muscle involved in breathing, receives a high blood supply, making it one of the first to recover after muscle relaxants wear off. The fast recovery of the diaphragm is important for restoring normal respiratory function following surgery.

 

Triceps (Option A): The triceps, located in the upper arm, are peripherally situated and recover later than centrally located muscles. The slower return of function in muscles like the triceps is due to their lower blood supply and distant location from central circulation.

Adductor pollicis (Option B): Located in the hand, this peripheral muscle tends to recover more slowly because it has lower blood flow compared to central muscles. It is useful for monitoring complete neuromuscular recovery.

Quadriceps (Option C): Quadriceps exhibit a slower recovery because they are more distant from central circulation and have less blood flow compared to muscles like the diaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following does this Darrow-Yannet diagram (Solid line represent the controlled condition and broken red-line indicates new-steady state condition) represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diarrhea

 

Explanation:

The Darrow-Yannet diagram shows isosmotic volume contraction; an example of that is diarrhoea.

Darrow-Yannet Diagram:

  • It helps to understand the plasma osmolarity and volume alterations in various diseases.
  • The volume is plotted in x-axis and plasma osmolarity in y-axis.
  • Broken lines indicate the flow of water between compartments driven by osmotic gradients, reflecting passive movement in response to changes in solute concentrations.
  • A normal Darrow-Yannet Diagram is shown below:

Disorder

Examples

Effects

Isosmotic volume contraction
  • Diarrhoea
  • Vomiting
  • Haemorrhage
  • Burns
  • Decrease in ECF and plasma volumes
  • Increased plasma protein concentration
  • Increased hematocrit
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure

Hyposmotic volume contraction
  • Adrenocortical insufficiency
  • Gastric secretions loss
  • Decreased plasma volume
  • Decreased ECF and plasma osmolality
  • Water shifts from ECF to ICF
  • Cellular swelling
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure

Hyperosmotic volume contraction
  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Excessive sweating
  • Alcoholism
  • Fever
  • Decrease in ECF and plasma volumes
  • Increased ECF and plasma osmolality
  • Water shifts from ICF to ECF
  • Increased hematocrit
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure.

questions.text: A patient presents with bone pain, fatigue and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests reveal anemia and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance. Which substrate accumulates in Gaucher's disease due to the deficient enzyme activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucosylceramide

 

Explanation:

  • Gaucher’s disease → deficiency of β-glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase) → accumulation of glucosylceramide.

  • Features: hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, bone pain, “wrinkled paper” macrophages.

Takeaway:
Gaucher’s = β-glucosidase deficiency → glucosylceramide accumulation.

  • Sphingomyelin (Option A) → Niemann-Pick

  • Ganglioside (Option C) → Tay-Sachs

  • Ceramide (Option D)→ Farber disease

questions.text: Which of the following mediators is responsible for cancer cachexia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) TNF-alpha

Explanation:

TNF-alpha is responsible for cancer cachexia.

  • Cancer cachexia means weight loss in cancer patients due to the elevation of TNF-alpha mediators.
  • TNF-alpha also learned as no food appetite, because whenever TNF-alpha is raised in the body (can be due to fever or cancer), appetite of patient decreases and they stop feeling hungry.

 

IFN-gamma (Option B) is responsible for granuloma formation.

IL-8 (Option C) is for neutrophil recruitment.

TGF-beta (Option D) is the most fibrogenic cytokine.

questions.text: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) El Plantón

 

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts El Planton

 

Torture:

  • Defined as deliberate, systemic, or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason.

 

Physical torture subtypes

Types of Torture

Description

El Plantón

(Option D)
  • Victim is forced to stand for extended periods in the ‘Army Corps’ poster or body folding or on one leg.
  • Dependent edema and petechiae.

Scaphism

(Option A)
  • An ancient form of execution involving being trapped between two boats and subjected to insects and exposure.


 

Dry Submarine

(Option B)
  • Form of suffocation where the victim's head is wrapped in a plastic bag, causing breathing difficulty.
  • Lung petechiae are seen.


 

Picana/Electric cattle prod

(Option C)
  • An electric torture method that applies electric shocks to the genital region.
  • Reddish brown lesions at points of contact with burning and scarring.

questions.text: An immigrant laborer comes to your Sunday volunteer clinic complaining of thickening of the skin on his scalp. The lesions are not itchy, cross the hairline, and are not associated with loss of hair as shown in the given image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pityriasis amiantacea

 

Explanation: 

  • Pityriasis amiantacea is a scalp condition characterized by the formation of thick, asbestos-like scales that adhere to the hair shafts.

  • While the lesions are typically not itchy, they could cause hair loss if left untreated.
  • Can be secondary to an underlying inflammatory skin disorder such as:
    • Psoriasis
    • Lichen simplex
    • Scalp infections
  • Treatment
    • Topical corticosteroids
    • Keratolytic agents

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option B) is a scalp condition with red, itchy, greasy scales that affects areas rich in sebaceous glands, like the scalp, face, and upper trunk it can be caused by the fungi Malassezia furfur.

 

Pityriasis rosea (Option C) presents with oval-shaped, pink, or red patches on the trunk, arms, or legs. It doesn't involve the scalp, and the lesions don't cross the hairline. It is also caused by Malassezia furfur.

Tinea barbae (Option D) is a fungal infection of the beard area in men, characterized by erythematous plaques and pustules.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmias presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis. The physician considers prescribing either terfenadine or fexofenadine for symptom relief. Which differentiating factors should be considered when selecting the appropriate antihistamine for this patient?

choices.text: Fexofenadine is more likely to cause sedation.
Fexofenadine is more potent than terfenadine.
Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.
Fexofenadine is more expensive than terfenadine.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.

Explanation:

  • Terfenadine, a first-generation antihistamine, is associated with a risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes, due to its effects on cardiac potassium channels.
  • In contrast, fexofenadine, the active metabolite of terfenadine, has a lower propensity for such cardiac adverse effects.

Feature

Terfenadine

Fexofenadine

Type

First-generation antihistamine

Second-generation antihistamine

Cardiac toxicity

Withdrawn due to risk of cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., Torsades de Pointes) when co-administered with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

(Note: CAT drugs - Cisapride, Astemizole, and Terfenadine have been withdrawn due to cardiotoxicity).

Generally considered safer with minimal risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

Drug Interactions

Prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Less prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

CNS Penetration

Penetrates blood-brain barrier.

Poor penetration of the blood-brain barrier.

Pharmacokinetics

Metabolism leads to a longer half-life and duration of action.

Minimal metabolism, shorter half-life, and shorter duration of action.

Sedative Effects

It may cause sedation and impair psychomotor performance.

Minimal sedation or impairment of psychomotor performance.

 

Fexofenadine is more likely to cause sedation (Option A): Incorrect; both cause minimal sedation, and fexofenadine is less sedating.

Fexofenadine is more potent than terfenadine (Option B): Incorrect; potency is similar as fexofenadine is terfenadine’s active metabolite.

Fexofenadine is more expensive than terfenadine (Option D): Incorrect; cost is variable and not the main clinical differentiator.

questions.text: A patient underwent unilateral orchiectomy for a swelling in the right testis. The specimen is sent for histopathological examination, and its microscopic appearance is depicted in the image below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: 3 different sizes of tumour cells are seen
Tumor cells are arranged in sheets
Tumor cells have a watery-clear cytoplasm

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Tumor cells have a watery-clear cytoplasm

Explanation:

The given histopathological image shows features suggestive of testicular seminoma.

Histology of seminoma:

  • The tumor shows cells with watery, clear cytoplasm (described as a “fried-egg” or clear cell appearance) due to glycogen accumulation, which is PAS positive.
  • The tumor cells are arranged in nests separated by fibrous septa, and within these septa there is lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration.
  • This triad of clear cytoplasm, nests of tumor cells, and lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate is characteristic of seminoma.

 

3 different sizes of tumour cells (small, medium and giant cells) are seen in a case of spermatocytic seminoma. (Option A)

Endodermal sinuses-like structures called Schiller-Duval bodies are present in the case of a yolk sac tumour. (Option B)

Tumor cells arranged in sheets are typical of embryonal carcinoma, whereas in seminoma, tumor cells are arranged in nests with intervening fibrous septa. (Option C)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in his legs. He has had a history of intermittent facial flushing and diarrhea for the past several years. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Carcinoid heart disease

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of facial flushing, diarrhea, and a newly detected heart murmur, coupled with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (such as leg swelling and shortness of breath), strongly points toward carcinoid heart disease.
  • Carcinoid heart disease is a complication of carcinoid syndrome, which results from the release of serotonin and other vasoactive substances by a carcinoid tumor.

Pathophysiology:

  • Plaque-like deposits composed of smooth muscle cells, myofibroblasts, extracellular matrix and an overlying endothelial layer which lead to valve dysfunction.
  • Valvular dysfunction can lead to edema, ascites and right-sided heart failure.
  • Pulmonary heart disease primarily affects the right side of the heart.
  • Within the right heart, the tricuspid valve is the first to be affected, followed by the pulmonary valve.
  • Regurgitant lesions are more common than stenotic lesions.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is evaluated by her obstetrician for routine prenatal care. She reports occasional palpitations and mild shortness of breath but has no significant past medical history. The physician explains that these symptoms can be related to normal cardiac changes in pregnancy. Which of the following is a physiological cardiac change typically observed during pregnancy?

choices.text: Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume
Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension
Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume
Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume


Explanation:
During pregnancy, the heart rate increases by up to 17%, and the stroke volume increases by up to 27%. As a result of this, Cardiac Output increases as

  • Cardiac Output = Heart Rate x Stroke Volume.

Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume (Option A): Cardiac output is not decreased, but it is increased in pregnancy

Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension (Option B): There is a decrease in systemic vascular resistance, so BP falls during pregnancy.

Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone (Option D): There is increase in heart rate during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of primary chronic mitral regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ischemic cardiomyopathy

Explanation: 

Primary chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) refers to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve itself. Ischemic cardiomyopathy causes secondary (functional) mitral regurgitation due to left ventricular dilation or dysfunction, not a primary structural issue of the valve.

 

MITRAL REGURGITATION

Etiology

(Options B, C & D ruled out)

Pathophysiology

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a chain-breaking antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D- Glutathione Peroxidase

Glutathione Peroxidase is a preventive antioxidant, not a chain-breaking antioxidant.

Antioxidants are substances that help control and reduce lipid peroxidation by neutralizing free radicals, which can cause cellular damage.

Classification of Antioxidants:

1. Preventive Antioxidants:
