  • Reduce the rate of chain initiation.
  • Examples:
    • Glutathione Peroxidase (Option D)
    • Catalase
    • Selenium

2. Chain-Breaking Antioxidants (Option A, B and C ruled out):
  • Interfere with chain propagation by stabilizing free radicals.
  • Examples:
    • α-Tocopherol (Vitamin E)
    • β-Carotene (Vitamin A)
    • Vitamin C
    • Superoxide Dismutase (SOD)

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute onset right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, he has right lower quadrant rebound tenderness and guarding. The doctor decides to take him up for an emergency surgery.

Which inhalation anaesthetic would be best for induction in this patient based on its MAC values and blood gas solubility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Sevoflurane

Explanation:

  • Sevoflurane has a moderate MAC value (2%) and is also preferred for its additional benefit of rapid induction and recovery times due to its relatively low blood-gas solubility.
  • The patient’s complaints and clinical features point towards the suspicion of Appendicitis. Hence, he is possibly being taken up for an emergency laparoscopic appendicectomy.
  • COMPOUND A of sevoflurane causes renal toxicity

 

MAC Definition:

The concentration of the general anaesthetic in the alveoli of the lung that produces unresponsiveness to the surgical incision in 50% of patients.

 

Nitrous oxide (Option A): It has a very high MAC value (105%) and is not potent enough to be used as a sole anaesthetic agent.

 

Desflurane (Option C): It has a MAC value of around 6%, so it is less potent than sevoflurane. However, it has a very rapid onset and offset, making it suitable for short procedures and outpatient surgeries.

 

Halothane (Option D): It has a very low MAC value (0.75%), indicating high potency, but it is associated with significant side effects, including hepatotoxicity, and is less commonly used today.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with headaches, visual disturbances, and delayed growth. An MRI of the brain reveals a 3 cm cystic mass with calcifications. The growth was found to be encapsulated and multiloculated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

Craniopharyngioma: 

  • Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumours arising from vestigial remnants of the Rathke pouch
  • They commonly occur in the suprasellar region and often present as encapsulated and multiloculated cystic masses with calcifications. 
  • The cysts contain cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid (compared to machine oi)l
  • It has 2 histological variants: Adamantinomatous and papillary. 

Feature

Adamantinomatous

Papillary

Age group

Children

Adults

Epithelium

Stratified squamous

Stratified squamous

Wet keratin

+

-

Calcifications

+

-

Cysts

+

-

Stellate reticulum

+

-

 

  • Common presentations include headaches and visual disturbances like bitemporal hemianopia due to optic chiasma compression, while children present with growth retardation due to pituitary hypofunction and GH deficiency.

 

Oligodendroglioma (Option A): Typically affects adults (30–50 years old). Commonly located in cerebral hemispheres, not suprasellar. Calcifications can be present, but they are intra-axial and not cystic or multiloculated. Endocrine symptoms are rare. Age and symptom mismatch

Meningioma (Option B):Rare in children; typically seen in middle-aged to older adults. Usually extra-axial, solid, may calcify but are not cystic or multiloculated. Often incidentally found unless very large. Does not cause hormonal dysfunction in children. Age and imaging mismatch

Pituitary Adenoma(Option D): Unlikely in a child .Pituitary adenomas are rare in children. Typically cause endocrine symptoms, but visual changes in children from adenomas are uncommon. Less likely to be calcified or multiloculated. Usually solid tumors, not cystic. Age, imaging, and morphology mismatch

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman with a history of 3 first-trimester miscarriages and regular menstrual cycles had an HSG showing an indented external uterine contour. MRI confirms two separate endometrial cavities with a partial outer uterine indentation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bicornuate uterus

Explanation:

Differentiating a Bicornuate and Septate Uterus plays a crucial role in arriving at a diagnosis.

  • 3D sonography and MRI provide accurate assessments.

Gold standard- Hysteroscopy + Diagnostic Laparoscopy

Didelphys uterus (Option C) arises from the complete failure of the fusion of the Mullerian ducts, resulting in two separate uterine cavities, each with its cervix. It can also present with two vaginas. On HSG/MRI, two separate uterine bodies with no connection between them are seen.

There is an increased incidence of breech and preterm labor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Nocardia and Actinomyces is false?

choices.text: Actinomyces infections are endogenous, whereas Nocardia infections are exogenous.
Actinomyces is nonacid-fast, while Nocardia is partially acid-fast.
Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Nocardia infections.
Nocardia is an obligate aerobe, whereas Actinomyces is anaerobic.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the role of physiological pH of the vagina?

choices.text: The acidic pH of the vagina helps prevent the growth of pathogenic organisms.
Doderlein’s bacillus is responsible for maintaining the acidic pH by converting glycogen to lactic acid under the influence of estrogen.
Doderlein’s bacillus appears in the vagina 3–4 days after birth and disappears after 10–14 days, to reappear at puberty.
An increased vaginal pH can predispose to infections such as vulvovaginal candidiasis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) An increased vaginal pH can predispose to infections such as vulvovaginal candidiasis.

Explanation:

Vulvovaginal candidiasis (yeast infection) typically occurs in a physiological pH of vagina (acidic environment) and is not associated with an increased vaginal pH.

The infections that typically occur in increased vaginal pH are Trichomoniasis and bacterial vaginosis.

Normal physiological pH of vagina i.e. 3.8-5.0 (acidic) helps prevent the growth of pathogenic organisms (Option A). Certain microorganisms thrive when vaginal pH is increased.

Vaginal pH is maintained by the Doderlein’s bacillus which converts glycogen to lactic acid under the influence of estrogen (Option B). Doderlein’s bacillus appears in the vagina 3–4 days after birth, disappears after 10–14 days, and reappears at puberty when estrogen levels rise (Option C).

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is scheduled for an ERCP using the contrast mentioned below. Which type of contrast agent is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Non-ionic Monomer

 

  • Iohexol is an iodine contrast agent that is classified as a Non-ionic monomer.
  • The commonly used iodine contrast agents are water soluble and are classified into ionic and non-ionic groups based on their osmolality and chemical structure.
  • The iodine particle ratio helps decide the osmolality of the drug, where high osmolar drugs pose a higher risk for kidney damage.

 

Iodine Particle Ratio

  • Seizures
 

-

Mild reactions:

  • Hives (Urticaria)
  • Erythema (Redness of skin)
 

Moderate to severe reactions:

  • Wheezing
  • Anaphylactoid reactions (Non-IgE mediated)
  • Also known as Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (AKI).
  • It is defined as an increase in serum creatinine by > 0.5 mg/dL or a > 25% rise from the baseline within 3 days of contrast administration, without any other clear cause.
  • Risk factors:
    • Patients with pre-existing kidney disease.
    • Pre-contrast eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m² indicates higher risk.

Management:

Observation for mild reactions

Management:

  • Mild reactions: Antihistamines (e.g., Diphenhydramine)
  • Severe reactions: Requires epinephrine and advanced airway management as needed.

Management:

Intravenous hydration (e.g., normal saline)

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by their parents reporting that their infant is not meeting developmental milestones, such as rolling over or sitting up. On examination, the infant has eczema and a noticeable musty odor. Hair and skin pigmentation appear lighter. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Explanation:

  • The infant’s symptoms, like failure to meet developmental milestones, eczema, a musty odor, and lighter hair and skin pigmentation, are characteristic of Phenylketonuria (PKU).
  • PKU is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).
  • This enzyme deficiency disrupts the body's ability to metabolize the amino acid phenylalanine, leading to its accumulation in the body.

 

Deficiency in tyrosinase (Option B) causes albinism. It does not typically present with a musty odor or developmental delays.

 

Deficiency in tyrosine aminotransferase (Option C) can cause tyrosinemia type 2, which primarily affects the eyes and skin but does not present with a musty odor or developmental delays

 

Deficiency in 4-HPPD (Option D) is less common and typically does not include the musty odor. It causes tyrosinemia type- 3 (Hawkinsuria) with a swimming pool (chlorine) odor.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements from the following:

 

a)BCG vaccine for TB- primary

b)BCG for Ca bladder- secondary

c)OCP for contraception- primary

d)OCP for PCOD- secondary
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a,b,c,d

 

Explanation:

  • Secondary prevention focuses on the early detection and prompt treatment of diseases to prevent their progression to more advanced or severe stages. This includes screening and early diagnosis.
  • Primary prevention focuses on interventions to prevent the onset of disease.




 

Level of Prevention

Goals

Examples

Primordial

To prevent the establishment of risk factors
  • Lifestyle modification
  • Health promotion

Primary

Interventions to prevent the onset of disease
  • Vaccinations (statement a)
  • Health education
  • Family planning (statement c)
  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Pre-placement examination

Secondary

Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications
  • Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears)
  • Self-examinations
  • Health camps with screening
  • DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy.
  • Treatment (statement b and d )

Tertiary

Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physical therapy
  • Chronic disease management programs
  • Reconstructive surgery

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no medical comorbidities complaints of involuntary leakage of urine primarily when she coughs or sneezes. She has tried Kegel exercises, lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding caffeine, and pessary but these have not significantly improved her symptoms. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Colposuspension surgery

Explanation:

In this scenario, all the conservative and less invasive measures have failed. Hence, the next best step in management is colposuspension surgery.

Treatment of urinary incontinence:

Type of urinary Incontinence

Stress urinary Incontinence

Urgency urinary Incontinence

Overflow Incontinence

Step 1
  • Lifestyle
  • Weight loss in obese individuals
  • Reduce fluid and caffeine intake
  • Avoiding bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, carbonated drinks)
  • Restrict intake of fluid to 1 liter/day

If non-obstructive pathology

  • Continuous catheter drainage
  • Intermittent self-catheterization

Step 2
  • Pelvic floor muscle training( Kegel exercises)
  • Biofeedback therapy
  • Scheduled Voiding
  • Bladder retraining
  • Scheduled voiding

If obstructive pathology

  • Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin for bladder outlet obstruction)
  • Urethroplasty for urethral strictures

Step 3

Medical Treatment

  • Estrogen
  • Sympathomimetic drugs (α-adrenergic) Imipramine

Medical Treatment

  • Anticholinergics:
  1. Oxybutynin
  2. Tolterodine
  3. Fesoterodine fumarate
  4. Darifenacin
  • Beta -3 adrenergic agonist (Mirabegron* )
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., imipramine)
  

Step 4

Devices

  • Pessary
  • Urethral Inserts

Neuromodulation

  • Sacral nerve stimulation
  • Peripheral tibial nerve stimulation

Intradetrusor botulinum toxin A injection

 

  

Step 5

Surgical Treatment

  • Colposuspension
  • Midurethral tape

Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT)

Transobturator tape (TOT)

  • Microslings
  • Bladder neck suspension
  • Bulking agents injection
  • Others

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz (MMK)

Paravaginal repair

Surgical Treatment

  • Cystoplasty (to increase bladder capacity)
  • Urinary diversion procedures (eg. ileal conduit)
  
  • Note: Mirabegron contraindicated in severe uncontrolled hypertension systolic blood pressure ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≤ 110 mm Hg, or both
  • Mirabegron is better tolerated than antimuscarinics in older patients and can be considered as an alternative to antimuscarinics for elderly patients.

questions.text: A 35 year old man visits the clinic with a persistent cough and fever lasting for more than 2 weeks. He also reports experiencing night sweats and significant weight loss over the past month. Sputum smear tests or radiological tests are not yet done. According to the new terminologies in NTEP, how should this patient's case be categorized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Presumptive TB case

 

Explanation:

  • The patient should be categorized as a "Presumptive TB case" according to NTEP's new terminologies as the patient is showing cough, fever or night sweats & apparent loss in weight for more than 2 weeks.
  • The term Presumptive TB case is used in place of TB suspect (Option B) and refers to individuals who show symptoms suggestive of TB but have not yet been confirmed with a diagnosis.
  • This term is crucial for early identification and screening of TB cases to initiate timely diagnosis and treatment.
  • The new NTEP changes in terminologies are as follows:

Category

Description

Criteria/Features

Presumptive TB Case
  • Used in place of TB suspect.
  • Individuals showing symptoms suggestive of TB but not yet confirmed.
  • Cough, Fever, Night sweats +- Weight loss > 2 weeks

Clinically Diagnosed TB Case

(Option A)
  • Sputum negative but with high clinical suspicion of TB.
  • Used in place of Sputum negative TB case. (Option C)
  • Persistent symptoms despite negative sputum smear
  • High clinical suspicion based on symptoms, radiological and histological features

Bacteriologically Confirmed TB Case
  • Biological specimen is positive for sputum AFB and/or CBNAAT.
  • Used in place of Sputum positive TB case.
  • Positive sputum smear for AFB
  • Positive CBNAAT test confirming the presence of TB bacteria

questions.text: Based on the image provided, which of the following statements is TRUE?

choices.text: Measure from the acromion to the olecranon and mark the midpoint.
MUAC assesses the nutritional status of children aged three months to five years.
In Shakir’s tape, the Yellow zone indicates 11.5 to 13.5 cm.
In Shakir’s tape, the Green zone indicates >11.5 cm.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Measure from the acromion to the olecranon and mark the midpoint

 

Explanation:

 

MID UPPER ARM CIRCUMFERENCE (MUAC)

Definition
  • MUAC - used to assess the nutritional status of children aged 6 months to 5 years. (Option B)
  • In infants under 6 months old, the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) is not utilised as a measurement criterion.

Procedure
  • Ensure the child is standing straight with their left arm free of clothing. The arm should be bent at a right angle.
  • Measure the distance between the tip of the shoulder (acromion) and the tip of the elbow (olecranon). Mark the midpoint on the upper arm. (Option A)
  • The child's arm should hang relaxed by their side, with the palm facing the thigh.
  • Use a MUAC tape to wrap around the marked midpoint of the arm. The tape should be snug but not tight enough to pinch the skin.
  • Record the measurement at the zero mark of the tape.

Shakir’s Tape

The tape is marked with different zones that correspond to various levels of malnutrition:

  • Red Zone: Indicates severe malnutrition (MUAC < 11.5 cm).
  • Yellow Zone: Indicates moderate malnutrition (MUAC between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm). (Option C)
  • Green Zone: Indicates healthy nutritional status (MUAC > 12.5 cm) (Option D)
 

SHAKIR’S TAPE

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman presents with persistent knee pain after recently undergoing bariatric surgery. She reports a history of significant weight loss and intermittent joint swelling. MRI was taken which revealed the following. What is the most likely reason behind this patient's condition?

choices.text: Postoperative autoimmune response leading to synovitis
Fat embolism from rapid adipose tissue breakdown

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat embolism from rapid adipose tissue breakdown

 

Explanation:

  • MRI reveals bone marrow oedema in the distal femur and proximal tibia which suggests osteonecrosis.
  • Rapid weight loss can lead to fat mobilisation and subsequent fat embolism, resulting in vascular obstruction and ischemia, which are key contributors to osteonecrosis.

 

Causes of Osteonecrosis

Trauma:

Fractures or dislocations disrupt blood supply, especially in the femoral neck, scaphoid, and talus.

Corticosteroid Use:

High-dose steroids cause fat cell swelling and intravascular stasis, leading to bone ischemia

Alcohol Abuse:

Chronic alcohol use leads to fat embolism and marrow swelling, causing venous stasis.

Sickle Cell Disease:

Sickled red cells obstruct blood vessels, leading to ischemia and bone death.

Gaucher’s Disease:

Lipid accumulation in bone marrow causes vascular compression and ischemia

Thrombophilia:

Increased blood clotting tendency leads to capillary thrombosis, causing bone necrosis.

Antiphospholipid Antibodies:

As seen in SLE, these antibodies promote clot formation, leading to ischemia.

Fat Embolism:

Fat emboli block capillaries, causing endothelial damage and thrombosis.

Venous Stasis:

Marrow swelling increases intraosseous pressure, leading to venous blockage and ischemia.

Dysbaric Osteonecrosis:.

Rapid decompression (e.g., in divers) causes gas bubbles in vessels, leading to bone necrosis.

Pregnancy:

Hormonal changes and fatty liver can decrease fibrinolysis, increasing clot formation.

Radiation Exposure:

Radiation damages blood vessels, leading to poor blood flow and bone necrosis

Postoperative autoimmune response leading to synovitis (Option A):

  • Postoperative autoimmune response leading to synovitis typically presents with widespread joint symptoms and inflammatory markers rather than localised bone marrow oedema seen in osteonecrosis

Osteoporosis due to nutritional deficiencies (Option C):

  • Nutritional deficiencies can lead to weakened bones, but they neither cause intermittent swelling nor osteonecrosis as suggested by the MRI findings.

Bed rest post-surgery (Option D):

  • Prolonged immobility could cause stiffness but is less likely to explain significant pain and swelling and the osteonecrosis suggested by the MRI findings.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the nature of vegetation in infective endocarditis (IE)?

choices.text: Typically contain only fibrin and inflammatory cells
Most commonly found on the tricuspid valve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prone to embolisation

Explanation:

  • Vegetation in infective endocarditis is large and bulky, typically composed of fibrin, platelets, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells (Option B)

  • Embolization: Due to bulkiness, parts of the vegetation can break off, and these detached fragments are called emboli, which can travel through the bloodstream, causing systemic embolization. 

  • Embolization is common but not guaranteed.

Smooth and non-destructive lesions (Option A): Seen in non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE), not in infective endocarditis.

Contain only fibrin and inflammatory cells (Option B): IE vegetations also include microorganisms and platelets.

Most commonly found on the tricuspid valve (Option D): True mainly in IV drug users; overall, the mitral valve is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: What is the primary function of the Rapoport-Luebering Shunt in red blood cells?

choices.text: To produce 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate, which regulates oxygen binding to hemoglobin
To facilitate the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) To produce 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate, which regulates oxygen binding to hemoglobin

Explanation:

The Rapoport-Luebering Shunt forms 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) through a series of enzymatic reactions involving 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (1,3-BPG).

  • Formation of 1,3-BPG:
    • In glycolysis, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is converted to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate by the enzyme glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.
    • This reaction involves the addition of an inorganic phosphate and the reduction of NAD+ to NADH.
  • Conversion to 2,3-BPG:
    • In the Rapoport-Luebering Shunt, 1,3-BPG is converted to 2,3-BPG by the enzyme bisphosphoglycerate mutase.
    • This reaction shifts the phosphate group from the first carbon to the second carbon of the glycerate molecule, forming 2,3-BPG.
  • Conversion of 2,3-BPG to 3-phosphoglycerate:
    • 2,3-BPG can be hydrolyzed to 3-phosphoglycerate by the enzyme 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate phosphatase.
    • This reaction removes a phosphate group, resulting in the formation of 3-phosphoglycerate, which then re-enters the glycolytic pathway.

 

The Rapoport-Luebering Shunt does not generate ATP; it bypasses an ATP-generating step in glycolysis (Option A).

 

The conversion of pyruvate to lactate is a function of lactate dehydrogenase and is not related to the Rapoport-Luebering Shunt (Option C).

 

The conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate is catalyzed by hexokinase or glucokinase and occurs at the very beginning of glycolysis, unrelated to the Rapoport-Luebering Shunt (Option D).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has undergone cataract surgery. He has now returned after 6 weeks with endophthalmitis. What is the most likely organism that caused the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Propionibacterium acnes

 

Explanation:

The scenario is that of late-onset postoperative endophthalmitis

  • Endophthalmitis is inflammation of the inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers

 

Delayed onset endophthalmitis:

 

Onset

  • After 6-weeks of intraocular surgery

Course
  • Slow, with a panuveitis-like picture

Clinical Features
  • Granulomatous keratic precipitates
  • Inflammatory deposits over intraocular lens (IOL)
  • White capsular plaque
  • Anterior chamber reaction
  • Vitritis
  • Cystoid macular edema (CME)

Response to Treatment
  • May respond to periocular or systemic steroids but usually recurs

Common Causative Organisms
  • Bacterial: Propionibacterium acnes (most common), Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus
  • Fungal: Aspergillus, Candida, and others

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the nose are true?

 


	The anterior sloping part of the roof of the nose is formed by the nasal bones.
	The floor of the nose is formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone.
	The posterior sloping part of the roof of the nose is formed by the body of the sphenoid bone.
	The anterior three-fourths of the floor of the nose is formed by the palatine process of the maxilla.
	The posterior one-fourth of the floor of the nose is formed by the horizontal part of the sphenoid bone.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

Each nasal cavity features a lateral wall, a medial wall, a roof, and a floor.

 

Roof of the nose

Floor of the nose
  • Anterior Sloping Part: Formed by the nasal bones. (Statement 1)
  • Posterior Sloping Part: Formed by the body of the sphenoid bone. (Statement 3)
  • Middle Horizontal Part: Formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone (passage of olfactory nerves into the nasal cavity). (Statement 2)
  • Anterior Three-Fourths: Formed by the palatine process of the maxilla. (Statement 4)
  • Posterior One-Fourth: Formed by the horizontal part of the palatine bone. (Statement 5)

questions.text: An 18 year old girl comes to the OPD with complaints of irregular cycles, weight gain and excessive hair growth on the face. You are suspecting PCOS. What will be the initial management for hirsutism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) OCPs with cyproterone acetate

Acne and Hirsutism treatment in PCOS

  • Oral combined pills with spironolactone

 

Lifestyle changes

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient diagnosed with mild Crohn's disease affecting the ileocecal region presents to your clinic. The patient has mild symptoms with no significant systemic involvement. What is the most appropriate first-line drug to prescribe for this patient to induce remission in mild Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Budesonide

 

Explanation:

  • Budesonide is a first-line treatment for inducing remission in mild to moderate Crohn's disease, especially when the disease is localized in the ileocecal region.
  • It is a corticosteroid with a high first-pass metabolism, resulting in fewer systemic side effects than corticosteroids like prednisone.

 

Category

Mild Crohn's Disease

Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease

Induction Therapy
  • First-line: Budesonide (Option D) (preferred for ileocecal disease)or aminosalicylates (e.g., mesalamine).
  • Prednisone (Option A) for those who do not respond to budesonide.
  • Alternative: Enteral nutrition.
  • First-line: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone for short term) or biologics
    Anti-TNF agents (Infliximab (Option C), Adalimumab)
  • Anti-integrin therapy (Vedolizumab)
  • Anti-interleukin therapy (Ustekinumab)
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents plus immunomodulators (Azathioprine, 6-MP) (Option B)

Maintenance Therapy
  • First-line: Continue aminosalicylates if effective.
  • Alternative: Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP) for patients intolerant to aminosalicylates.
  • Anti-TNF monotherapy: Long-term for maintaining remission.
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents with immunomodulators (for severe cases or history of nonresponse to biologics).
  • Continue anti-integrin or anti-interleukin agents for those induced by these therapies

Monitoring
  • Regular follow-up to monitor symptoms and inflammation.
  • Ileocolonoscopy 6-12 months post-remission. Drug level monitoring and fecal calprotectin to assess mucosal healing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss in his right ear. Audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss, and an MRI shows no abnormalities in the cochlear nerve. A defect in converting mechanical sound vibrations into electrical signals is suspected. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Organ of Corti

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with sensorineural hearing loss, typically caused by damage to the inner ear or the neural pathways responsible for hearing.
  • Given the defect in converting mechanical sound vibrations into electrical signals, the likely issue lies in the Organ of Corti, where the hair cells transduce sound vibrations into electrical impulses.

  • The Organ of Corti, located on the basilar membrane inside the cochlea, contains the hair cells responsible for the hearing transduction mechanism.
  • When sound waves are transmitted through the ear and reach the inner ear, they cause vibrations of the basilar membrane, which bend stereocilia on the hair cells.
  • Inner hair cells are arranged in a single row, while outer hair cells form three to four rows.
  • Inner hair cells transmit auditory stimuli to the brain, while outer hair cells modulate inner hair cell function to enhance sound sensitivity and clarity.
  • This bending opens ion channels, generating electrical impulses.
  • These impulses are sent through the auditory nerve to the brain, where they are interpreted as sound.

Oval window (Option A) is a membrane-covered opening between the middle and inner ear.

  • It plays a role in the mechanical conduction of sound by transmitting vibrations from the stapes to the fluid in the cochlea but is in converting those vibrations into electrical signals.

Tympanic membrane (Option C) vibrates in response to sound and transmits from the external ear to the ossicles of the middle ear.

  • Damage leads to conductive hearing loss but doesn't affect sound transduction.

Stapes footplate (Option D):

  • This structure amplifies sound waves but involves the conductive hearing process, not sensorineural conversion.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a history of self-harm, chronic emptiness, and unstable relationships often alternates between idealizing and devaluing others. What defense mechanism is most commonly observed in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Splitting

Explanation:

  • Splitting is a common defense mechanism in borderline personality disorder, where individuals view people or situations as either all good or all bad, contributing to their unstable relationships.

 

BORDERLINE PERSONALITY DISORDER:

 

General Characteristics

  • More common in females than in males.
  • Persons with BPD are often in a state of crisis, with frequent mood swings, shifting from being argumentative to depressed, and later feeling numb.
  • They can experience short-lived psychotic episodes and their behavior is highly unpredictable,

 

Self-Destructive Behaviors

  • Repetitive self-destructive acts such as wrist slashing or self-mutilation, often to elicit help from others, express anger, or numb overwhelming emotions.

 

Interpersonal Relationships

  • Individuals with BPD have tumultuous interpersonal relationships, feeling both dependent on others and hostile toward them when frustrated.
  • They cannot tolerate being alone and prefer companionship, even in unhealthy relationships.

 

Identity and Emotional Experience

  • Chronic feelings of emptiness, boredom, and a lack of a consistent sense of identity (identity diffusion) are common, with some complaining of feeling depressed despite fluctuating moods.

 

Distorted Relationships

  • Relationships are distorted, with others seen as either "all good" or "all bad" due to splitting, leading to idealization or devaluation of people.

 

Defense Mechanism

  • Projective identification is a common defense mechanism, where patients project unacceptable aspects of themselves onto others, inducing them to play the projected role.

 

Treatment

  • Dialectical behaviour therapy.
  • Mentalization based therapy.
  • Transference: Focussed Psychotherapy.
  • Pharmacotherapy: Antipsychotics, antidepressants, mood stabilizers like carbamazepine.

 

Sublimation (Option A) is a mature defense mechanism where individuals redirect unacceptable impulses or emotions into socially acceptable behaviors or activities.

Rationalization (Option C) involves explaining away or justifying behaviors or feelings to make them seem more acceptable or less distressing.

Displacement (Option D) involves shifting emotions from a threatening target to a safer one, such as expressing anger toward a friend instead of an authority figure.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with redness, mild swelling, and foreign body sensation in the right eye for 2 days. On examination, no visual impairment is noted, and a diagnosis of acute conjunctivitis is made. Which of the following is not a common sign of conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)

 

Explanation:

Ciliary congestion, also known as ciliary injection, is not a sign of conjunctivitis. It refers to deep, radial vessel congestion around the limbus, usually associated with intraocular conditions like iritis, keratitis, or acute glaucoma. The vessels here are part of the deeper structure of the eye, unlike the superficial vessels involved in conjunctivitis.

 

Symptoms and Signs of Conjunctivitis:

  • Hyperemia or redness of the conjunctiva (Option B)
  • Pain
  • Photophobia (rare, associated corneal involvement or iritis can be present)
  • Blepharospasm
  • Discharge (prominent feature)
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage (Option C)
  • Chemosis or conjunctival edema (Option A)
  • Inflammatory reactions: Follicles (localized aggregation of lymphocytes), papillae (hyperplasia of the normal vascular system), granulomas
  • Pseudomembranes/True membranes

 

Feature

Conjunctival Congestion

Ciliary Congestion

Location of Congestion

Confined to the conjunctiva, often more marked in the fornices.

Involves the area around the corneal margin, known as the limbal region.

On moving conjunctiva

Congested vessels also move

Congested vessels do not move

Common Causes

Bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, viral conjunctivitis

Acute iridocyclitis, acute glaucoma, keratitis, corneal ulcer.

Image

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the community health centre with a fever, malaise, and an itchy, vesicular rash (shown in the image below) that began two days ago. The child's mother asks when it will be safe for her child to return to school without posing a risk of spreading the infection to other children. What is the appropriate advice regarding the duration of isolation for this child to prevent the spread of this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Until all lesions are crusted

Explanation:

  • The given scenario and rash in the image depict Chickenpox caused by the varicella-zoster virus.
  • It is highly contagious and primarily spreads through respiratory droplets and direct contact with vesicular fluid from the rash.
  • Proper isolation and prevention strategies are crucial to prevent the spread of this infection, especially in settings like schools.

 

Period of isolation:

  • The separation of infected individuals or animals from others during the period when they can transmit the infection.

 

Disease

Duration of isolation

Chickenpox

Until all lesions are crusted, usually 6 days after the onset of the rash (Option D)

Measles

7 days after the onset of rash (Option A)

Diphtheria

Until 48 hrs of antibiotics or negative cultures after treatment (Option B)

Salmonellosis

Until 3 negative stool cultures (Option C)

Pertussis

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease

Mumps

Until swelling subsides

Tuberculosis

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy

Cholera

3 days after tetracycline started

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Enlarged kidneys:

  • Patients with ADTKD-MUC1 have mutations in MUC1 gene. Kidney histology shows tubulointerstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy leading to small fibrotic kidneys with medullary cysts
  • ADTKD-UMOD is caused by mutations in the UMOD gene, which encodes the protein uromodulin, also known as Tamm-Horsfall protein. These patients have associated gout.

questions.text: A 24-year-old burns patient is receiving fluid resuscitation and is being closely monitored. What should his ideal urine output be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 0.5 mL/kg/hr

 

Explanation:

  • During fluid resuscitation, burns patients should be closely monitored
  • The main aspect of monitoring is urine output.

A urinary output of 0.5 mL/kg/hr in adults and 1 mL/kg/hr in children should always be maintained to prevent over and under-perfusion.

Patient Group Target Urine Output
Adults ≥ 0.5 mL/kg/hr
Children 1–2 mL/kg/hr

questions.text: A patient experiences persistent shoulder pain and weakness after a fall. An MRI reveals a full-thickness rotator cuff tear. Which statement correctly describes the classification of rotator cuff tears?

choices.text: Full-thickness tears involve bursal side tear, within tendon substance
Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side
Full-thickness tears are typically caused by overuse and repetitive stress
Partial-thickness tears develop gradually due to impingement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Rotator Cuff Anatomy and Tear Classification

Anatomy of the Rotator Cuff

  • Muscles Involved:
    • Supraspinatus
    • Infraspinatus
    • Teres minor
    • Subscapularis (collectively known as SITS)

Anterior view:

Posterior view:

  • Functions:
    • Stabilizes the shoulder joint
    • Assists in arm rotation and lifting
    • Controls shoulder blade movement

Role of Specific Muscles

  • Supraspinatus & Infraspinatus:
    • Keep the humeral head secure in the glenoid during arm abduction.
  • Subscapularis:
    • Stabilizes the front of the shoulder joint.
    • Prevents anterior dislocation of the humeral head.

Classification of Rotator Cuff Tears

Type

Description

Common Causes

Partial-Thickness Tears

Involve damage to some fibers of the tendon; can occur on:

Bursal side (top)

Articular side (bottom)

Within tendon substance (Option A ruled out) (Option B)

Overuse, repetitive stress (Option C ruled out)

Full-Thickness Tears

Complete rupture of the tendon; not attached to the bone

Sudden injuries (e.g., falls), gradual development due to stress or impingement (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: The following sign in breast MRI is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The "Linguine Sign" is a characteristic MRI finding of an intracapsular breast implant rupture.

  • Intracapsular Rupture: The implant shell breaks, but the fibrous capsule remains intact, preventing silicone from leaking out.
    • On MRI, the collapsed shell appears as multiple wavy lines, resembling linguine.
    • On USG, it appears a stepladder appearance.
  • Extracapsular Rupture: Silicone escapes beyond the fibrous capsule, often seen as the "Snowstorm Sign" on ultrasound. (Option C)

Other MRI Signs:

  • "Keyhole Sign" / "Teardrop Sign": Silicone on both sides of a radial fold suggests rupture.
  • "Salad Oil Sign": Seen in double-lumen implant rupture with mixing of saline and silicone.

Management: Surgical removal is recommended to prevent silicone migration and complications.

 

Fibrocystic breast disease (Option A):

  • Benign condition with lumpy, painful breasts. Common imaging findings include cystic changes, fibrosis, and adenosis.

 

Fat necrosis of the breast (Option D):

  • Occurs due to trauma or surgery, presenting as oil cysts, calcifications, or irregular masses on mammography or ultrasound.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Stool cultures reveal the presence of a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that is oxidase-negative, ferments glucose, and reduces nitrate to nitrite. Which of the following bacteria is most likely the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Escherichia coli

 

Explanation:

E. coli is a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that ferments glucose and is oxidase-negative. It can reduce nitrate to nitrite and is a common cause of gastrointestinal infections, particularly diarrhea, in adults. Given the symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, along with the culture results, E. coli is the most likely causative agent.

 

Edwards-Ewing Classification of the Enterobacteriaceae Family

Tribes and Genera:

Tribe

Genus

Escherichiae

Escherichia (Option A), Shigella

Edwardsiellae

Edwardsiella

Salmonellae

Salmonella

Citrobacteriaceae

Citrobacter

Klebsielleae

Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Serratia, Hafnia, Pantoea

Proteae

Proteus, Providencia, Morganella

Yersinieae

Yersinia

Erwinieae

Erwinia

 

Characteristics of the Enterobacteriaceae Family (Option A)

  • Microscopy:
    • Gram-negative bacilli, appearing as rod-shaped bacteria.
    • Non-sporing, indicating they do not form spores for survival in harsh environments.
  • Oxygen Requirements:
    • Aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, meaning they can grow in the presence or absence of oxygen, providing them with versatility in various environments.
  • Motility:
    • Most members are motile due to peritrichous flagella, which are flagella distributed all over the surface of the bacteria.
    • Notable non-motile genera include Shigella and Klebsiella, which lack flagella.
  • Biochemical Properties:
    • Ferments glucose, producing both gas and acid as byproducts, a characteristic that can be useful in distinguishing these bacteria in the lab.
    • Reduces nitrates to nitrites, an important metabolic process that aids in the identification of specific species.
    • Produces catalase, which helps break down hydrogen peroxide, protecting the bacteria from oxidative damage.
    • Does not produce oxidase, distinguishing it from other similar families of bacteria.

 

Clostridium difficile (Option B): Clostridium difficile is gram-positive bacillus.

 

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C): Staphylococcus aureus is gram-positive cocci.


Vibrio cholerae (Option D): Vibrio cholerae is gram-negative curved bacilli with polar flagellum.

questions.text: Which of the following schemes is most closely related to providing unemployment relief to eligible individuals who have lost their jobs in specific circumstances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atal Beemit Vyakti Kalyan Yojana

Explanation:

 

Scheme

Description

Key Features

Atal Beemit Vyakti Kalyan Yojana
  • Provides financial assistance to employees covered under the ESI Act, 1948, who become unemployed.
  • Offers relief payment for up to 90 days, once in a lifetime.
  • The relief payment is 50% of the employee's wages.
  • To be eligible, the insured person must have been employed for at least two years and contributed for at least 78 days.

Abhiyan Indra Dhanush

(Option C)
  • Aims to enhance hygiene and cleanliness in ESIC hospitals.
  • Implements a VIBGYOR colour-coded pattern for changing bed sheets.

MGNREGA (Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act)

(Option D)
  • Guarantees 100 days of paid work to rural households.
  • Provides wage employment to households below the poverty line who are willing to perform unskilled manual labor.
  • Employment must be provided within 15 days of application; otherwise, the individual is entitled to unemployment allowance

questions.text: What is the image given below used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Local distribution of a disease

Explanation:

The image shows a spot map, which is useful for determining the local distribution of a disease.

Spot maps/Shaded maps:

  • It is useful in outbreaks to determine the local distribution of a disease.
  • Inner and outer city variations in disease frequency are well known.
  • These variations are best studied using spot maps.
  • They show areas of high and low frequency at a glance, the boundaries, and distribution.
  • For example, if the map shows a clustering of cases, it may suggest a common source of infection or a common risk factor shared by all the cases.
  • The classic example of the use of spot maps was by John Snow for the cholera epidemic in 1854.

Migration studies(Option D):They compare disease and death rates between migrants and their new environment versus their place of origin.

Rural-urban variation and National variation are not indicated by the spot maps (Option B & C)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presenting with persistent right ear fullness, hearing loss, and pressure particularly during flights is suspected of having Eustachian tube blockage. During rhinoscopy, a structure labelled as X in the image below is noted. Identify this structure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fossa of Rosenmuller

 

Explanation:

The structure marked ‘X’ in the above image is the fossa of rosenmuller.

Anatomy of Nasopharynx

  • The nasopharynx, also known as the epipharynx, is the uppermost portion of the pharynx, located behind the nasal cavities and extends from the base of the skull to the soft palate or the horizontal plane that passes through the hard palate.
  • Boundaries of the nasopharynx:

Boundaries

Relations

Roof

Formed by basisphenoid and basiocciput.

Posterior wall
  • C1 vertebra covered by prevertebral muscles and fascia
  • The roof and the posterior wall merge gradually with one another.

Floor
  • It is formed by the soft palate anteriorly but is deficient posteriorly.
  • The nasopharynx connects to the oropharynx (nasopharyngeal isthmus).

Anterior wall
  • Formed by posterior nasal apertures or choanae.
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates and meatuses are seen.

Lateral wall

  • Eustachian tube
  • Torus tubarius: A cushion-like elevation that borders the Eustachian tube from above and behind. (Option B)
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller: A recess above and behind the torus tubarius (the most common site for carcinoma origin).
  • Salpingopharyngeal fold: A ridge extends from the lower end of the torus tubarius to the lateral pharyngeal wall.

 

 

Pyriform fossa (Option A) or pyriform sinus (smuggler’s pouch) are the two depressions on the lateral sides of the aryepiglottic folds.

  • It is a site where foreign bodies can lodge and form the lateral channel for food.

 

Post cricoid region (Option D) is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and lower borders of the cricoid lamina.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty urinating and a history of profuse, creamy urethral discharge. He reports a prior untreated sexually transmitted infection. The urethrogram of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bulbar urethral stricture

 

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of difficulty urinating and a history of profuse, creamy urethral discharge strongly suggest a gonococcal infection, which can lead to inflammation and scarring in the bulbar urethra, resulting in a stricture. The urethrogram findings of narrowing specifically in the bulbar urethra support this diagnosis.

 

Parts of urethra

 

Bulbar urethral stricture

• Stricture seen in the bulbar urethra.

• Common in gonorrhoea.

• Presents with profuse, purulent or mucopurulent urethral discharge.

Stricture of distal penile urethra

• Urethrogram showing narrowing in the distal urethra.

 

Urethral carcinoma (Option A): Less likely due to the absence of risk factors and the typical presentation of malignancy, which would not match the history of an untreated STI.

 

Penile urethral stricture (Option C): Unlikely, as the urethrogram shows narrowing in the bulbar urethra, and penile strictures are less common in this context.

 

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) (Option D): Unlikely due to the patient's younger age and specific symptoms that align more with a urethral stricture rather than bladder outlet obstruction.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with continuous, painless vaginal bleeding for two months following 7 weeks of amenorrhea. She previously experienced heavy menstrual bleeding. Examination reveals a slightly enlarged uterus. A biopsy of the endometrium is shown below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metropathia hemorrhagica

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation and the biopsy revealing Swiss cheese endometrium suggest Metropathia hemorrhagica, which is a specialised form of anovulatory AUB, typically affecting women aged 40-45 and is characterised by continuous, painless vaginal bleeding, often following a period of amenorrhea.

  • The uterus may be slightly enlarged.
  • This condition can mimic abortion or ectopic pregnancy if preceded by amenorrhea but without pain.
  • Endometrial biopsy: Hyperproliferative endometrium - Cystic Glandular Hyperplasia (CGH), also known as the Swiss cheese endometrium

questions.text: A 65-year-old bedridden patient presents with a stage III pressure sore on the sacrum. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Application of hydrocolloid dressing

Explanation:

The management of pressure sores depends on the stage and severity of the wound.

For a stage III pressure sore, conservative management is typically the initial approach, with surgery reserved for more advanced cases or when conservative measures fail.

 

Conservative management includes:

1. Pressure relief: Repositioning the patient every 2-3 hours

2. Wound care: Cleaning and dressing the wound

3. Nutritional support: Ensuring adequate protein and calorie intake

4. Hydrocolloid dressings: These maintain a moist environment, promote autolytic debridement, and protect the wound

 

Surgical management is considered for:

1. Stage III and IV pressure sores that fail to heal with conservative measures

2. Exposed bone, tendon, or joint

3. Undermining, tunneling, or sinus tract formation

 

Surgical options include:

Immediate surgical debridement (Option A) is incorrect as it's too aggressive for initial management.

Negative pressure wound therapy (Option C) is typically used after debridement and is not the first-line treatment.

Flap reconstruction (Option D) is a surgical option reserved for more advanced cases or when conservative measures fail.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic constipation visits her primary care physician. She has been prescribed bisacodyl, a stimulant laxative, to help with her bowel movements. The physician advises her to take the medication before bedtime.

What is the BEST explanation for prescribing bisacodyl before bedtime?

choices.text: Bisacodyl takes 6-8 hours to reach the small bowel, thus needs to be given at bedtime for morning evacuation.
Bisacodyl has an associated sedative effect, thus needs to be prescribed before sleep.
The drug requires hydrolysis by endogenous esterases in the bowel for activation, which takes 6–10 hours on oral dose.
Bisacodyl mechanism of action involves the process of fermentation, which needs 6-8 hours to take place.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The drug requires hydrolysis by endogenous esterases in the bowel for activation, which occurs after 6–10 hours on oral dose.

Explanation:

Bisacodyl and other Stimulant laxatives require hydrolysis by endogenous esterases in the bowel for activation, so the Bisacodyl effects are seen after 6–10 hours of an oral dose.

However, Bisacodyl can also be given via rectal suppositories which act within 15-60 mins.

 

  • Bisacodyl acts by causing low grade inflammation in small and large bowel, stimulating intestinal motility and promoting accumulation of water and electrolytes. Hence, there’s no relation with the drug reaching the colon to act. (Option A ruled out)
  • Bisacodyl does not have any sedative or sleep inducing effect. (Option B ruled out)
  • Bisacodyl does not involve fermentation. It is activated by the process of hydrolysis by endogenous esterases. (Option D rule out)

questions.text: A 50 y/o man presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for the past two days. His serum lipase is elevated to five times the normal limit. An abdominal X-ray shows a dilated loop of small intestine near the pancreas. Which of the following is the most likely imaging sign observed on the X-ray in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient’s clinical presentation of severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and elevated lipase levels strongly suggests acute pancreatitis. Sentinel loop sign is a classic X-ray finding in acute pancreatitis, showing a dilated loop of the small intestine near the pancreas due to localized ileus caused by the inflammation.

Acute Pancreatitis

Clinical Diagnosis (Requires 2 of 3):

  1. Abdominal pain is strongly suggestive of acute pancreatitis.
  2. Serum amylase and/or lipase level at least 3 times the upper limit of normal.
  3. Imaging findings characteristic of acute pancreatitis.

 

X-ray Features

 

• Sentinel loop sign (Option C): 

◦ Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localized ileus.

◦ Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

Sentinel loop sign

• Colon cut-off sign: 

◦ Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.

◦ Significance: Suggests localized pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

Investigations of Choice:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT): Primary tool for assessing pancreatic necrosis, peripancreatic inflammation, fluid collections, and complications.
    • Most reliable for staging and detecting complications.
    • May underestimate necrosis if done in the first 24 hours.

Morphological Types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008):

  1. Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis:: Mild form with pancreatic oedema and swelling but no necrosis.
  2. Necrotising pancreatitis: Severe form involving pancreatic parenchymal necrosis, associated with higher morbidity and mortality.

Colon cut-off sign (Option A): Seen in acute pancreatitis, it indicates abrupt gas cut-off in the colon at the splenic flexure but doesn't explain small intestine dilation abdominal X-ray findings.

Pneumoperitoneum (Option B): Refers to free air under the diaphragm, often due to bowel perforation, and is not linked to acute pancreatitis.

Ground-glass opacity (Option D): Typically seen in lung imaging (e.g., pneumonia, ARDS), not related to pancreatitis or abdominal X-ray findings.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male with poorly controlled diabetes presents with a non-healing corneal ulcer in his right eye, despite two weeks of appropriate antibiotic therapy. The ulcer shows signs of impending perforation with severe thinning of the cornea. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Increase the frequency of antibiotic eye drops.
Apply a pressure bandage and recommend strict bed rest.
Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue.
Start topical steroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue

Explanation: 

For impending corneal perforation, necrotic tissue is first removed (mechanical debridement), then tissue adhesive (e.g., cyanoacrylate glue) is applied to seal the thin area and prevent rupture.

  • Mechanical debridement is necessary to remove necrotic material and promote healing in a non-healing ulcer.
  • Tissue adhesive glue is indicated to prevent perforation, especially when the perforation is less than 2mm.


Increasing the frequency of antibiotic eye drops (Option A): At this stage, just increasing frequency won’t be useful.

Applying a pressure bandage and bed rest (Option B): Pressure can worsen thinning and precipitate perforation.

Topical steroids (Option D) are contraindicated as they can worsen the infection.

questions.text: A 9-month-old pediatric patient presents with hypotonia, seizures, and delays in achieving developmental milestones. The child exhibits characteristic facial features, including a prominent forehead, sparse eyebrows, and distinct hair appearance. Laboratory results reveal decreased levels of copper and ceruloplasmin. What is the pattern of inheritance for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X-linked recessive.

 

Explanation:

  • The patient exhibits hypotonia, seizures, and developmental delays, along with characteristic facial features such as a prominent forehead, sparse eyebrows, and kinky hair.
  • Laboratory tests reveal low levels of copper and ceruloplasmin.
  • These clinical signs are consistent with Menkes disease, an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to impaired copper transport and significant neurological deficits, predominantly affecting males.

 

Menkes Kinky Hair Disease:

  • Menkes Kinky Hair Disease (also known as Menkes disease or Menkes syndrome) is a rare, X-linked recessive genetic disorder that affects copper levels in the body.
  • It is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, which is responsible for regulating the transport of copper in and out of cells.

 

Presentation:

Neurological Symptoms

Developmental delay, hypotonia (poor muscle tone), seizures

Hair Abnormalities

Brittle, sparse hair with a "kinky" or twisted appearance under a microscope.

Failure to Thrive

Poor feeding, vomiting, and lack of weight gain

Connective Tissue Issues

Weak bones (osteopenia), loose skin and joints due to lack of copper-dependent enzymes involved in collagen cross-linking

Characteristic Facial Features

Sagging cheeks, depressed nasal bridge

Blood Vessel Complications

Fragile arteries, leading to complications like subdural hemorrhage.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Genetic testing to identify mutations in the ATP7A gene (gold standard).
  • Plasma copper and ceruloplasmin levels are typically low.
  • Microscopic examination of hair shows the characteristic kinky or twisted appearance.

 

Management:

  • No cure for Menkes disease.
  • Early treatment with parenteral copper histidinate injections may improve outcomes if started early, though it is not fully curative.
  • Supportive care includes managing seizures, nutritional support, and physical therapy.

Autosomal recessive (Option A):
Incorrect because Menkes disease follows an X-linked, not autosomal, inheritance pattern.

Mitochondrial inheritance (Option B):
Incorrect because mitochondrial disorders are maternally inherited and do not match the copper metabolism defect seen here.

Autosomal dominant (Option D):
Incorrect because there is no dominant transmission pattern in Menkes; it is transmitted via the X chromosome.

questions.text: Functional imaging of choice for diagnosis of ZES is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Ga-68 DOTATE PET-CT

  • Ga-68 DOTATE PET-CT is the imaging modality of choice now for Neuroendocrine tumors and pheochromocytoma with sensitivity > 90%.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the difference between Cost-Benefit Analysis and Cost-Effective Analysis in health management?

choices.text: Cost-Benefit Analysis focuses on the qualitative aspects of health services, while Cost-Effective Analysis focuses on quantitative aspects.
Cost-benefit analysis compares monetary costs and benefits, whereas Cost-Effectiveness Analysis compares the costs to achieve a specific non-monetary outcome.
Cost-Benefit Analysis is used for planning and budgeting, while Cost-Effective Analysis is used for project scheduling.
Cost-Benefit Analysis evaluates staff performance, whereas Cost-Effective Analysis evaluates patient outcomes.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cost-benefit analysis compares monetary costs and benefits, whereas Cost-Effective Analysis compares the costs to achieve a specific non-monetary outcome.

 

Explanation:

  • Cost-Benefit Analysis
    • It is a management technique that compares a program's monetary costs with its monetary benefits, expressed in terms of economic gain.
    • It helps determine whether the benefits outweigh the costs in monetary terms.
    • The main drawback with this technique is that the benefits in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms.
  • Cost-Effective Analysis
    • Compares the costs of different interventions to achieve a specific health outcome that is not expressed in monetary terms.
    • It is used to determine the most efficient way to achieve a particular health goal, such as lives saved or cases treated, without converting the outcomes into monetary values.

questions.text: A 36 year old HIV positive patient presents with double vision, vomitting epsiodes with daily frontal headaches that dont respond to painkillers. Patient is not cooperative during physical examination due to headache. Fundus examination shows papilledema. Neuroimaging is performed. Which of the following is not correct about immediate management of this patient?

choices.text: Lumbar puncture for CSF CBNAAT for MTB

questions.solution:
Correct answer A:  Lumbar puncture for CSF CBNAAT for MTB

This immunocompromised patient is having ring enhanching lesions seen on MRI head. Lesions show “Target sign” with solid central nodule. First differential diagnosis in india TB meningitis. Due to raised ICP lumbar puncture cannot be performed in this patient as of now due to risk of brain herniation. Empirical ATT with steroids will be started along with measures to lower raised ICP. Double vision is seen this case due to 6th nerve palsy seen in raised ICP. 

Contraindications to Lumbar puncture

  1. Papilledema

  2. Focal neurologic deficit (esp. new onset)

  3. Midline shift or mass on CT/MRI

  4. Bleeding disorders / Anticoagulants

  5. Skin infection at site

  6. Uncontrolled seizures

  7. Signs of raised ICP with impending herniation

questions.text: During a food festival in a small town, 200 people attended a barbecue event. Within 48 hours, 60 attendees developed symptoms of food poisoning. Local health officials want to measure the extent of the outbreak among those who attended the event. What is the term used to describe the proportion of people who developed symptoms out of all the attendees?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Attack rate

Explanation:

The attack rate is the most appropriate measure in this scenario. It represents the proportion of exposed individuals who develop the disease during a specified time period. In this case, we want to measure the extent of food poisoning among those who attended the barbecue event.

To calculate the attack rate:

Number of new cases / Total number of people at risk × 100 = 60 / 200 × 100 = 30%

Secondary attack rate (Option B):

This is a measure of commuicability/transmisibility of a disease. It's typically used for person-to-person transmitted diseases, not for a common source outbreak like food poisoning at an event.

Case fatality rate (Option C) :

This is a measure of severity/virulence of a disease. It is the proportion of individuals who die from a specific disease among those diagnosed with it. It is not applicable here, as we are not provided with death data. We are focused on the extent of the outbreak, not its severity.

Prevalence rate (Option D): This measures the proportion of people with a particular condition at a specific time. It's unsuitable for this acute outbreak scenario, as we're interested in new cases that developed after a specific exposure, not the total number of existing cases in the population.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with blistering and severe itching on her arms after applying the juice from a black seed, as shown in the image. She also experiences nausea and abdominal pain. Which of the following statements is not true?

choices.text: Often used in malingering for artificial bruises.
Commonly used for Arrow and Cattle poisoning.
Large oral doses can be potentially fatal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Commonly used for arrow and cattle poisoning.

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario of blistering and severe itching on her arms after applying the juice from the seed, as shown in the image, suggests Semecarpus Anacardium.
  • It is used to create artificial bruises (malingering) but is not commonly used for Arrow and cattle poisoning.
  • Abrus precatorius is used as an arrow poison and ideal cattle poison.

 

Semecarpus Anacardium:

  • Commonly known as the marking nut or bhilawanol (washermen use its juice to inscribe identification numbers on clothes).
  • Seeds:
    • Black, cone/heart-shaped with a rough projection at the base.
    • They have a thick pericarp that contains an acrid, brownish, oily juice that turns black upon exposure to air.

  • Active principles: Semecarpol and Bhilawanol (Option B)
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Skin exposure: Applying the juice can cause irritation, itching, and painful blisters filled with acrid serum.
      • Eczematous eruptions resembling bruises may also occur, potentially evolving into ulcers with sloughing.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever and painful micturition, often accompanied by brown-colored urine.
    • Oral ingestion: A large dose can cause blisters in the mouth and throat, severe gastrointestinal irritation, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, cyanosis, loss of reflexes, delirium, coma, and potentially death. (Option D)
    • Fatal dose: Approximately 5–10 g (5–8 seeds).
    • Fatal period: 12–24 hours.
  • Treatment:
    • Rinse the affected skin with soap and water.
    • Apply bland liniments.
    • Provide demulcent drinks and symptomatic treatment.
  • Medico-legal Aspects:
    • Criminal Use: The juice can be introduced vaginally as a form of punishment for infidelity or applied to the cervical os for illegal abortions.
    • Malingering: The juice can simulate conjunctivitis or falsely substantiate assault claims, as the lesions resemble bruises (Option A)

questions.text: A 25-year-old asymptomatic patient undergoes a routine lumbar spine X-ray for an unrelated complaint. The radiologist notices an incidental finding on the image. Which of the following findings would be inconsistent with spina bifida occulta?

choices.text: Tuft of hair or dimple over the affected area
Often asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging
Failure of vertebral arches to fuse with intact spinal cord and meninges
Visible sac with cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Visible sac with cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect.

 

Explanation:

  • Spina bifida occulta is characterised by:
    • Failure of vertebral arches to fuse with the spinal cord and meninges remaining within the spinal canal (Option C).
    • It is often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging (Option B).
    • External signs like a tuft of hair or dimple over the affected area (Option A).
  • In contrast, a visible sac containing cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect (Option D) indicates spina bifida aperta, specifically myelomeningocele, not spina bifida occulta.

questions.text: A 60 y/o male presents with fever, cough, and foul-smelling sputum. A chest X-ray reveals a localized opacity in the apical lower lobe. Sputum culture shows the presence of anaerobic bacteria. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Bronchial obstruction due to lung cancer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)Aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions

Explanation:

The X-ray shows a lung abscess. Aspiration is the most common cause of lung abscesses, particularly in the apical lower lobe, and is frequently associated with anaerobic bacteria from the oral cavity.

 

Lung Abscess Localized suppuration in the lung is characterized by tissue necrosis

 

Aetiology:

  • Infectious: Pneumonia due to Streptococcus, Pneumococcus, Haemophilus, Staphylococcus, anaerobic bacteria, etc.
  • Chronic upper respiratory infections (e.g., sinusitis, tonsillitis, dental infections).
  • Mechanical: Bronchial obstruction due to tumours or foreign bodies.
  • Other Causes: Septicaemia and aspiration, commonly lead to lung abscess in the apical lower lobe.

Sites of Infection:

  • Apical Lower Lobe: Most frequently involved in aspiration-related lung abscesses.
  • Posterior Segments: Can be affected due to gravity when aspiration occurs.
  • Upper Lobes: May be involved in cases of tuberculosis or certain types of pneumonia.

 

Routes of Infection:

  • Aspiration: Inhalation of oropharyngeal or gastrointestinal secretions, often leading to anaerobic infections from the oral cavity.
  • Hematogenous Spread: From e.g., endocarditis or septicemia
  • Direct Extension: Localized infections in adjacent structures (e.g., pneumonia, empyema) can extend into lung tissue.

 

 

Hematogenous spread from endocarditis (Option B): While it can cause lung abscesses, it is less common than aspiration in the context of anaerobic infections and would typically present with multiple abscesses rather than a localized opacity.

Direct extension from pneumonia (Option C) can cause lung abscesses, but in this case, the specific presence of anaerobic bacteria and the apical location suggest aspiration as the more likely cause.

Bronchial obstruction due to lung cancer (Option D) is a possible cause of infection and abscess formation, but the presence of anaerobic bacteria and the patient's age make aspiration a more plausible cause, especially in the context of a localized opacity in the lung.

questions.text: A public health officer is investigating an outbreak of a viral illness in a tropical region. The affected individuals present with symptoms such as fever, maculopapular skin rash, conjunctivitis, and joint pain. The officer needs to identify the primary vector responsible for the transmission of the virus to implement effective control measures. Which vector is primarily responsible for transmitting the virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aedes aegypti mosquito

Explanation:

Zika virus disease should be considered in patients with acute onset of fever, maculopapular rash, and arthralgia, particularly if they have travelled to areas with ongoing transmission in the two weeks before symptom onset. Zika virus is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito.

Zika virus disease:

  • Agent: Zika virus is a Flavivirus transmitted via mosquito bite; hence, it is called an arbovirus.
  • Mode of Transmission:
    • Transmitted by the bite of an infected Aedes aegypti mosquito, which tends to bite during the morning and late afternoon.
    • It is also increasingly recognized that an infected pregnant woman can pass the virus to her baby during pregnancy or near the time of birth.
  • Clinical Symptoms: Fever, skin rash, conjunctivitis, joint pain, headache. Symptoms are usually mild and last 2-7 days. Pregnant women are at increased risk for developing both fetal and maternal complications.
  • Prevention: Prevention and control depend on reducing mosquitoes by removing and modifying breeding sites.

Anopheles mosquito (Option A): Primarily known for transmitting malaria.

Culex mosquito (Option B): Primarily known for transmitting West Nile virus and other arboviruses.

Ixodes tick (Option D): Known for transmitting Lyme disease and other tick-borne illnesses unrelated to mosquito-borne diseases.

questions.text: A 28 year old pregnant woman at 37 weeks gestation presents to the obstetric clinic for a routine check-up. On abdominal examination, the fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, and the pelvic grip is empty. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a normal baseline with reassuring variability. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) External cephalic version

Explanation:

In the given scenario, the pregnant woman presents at 37 weeks, the fetal head is not engaged, and the fetal status is stable, which is in a transverse lie. An external cephalic version could be the appropriate next step in management to attempt to reposition the fetus for a potential vaginal delivery.

  • M/c cause of transverse lie - Prematurity
  • It has high risk of cord prolapse
  • Antenatal Management: If there are no contraindications, attempt an external cephalic version (ECV) beyond 35 weeks for the transverse lie.
  • If Version Fails or is Contraindicated: Elective cesarean section (Option D) is the preferred delivery method.
  • Management in Labor: In early labor, try an external cephalic version (ECV) if appropriate or opt for cesarean section if ECV is unsuccessful. In late labor, ECV is usually impractical due to ruptured membranes, so the cesarean section is preferred in such cases.
  • Internal Version Considerations: Only for specific cases like managing the second twin.

Immediate induction of labour (Option A): The fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, which means the baby is not in a favourable position for a safe vaginal delivery. Attempting induction could increase the risk of complications such as cord prolapse or obstruction.

Vaginal delivery with careful monitoring (Option C): Vaginal delivery is contraindicated in transverse lie due to the risk of cord prolapse or obstructed labour.

questions.text: Identify the procedure done to assess infertility, which is given below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hysterosalpingography

 

Explanation:

The above image shows hysterosalpingography with normal uterine filling and bilateral patent tubes.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG):

  • Visualising the uterine cavity & fallopian tubes by retrograde injection of radiocontrast dye to identify filling defects & blocks.
  • Timing of HSG: 
    • postmenstrual period
    • follicular phase 
    • usually D6-D11 of mesntrual cycle to avoid it during pregnancy and ensure endomtrium is thin for better visualisation

Preparation
  • NSAID 30 minutes before to prevent tubal spasm.
  • Paracervical block in patients with cervical stenosis.

4 phases of radiographic images taken
  • Pre-contrast preliminary.
  • During contrast filling.
  • Contrast spillage into the peritoneum.
  • During deflation and withdrawal.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

Saline infusion sonography (Option A) or sonosalpingography uses ultrasound to visualise the uterus & tubes while simultaneously injecting saline (not radiocontrast dye) retrograde into the uterus.

Sonoelastography (Option C) is used to assess soft tissue stiffness.

Contrast-enhanced sonography (Option D) combines intravenous contrast injection & ultrasonographic examination.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the “Beck’s cognitive triad”?

choices.text: Perception of the environment as hostile
Expectations of suffering and failure in the future

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Introjection of lost significant object

Explanation:

The introjection of lost objects is a part of the psychodynamic theory of depression, while the cognitive triad is a component of the cognitive theory, involving self-perception, environment, and the future.

Psychosocial Theories of Depression

Life Events and Environmental Stress

  • Stressful life events often precede the first episode of mood disorders.
  • Initial stress may lead to long-lasting biological changes, increasing the risk for future episodes even without further stressors.

 

Psychodynamic Theories

  • Early disturbances in the infant-mother relationship predispose to depression.
  • Depression is linked to real or imagined loss of significant objects.
  • Introjection of lost objects serves as a defense mechanism.
  • Feelings of love and hate toward the lost object result in self-directed anger.

 

Cognitive Theory

  • Depression arises from cognitive distortions known as depressogenic schemata.
  • Cognitive Triad (by Aaron Beck):
    • Worthlessness: Negative self-perception. (Option A)
    • Helplessness: Perception of the environment as hostile and demanding. (Option B)
    • Hopelessness: Expectation of suffering and failure in the future. (Option C)
  • Therapy focuses on modifying these cognitive distortions.

 

Learned Helplessness

  • Developed from studies showing that exposure to uncontrollable stressors (e.g., electric shocks in dogs) leads to passive behavior.
  • Humans may internalize helplessness and lose self-esteem after adverse events.
  • Improvement in depression involves learning a sense of control and mastery over one’s environment.

 

Evolutionary Theory

  • Depression is viewed as an adaptive response to perceived environmental threats.
  • Withdrawal from social situations and decreased activity may serve as protective mechanisms.

questions.text: You have been posted in a rural PHC where you just received a new batch of vaccines for the upcoming vaccination drive. You need to educate your team on the conditions that have to be fulfilled in order to reuse opened vaccine vials during the drive. Which of the following would you not suggest regarding the same?

choices.text: The Vaccine Vial monitor has not reached the discard point.
An aseptic technique must be used to withdraw all doses.
Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+6° C to +10° C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point.
The expiry date should not have passed.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+6° C to +10° C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point
 

Explanation:

  • Here, we need to explain the conditions for fulfilling the Open Vial Policy; this statement is not true.
  • Under Open Vial Policy, Vaccines are stored at an appropriate temperature range of (+2°C to +8°C) during transportation & storage at cold chain points.
  • Other conditions to be fulfilled under open vial policy include:
  • The Vaccine Vial monitor has not reached the discard point (Option A): Monitoring the Vaccine vial Monitor (VVM) is an essential aspect of vaccine management followed under the Open Vial Policy
  • An aseptic technique must be used to withdraw all doses (Option B): Maintaining sterility during the withdrawal of the vaccine is important to prevent contamination, a requirement under the Open vial policy.
  • The expiry date has not passed (Option D): Expired vaccines can lose their efficacy and can even become harmful.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with signs of early virilization and ambiguous genitalia. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ACTH and 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
21β-hydroxylase deficiency leads to reduced cortisol and aldosterone production, causing elevated ACTH and increased production of androgens, resulting in virilization and ambiguous genitalia.

 

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

  • Definition: Group of genetic disorders affecting adrenal glands, causing enzyme deficiencies in steroid biosynthesis.
  • Effects: Disruption in cortisol and aldosterone production, leading to various symptoms.
  • Prevalence: Most common deficiency is 21β-hydroxylase deficiency (90%+ cases).

21β-Hydroxylase Deficiency

  • Impact: Reduced cortisol and aldosterone production.
  • Consequence: Increased ACTH secretion. (Option B)
