  • Result: Increased precursor steroids converted to androgens → Virilization.

Other Enzyme Deficiencies in CAH

Enzyme Deficiency

Description

Symptoms/Consequences

Cholesterol desmolase deficiency

Fatal in utero, prevents placental progesterone synthesis.

Death before birth.

Steroidogenic acute regulatory (StAR) protein deficiency

Known as congenital lipoid adrenal hyperplasia. Prevents cholesterol movement into mitochondria.

Low steroid production, female genitalia regardless of genetic sex.

3β-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency

Increases DHEA secretion (weak androgen).

Masculinization in females, hypospadias in males. (Option C)

17α-Hydroxylase deficiency

Caused by mutated CYP17 gene. Prevents sex hormone production.

Female external genitalia, hypertension, hypokalemia due to high 11-deoxycorticosterone. (Option D- not early virilization)

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

Increased 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone secretion.

Virilization, hypertension due to salt and water retention. (Option A)

Treatment

  • Glucocorticoid treatment: Recommended for all virilizing forms of CAH.
    • Purpose: Addresses glucocorticoid deficit.
    • Effect: Inhibits ACTH secretion, reducing androgen and steroid production.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male recipient of a kidney transplant presents with a sudden increase in serum creatinine levels three days post-transplant. Laboratory tests reveal the presence of donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) and linear C4d staining in peritubular capillaries on biopsy. Which of the following statements best describes the condition?

choices.text: It is primarily mediated by T-cell activation.
It is characterized by the presence of pre-existing antibodies against donor antigens.
It is commonly associated with chronic rejection mechanisms.
It usually resolves spontaneously without intervention.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is characterized by the presence of pre-existing antibodies against donor antigens.

Explanation:

Acute Humoral Rejection (AHR) is diagnosed through the presence of donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) in the serum, along with histological evidence of glomerulitis or peritubular capillaritis observed in biopsy samples. Additionally, linear C4d staining in peritubular capillaries serves as a critical marker for confirming the diagnosis.

 

Acute Humoral Rejection (AHR):

  • Definition
    • Significant complication in organ transplantation, particularly in kidney transplants.
    • Characterized by donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) targeting the vascular endothelium, leading to tissue injury and graft dysfunction.

Mechanisms of AHR:

  • Pathophysiology
    • Binding of DSAs to donor HLA molecules activates the complement system, resulting in:
      • Capillary Injury: Damage to peritubular capillaries is a hallmark of AHR.
      • C4d Deposition: A key diagnostic marker; approximately 30% of acute rejection biopsies show widespread C4d staining.
      • Histological Features: May include neutrophilic infiltration, glomerulitis, and fibrinoid necrosis in severe cases.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnostic Criteria
    • Combination of clinical presentation, serological testing, and histopathological findings:
      • Histologic Evidence: Glomerulitis or peritubular capillaritis.
      • Antibody Interaction: Linear C4d staining indicates recent antibody interaction with vascular endothelium.
      • Detection of DSAs: Presence of DSAs in serum confirms diagnosis.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Symptoms
    • Patients may experience:
      • Acute Elevation in Creatinine: Noted within days to weeks post-transplant.
      • Fever and Malaise: General systemic inflammation signs.
      • Graft Tenderness: Possible tenderness over the transplant site.

Treatment:

  • Management Approaches
    • Aim to reduce antibody-mediated injury:
      • Plasmapheresis: Removes circulating antibodies.
      • Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): Modulates immune responses.
      • Rituximab: Targets CD20 on B cells to reduce antibody production.
      • Eculizumab: A complement inhibitor effective in severe AHR cases.

It is primarily mediated by T-cell activation (Option A) is incorrect because AHR is primarily mediated by antibody interactions, not T-cell responses.

 

It is commonly associated with chronic rejection mechanisms (Option C) is incorrect since AHR is an acute process, distinct from chronic rejection.

 

It usually resolves spontaneously without intervention (Option D) is incorrect; AHR typically requires immunosuppressive treatment for resolution.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about suicide inhibition is incorrect?

choices.text: The inhibitor covalently binds to the enzyme after being converted to a reactive intermediate.
Suicide inhibition is a reversible form of enzyme inhibition.
Suicide inhibitors resemble the enzyme's natural substrate.
Allopurinol acts as a suicide inhibitor of xanthine oxidase to manage gout.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Suicide inhibition is a reversible form of enzyme inhibition.

Explanation:

Suicide inhibition, is a special type of irreversible enzyme inhibition.

 

Process of Suicide Inhibition:

 

Examples of Suicide Inhibition:

 

Enzyme

Inhibitor

Mechanism

Clinical Application

Ornithine Decarboxylase (ODC)

Difluoromethylornithine (DFMO)

DFMO binds to ODC, is converted to a reactive form, and irreversibly inactivates the enzyme.

Treats trypanosomiasis by stopping polyamine synthesis in Trypanosoma parasites.

Xanthine Oxidase (Option D)

Allopurinol

Allopurinol is oxidized to alloxanthine, which forms an irreversible complex with xanthine oxidase.

Manages gout by reducing uric acid levels.

Cyclo-oxygenase (COX)

Aspirin

Aspirin acetylates a serine residue in COX, irreversibly inhibiting the enzyme.

Reduces inflammation and pain, and prevents heart attacks and strokes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. She reports a history of irregular menstrual cycles. She has no history of pelvic inflammatory disease and USG shows no uterine abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Ovulatory dysfunction

Explanation:

Ovulatory Dysfunction (PCOS) is the most common cause of female infertility in this patient with a history of irregular menstrual cycles and obesity.

Causes of Female Infertility:

1. Ovarian
  • Anovulation: PCOD (most common), hyperprolactinemia.
  • Kallman syndrome
  • Premature ovarian failure: Radiation, chemotherapy, galactosemia

2. Tubal (Blockage)
  • Recurrent PID, TB pelvis, Salpingitis
  • Endometriosis
  • Tubectomy
  • Kartagener syndrome

3. Uterine
  • Fibroid (M/C: Submucosal): Endometrial polyp
  • Ashermann syndrome
  • Chronic endometritis (Clamydia)
  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES): T shape uterus
  • Septate uterus

4. Cervical
  • Cervicitis
  • Cervical stenosis
  • Antisperm antibodies

5. Vaginal
  • Atresia, transverse vaginal septum

6. Miscellaneous
  • Alcohol (Option D), Smoking

  • Fibroid (Option C): No uterine abnormalities detected on ultrasound.

  • Premature ovarian failure (Option A): History of estrogen deficiency symptoms and amenorrhea; elevated FSH levels suggest Primary Ovarian Failure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old presents with right-sided hearing loss, vertigo, and horizontal nystagmus with fast phase to the right. The nystagmus worsens in darkness and improves with fixation. There is no nausea or vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Central vestibular nystagmus due to a cerebellar lesion
Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis
Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis
Central vestibular nystagmus due to Arnold-Chiari malformation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis

 

Explanation:

The patient’s horizontal nystagmus, with a fast phase to the right, worsens in darkness and improves with fixation, which suggests peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis.

Feature

Peripheral Nystagmus

Central Nystagmus

Location of lesion

Labyrinth or vestibulocochlear (VIII) nerve

Central neural pathways (vestibular nuclei, brainstem, cerebellum)

Latency

2-20 seconds

No latency

Duration

Less than 1 minute

More than 1 minute

Type of Nystagmus

Spontaneous nystagmus

Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus

Direction of Nystagmus

Fixed, towards the undermost ear

Change with direction of gaze

Fatigability

Fatigable

Non-fatigable

Response to Visual Fixation

Suppressed by Optic fixation; Worsens in darkness or with Frenzel glasses (+20 dioptre glasses), both abolishing optic fixation

Cannot be suppressed

Accompanying Symptoms
  • Severe vertigo
  • Loss of hearing in one ear
  • Ringing in one or both ears
  • Difficulty focusing vision
  • Loss of balance

None or slight:

  • Impairment in speech
  • Weakness or numbness
  • Gait disturbance
  • Impairment in vision

 

In Purulent Labyrinthitis (Option C), Vertigo is due to the inner ear bacterial infection, with total loss of cochlear and vestibular functions. Nystagmus would be on the opposite side, and there would be severe nausea and vomiting.

 

Central Vestibular Nystagmus (Option A and D) does not improve with optic fixation and has changing directions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a rapidly growing, painless mass in the upper arm. Imaging shows that the mass is located deep in the fascia, and biopsy results indicate poorly differentiated pleomorphic cells with high mitotic activity. What is the most important prognostic factor for this patient's soft tissue sarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Histological Grade

 

Explanation:

  • The histological grade is the most crucial prognostic factor in soft tissue sarcomas, as it directly reflects the tumour's biological behaviour, aggressiveness, and potential response to therapy.

 

Prognostic factors for soft tissue sarcoma

 

Prognostic Factor

Importance

Histological Grade

Comprehensive assessment of tumour aggressiveness;

Depth of Tumor

Tumours deep into the fascia are more likely to be malignant and have a poorer prognosis. (Option C)

Size of Tumor

Larger tumours (>5 cm) are more likely to be malignant and associated with a worse prognosis. (Option A)

Presence of Necrosis

Indicates high-grade tumours with aggressive behaviour. (Option B)

Vascular Invasion

Associated with a higher risk of metastasis and worse prognosis

Perineural Invasion

Suggests aggressive behaviour and the potential for local spread

Positive Resection Margins

Higher risk of recurrence if cancer cells remain at the edges of surgical resection

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with abdominal pain, irritability, and developmental delays. On examination, the child shows a wrist drop. Which of the following chelating agents is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Succimer (meso-DMSA)

 

Explanation:

  • Succimer (meso-DMSA) is the preferred oral chelating agent for lead poisoning in children due to its effectiveness and safety profile.

Overview of Chelating Agents

  • Mechanism:
    • Form stable complexes with metal ions to block interactions with biological systems.
    • Promote elimination of metals via urine or feces.

Common Chelating Agents

Chelating Agent

Indication

Administration Route

Dimercaprol (BAL) (Option A ruled out)

Arsenic and mercury poisoning

Intramuscular (IM)

Succimer (meso-DMSA) (Option B)

Lead poisoning (especially in children)

Oral

Unithiol (DMPS)

Mercury and lead toxicity

Oral or Intravenous (IV)

D-penicillamine (Option C ruled out)

Copper and lead poisoning

Oral (but with side effects)

CaNa₂EDTA (Option D ruled out)

Lead poisoning

IV

Deferoxamine (DFO)

Iron overload (e.g., in thalassemia)

IV or IM

Prussian Blue

Thallium and cesium poisoning

Oral

 

Factors Affecting Chelation Efficacy

  • Metal Type: Different metals require specific chelators due to varying affinities.
  • Age: Age impacts both toxicity levels and chelation effectiveness, necessitating tailored treatments.
  • Timing: Early use of chelators improves patient outcomes.

questions.text: Grade IV nerve injury in Sunderland classification corresponds to which type of nerve injury in Seddon’s classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Axonotmesis

 

Explanation:

 

Sunderland classification Seddon classification Injury
Grade I Neurapraxia Focal segmental demyelination
Grade II Axonotmesis Damaged axon with intact endoneurium
Grade III Axonotmesis Damaged axon and endoneurium with intact perineurium

Grade IV

Axonotmesis

(Option A)

Damaged axon, endoneurium, and perineurium with intact epineurium

Grade V

Neurotmesis

(Option B ruled out)

Complete nerve transection (disruption of myelin sheath, axon, endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium)

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse is admitted to the hospital due to severe alcohol withdrawal symptoms. After stabilisation, he expresses his desire to overcome his alcohol dependence and seeks assistance from the healthcare team. Which of the following is not an anti-craving drug commonly used in the management of alcohol dependence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Disulfiram

 

Explanation:

  • Disulfiram is FDA-approved for alcohol dependence but is not an anti-craving drug, as it works by causing adverse reactions when alcohol is consumed.
 

Drug Name

Mechanism of Action

Notes

FDA-
approved anti-craving drugs

Naltrexone (Option A)

Blocks opioid receptors

Reduces cravings and desire to drink

Acamprosate (Option B)

Modulates glutamate & GABA systems

Reduces cravings and helps maintain abstinence

Not FDA-
approved (off-label use)

Baclofen

GABA agonist

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Gabapentin

& Topiramate (Option D)

Modulates GABA & glutamate systems

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with symptoms of a respiratory infection. A sputum sample is taken and cultured. The isolated organism shows pink, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. Biochemical tests are performed, and the organism is found to be urease-positive, indole-negative, and citrate-positive. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Klebsiella pneumoniae

Explanation:
The following tests are used to identify Klebsiella pneumoniae

  • MacConkey Agar: Pink, mucoid colonies indicate lactose fermentation and a capsule-producing bacterium, both characteristic of Klebsiella pneumoniae.
  • Urease-positive: Klebsiella pneumoniae produces urease, which breaks down urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide.
  • Indole-negative: Klebsiella pneumoniae does not produce indole from tryptophan, differentiating it from Escherichia coli, which is indole-positive.
  • Citrate-positive: Klebsiella pneumoniae can utilize citrate as its sole carbon source.

Laboratory diagnosis of Klebsiella pneumoniae:

  • Gram staining: It is short, plump, straight capsulated gram-negative rods
  • Culture: On MacConkey agar, it produces large dome-shaped mucoid (due to capsule) sticky, pink color, lactose fermenting colonies.
  • Identification: Identification of K. pneumoniae from colonies is made either by automated identification systems such as MALDI-TOF or VITEK; or by conventional biochemical tests as described below
    • It is catalase positive and oxidase negative
    • ICUT tests: Indole test (negative), citrate test (positive), urease test (positive) and TSI (triple sugar iron agar) test shows acid/acid, gas present, H2S absent.

Escherichia coli (Option A): Although it can appear pink on MacConkey agar due to lactose fermentation, E. coli is indole-positive and urease-negative, ruling it out.

 

Proteus mirabilis (Option C): Proteus species are typically non-lactose fermenting and would not appear pink on MacConkey agar. They also do not appear mucoid.

Enterobacter cloacae (Option D): While this organism is citrate-positive and a lactose fermenter, it generally lacks the mucoid, highly capsulated appearance of Klebsiella pneumoniae colonies and is urease-negative.

questions.text:
An elderly male diabetic patient came with loss of vision in the left eye associated with pain in the left eye. On examination, the left eye appears red, and visual acuity- Perception of light+ and IOP is raised in the same eye. The patient gives history of blurring and diminution of vision for the past 1 year. The slit lamp examination is given below.


 

Choose the correct diagnosis and appropriate pathophysiology for this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Phacolytic glaucoma - Secondary open-angle glaucoma

 

Explanation:

  • Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glaucoma and the slit lamp image of a milky white cortex with a sunken nucleus corresponds to the Morgagnian type of hyper mature cataract - leading to secondary open-angle glaucoma called Phacolytic glaucoma. (Option C and D)

 

Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma

Phacolytic Glaucoma

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork.

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

 

Phacomorphic glaucoma is seen in the intumescent stage of cataract - a type of secondary closed-angle glaucoma. (Option A and B)

questions.text: The clinician performed the following test as shown. Which muscle is being tested here?

choices.text: Lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Abductor pollicis brevis

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical test done is the Pen test which tests the Abductor pollicis brevis - supplied by Median nerve.
  • Adductor pollicis (Option A): Supplied by ulnar nerve.
    • Book test/Froment sign is done.
  • Flexor carpi radialis (Option B): Supplied by median nerve.
  • Lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus (Option D): Supplied by median nerve.
    • Along with Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus does flexion of fingers.
    • Injury to the median nerve will cause a Pointing index sign on Oschner clasp/Benediction test.

Clinical tests for Median nerve:

Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C)
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis
  • Action: Opposition of thumb
  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

 

Treatment of median nerve palsy:

  • Conservative management mainly.
  • If not recovered, nerve repair is done by
    • High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months
    • Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Uric Acid Stones

 

Explanation:

Radiopaque stones:

  • Calcium Oxalate Stones (Option A ruled out)
  • Calcium Phosphate Stones
  • Struvite Stones
  • Cystine stones are also mildly radiopaque (Option C ruled out)

 

Radiolucent stones include:

  • Uric acid stones (most common) (Option B)
  • Xanthine stones (rarely seen, mainly in patients with xanthinuria) (Option D ruled out)

Stone Type

Features

Image

Calcium Oxalate
  • The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones) ; Radiopaque
  • Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia
  • Types: monohydrate (dumbbell shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped)

 


 

Calcium Phosphate
  • Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare
  • Types include apatite and brushite stones
  • Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis

Struvite
  • Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate)
  • Radiopaque
  • Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter)

Cystine
  • Radiopaque, Constitute approximately 1% of stones
  • Result from cystinuria, an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine
  • Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds

Uric Acid
  • Radiolucent
  • Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders
  • Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine

questions.text: A 60 y/o male presents with severe pain, swelling, and a foul-smelling discharge from a wound on his leg sustained three days ago.O/E the affected area has signs of necrosis, raising suspicion of gas gangrene. Which of the following toxins is responsible for toxaemia in gas gangrene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alpha toxin

Explanation:

  • The alpha toxin released by C.perferingens is lethal, dermonecrotic, and hemolytic and is hence responsible for toxaemia in gas gangrene.

 

Clostridium forms 12 different toxins:

  • 4 major toxins:
    1. Alpha: It is the most important toxin, responsible for toxemia in gas gangrene, with dermonecrotic and hemolytic effects. 
    2. Beta: Lethal and necrotising properties
    3. Epsilon: Lethal and necrotising properties
    4. Iota: Lethal and necrotising properties
  • 8 minor toxins:
    1. ​​​​​​​Gamma: Minor lethal action
    2. Eta: Minor lethal action
    3. Delta: It has a lethal effect and causes hemolysis of red blood cells in even-toed ungulates (sheep, goats, pigs, cattle).
    4. Theta: Oxygen-labile hemolysin, antigenically related to streptolysin O and acts as a lethal and broadly cytolytic toxin.
    5. Kappa: Collagenase properties
    6. Lamba: Proteinase and gelatinase properties
    7. Mu: Hyaluronidase properties
    8. Nu: Deoxyribonuclease properties

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe abdominal pain and per-vaginal bleeding. The uterus is tender, the pulse rate is 110 bpm, and BP is 90/60 mm Hg. Fetal heart sounds are absent. What grade of abruptio placentae is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade 3

 

Explanation:

The patient has per-vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain (uterine tenderness), haemodynamic instability (increased pulse rate and hypotension), and absent fetal heart sounds. It indicates grade 3 abruptio placentae.

 

Abruptio placentae- A form of antepartum haemorrhage where bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

 

Page Classification of abruptio placentae:

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

questions.text: A researcher is interested in examining the prevalence of hypertension among adults in a city and wants to identify any associated risk factors such as age, diet, and physical activity at a single time. The researcher collects data from a large sample of adults in the city. Which type of study design is the researcher using in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cross-sectional study

 

Explanation:

  • A cross-sectional study is used to determine the prevalence of a disease in a population at a specific time.
  • It is also known as a snapshot of the total population.
  • Here it is cross-sectional study because it calculates prevalence of a disease and relies on primary data, i.e., researcher collects the data himself.
  • To assess the incidence, a Cohort study (Option A) starts by determining whether risk factors are present.
  • Case-control study (Option C) determines whether an exposure is associated with an outcome. It starts with diseased and non-diseased.
  • An Ecological study (Option D) compares exposure and disease frequency in a series of populations. The unit of study is population. Ecological study uses secondary data.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Warthin's tumour and its diagnostic features is correct?

choices.text: It is best identified on imaging by its hypoechoic appearance and confirmed with FNAC.
A Tc99 pertechnetate scan showing a "hotspot" is indicative of Warthin's tumour.
Warthin's tumour generally exhibits low uptake on Tc99 pertechnetate scans

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A Tc99 pertechnetate scan showing a "hotspot" is indicative of Warthin's tumour.

Explanation:

Warthin's tumour shows increased uptake on Tc99 pertechnetate scans because of its high mitochondrial content. Histopathological features include papillary structures, cystic spaces, oncocytic epithelial cells, and lymphoid stroma.

Tc99 Pertechnetate Scan:

  • Purpose: Assesses salivary gland function and detects abnormal areas.
  • Hot Spot: Increased uptake of the radioactive tracer (Option D), indicating high mitochondrial content typical of Warthin's tumour.

Histopathology (HPE) (Option C):

  • Papillary Structures: Finger-like projections extending into cystic spaces.
  • Cystic Spaces: Fluid-filled cavities within the tumor.
  • Oncocytic Epithelial Cells: Two layers of cells with abundant mitochondria lining the papillary and cystic areas.
  • Lymphoid Stroma: Supporting tissue with lymphocytes and germinal centres, resembling lymph node tissue.

It is best identified on imaging by its hypoechoic appearance and confirmed with FNAC (Option A): While FNAC is used for diagnosis, Warthin's tumour typically shows a "hot spot" on Tc99 pertechnetate scans due to high mitochondrial content, not just hypoechoic appearance. FNAC might not always reveal the distinct features of Warthin's tumour.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is being treated with theophylline. He is prescribed erythromycin for a respiratory tract infection. Which of the following outcomes is most likely due to the interaction between these two drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Increased risk of theophylline toxicity

 

Explanation:

  • Erythromycin is an inhibitor of the cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP1A2, which metabolises theophylline.
  • Inhibition of this enzyme leads to higher plasma levels of theophylline, increasing the risk of toxicity.

Theophylline toxicity:

  • It has a narrow margin of safety, and dose-dependent toxicity starts from the upper half of the therapeutic concentration range.
  • The image below shows the effects of theophylline toxicity.

 

Enzyme inhibitors: (leads to drug toxicity)

Drugs (Mnemonic- COKE in Gallon Contain Artificial Preservatives):

Cimetidine.

Grapefruit juice (Furano coumarins).

Omeprazole.

Clarithromycin & Ciprofloxacin.

Ketoconazole.

Acute alcoholism.

Erythromycin.

Protease inhibitor (Ritonavir).

Isoniazid (inhibits all CYP enzymes except CYP2E1).

Valproate.

questions.text: The diagram given below depicts a mechanism of separation of the placenta. What is this mechanism called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schultz

Explanation:

 

 

                                                                                    

Feature

Central Separation (Schultze)

Marginal Separation (Mathews-Duncan)

Initiation

Starts at the center of the placenta

It starts at the margin of the placenta

Relation with uterine contractions

Detachment occurs as uterine contractions increase

Detachment occurs as uterine contractions increase

Blood Accumulation

Leads to retroplacental hematoma

-

Mechanism

Weight of the placenta and blood facilitate detachment

Marginal areas are unsupported, leading to separation

Frequency

Less common

More common

questions.text: An elderly patient with a history of an intracapsular neck of femur fracture presents with hip pain radiating to the groin and thigh, worsening with activity but improving with rest. Examination reveals restricted range of motion and tenderness in the hip. Which of the following arteries is not typically involved in the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to such a presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inferior gluteal artery

 

Explanation:

The symptoms and examination findings, including hip pain radiating to the groin and thigh, worsened by activity and restricted motion, indicate avascular necrosis of the femoral head, commonly following an intracapsular neck of femur fracture.

The inferior gluteal artery primarily supplies the gluteal region and does not contribute significantly to the blood supply of the femoral head. Therefore, it is not typically involved in AVN associated with neck of femur fractures.

 

Blood supply to the femoral head and neck

 

Blood Supply Source

Description

Retinacular Vessels
  • Major supply, derived from the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries (branches of the deep femoral artery).
  • Forms an extensive network along the femoral neck.

Intraosseous Cervical Vessels
  • Secondary source, providing additional vascular support through small penetrating vessels along the femoral neck.

Artery of Ligamentum Teres
  • Tertiary source, also called the foveolar artery.
  • Supplies the femoral head via the ligamentum teres.
  • Important in younger patients or in cases of trauma.

Obturator Artery
  • Provides minor support through its acetabular branch.
  • Primarily supplies the medial thigh muscles but contributes to anastomoses around the hip joint.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was found shot dead in a parking lot. Forensic examination revealed that the cause of death was a shotgun injury. Considering the type of injury, what is the probable range of the shot?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) < 1 metre

 

Explanation:

  • A close-shot injury (< 1 metre) has a circular or elliptical entry wound with blackening, burning, tattooing, and singeing of hair.
  • The wound track and surrounding tissues appear cherry-red due to carbon monoxide absorption.

 

Gunshot wound characteristics based on Range of shooting:

Shooting Range

Range

Wound Description

Contact shot

Muzzle in direct contact

Circular entry wound with muzzle imprint, severe tissue damage, blackening, and burning of the wound edges. Cherry-red tissue due to carbon monoxide absorption.

Close-shot (Option A)

< 1 meter

Circular or elliptical entry wound with blackening, burning, tattooing, singeing of hair, and cherry-red tissue discolouration due to carbon monoxide absorption.

Short-range (Option B)

1-2 meters

Circular 4-5 cm wound (Rat hole) with irregular borders, no blackening, burning, or tattooing.

Intermediate shot (Option C)

2-4 meters

Large, irregular wound surrounded by multiple satellite wounds.

Distant shot (Option D)

> 4 meters

The entry wound fades, leaving multiple small pellet wounds.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a 2.5 cm ulcerative lesion on the right side of his lower lip confirmed as squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the primary lymphatic drainage and surgical management of this lesion?

choices.text: Drains to submental nodes; level I neck dissection is sufficient.
Drains to ipsilateral submandibular nodes; levels I-III neck dissection is recommended.
High risk of contralateral metastasis; bilateral neck dissection is needed.
Drains to preauricular and parotid nodes; requires superficial parotidectomy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Drains to ipsilateral submandibular nodes; levels I-III neck dissection is recommended.

 

Explanation:

  • The lymphatic drainage of the lower lip is primarily to the submental (level IA) and submandibular (level IB) nodes.
  • There's a significant risk of occult nodal metastasis for a lesion of this size, especially one close to the commissure.
  • Therefore, a selective neck dissection, including levels I-III on the ipsilateral side, is typically recommended even in N0.

 

 

 

Management

1. Early Stage (T1-T2N0):

  • Wide local excision with 1 cm margins
  • Consider elective neck dissection for tumors >2 cm or >4 mm depth
  • Reconstruction: Primary closure, local flaps, or skin grafts

 

2. Advanced Stage (T3-T4 or N+):

  • Wide local excision with ≥1 cm margins
  • Neck dissection (comprehensive or selective based on nodal status)
  • Complex reconstruction (local/regional flaps, free tissue transfer)
  • Adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy based on pathological findings
 

3. Management of the Neck:

  • Elective neck dissection for high-risk tumors (>2 cm, >4 mm depth)
  • Therapeutic neck dissection for clinically positive nodes
  • Levels typically addressed: I-III for N0 neck, I-V for N+ neck

questions.text: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with cough, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. She recently cleaned an old barn where she was exposed to large amounts of bird droppings. On examination, she has mild tachycardia, and her lungs exhibit scattered crackles. A chest X-ray reveals patchy infiltrates and several calcified nodules. Histopathology and a lactophenol cotton blue (LPCB) mount of cultured colonies are provided. What treatment is she started on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amphotericin-B 

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the patient’s history, histopathology showing intramacrophagic yeast form and (LPCB) mount showing numerous hyaline hyphae with few tuberculate macroconidia (arrows) and many smooth-walled oval microconidia are pointing towards a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

Histoplasmosis

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells
 

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large, thick-walled, spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)
 

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum are helpful for immunocompromised individuals.

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B (Option B) for two to four weeks, followed by a year of itraconazole (Option A ruled out)

Fluconazole (Option C ruled out): It is usually reserved for less severe infections or maintenance therapy after initial treatment with more potent antifungals like amphotericin-B. 

Surgical resection (Option D ruled out): It may be considered for localised infections or complications like abscesses, but it is not appropriate as a primary treatment strategy for disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the dose-response curves for benzodiazepines (Blue curve) and barbiturates (Red curve) is correct?

choices.text: Benzodiazepines demonstrate a steeper dose-response curve compared to barbiturates.
Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index compared to barbiturates.
Both benzodiazepines and barbiturates display a linear dose-response relationship.
Benzodiazepines and barbiturates show similar potency but differ in their maximal efficacy on the dose-response curve.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index compared to barbiturates.

Explanation:

A linear dose-response relationship implies that the response increases proportionally with increasing dosage.

  • Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index, making them safer for clinical use.

  • Barbiturates possess a narrow therapeutic index, meaning the difference between therapeutic and toxic doses is small, increasing the risk of overdose.

    • It exhibit a steeper dose-response curve, leading to a rapid progression from sedation to anesthesia and potentially fatal respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a recent dental infection presents with persistent headaches, fever, and confusion. He exhibits focal neurological deficits and seizures. The radiological findings are provided. Given his clinical presentation and imaging, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage
Start oral antibiotics and monitor with CT every 48 hours
Administer high-dose corticosteroids and supportive care
Begin antiepileptic medications and refer for op follow-up.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage

 

Explanation:

  • Given the history of a recent dental infection, along with imaging showing a ring-enhancing lesion in the frontal lobe and symptoms of fever, confusion, and seizures, the most likely diagnosis is a Brain abscess.
  • The mainstay treatment includes both surgical intervention and antibiotic therapy.

Brain Abscess:

  • Pathology:
    • Direct Spread: From air sinus infections or following brain surgery.
    • Hematogenous Spread: Typically associated with respiratory infections, endocarditis, or dental infections.
  • Symptoms include fever, confusion, seizures, focal neurological deficits and raised ICT.
  • Most common in the frontal lobe, but are also frequently found in the parietal lobe, particularly in cases of hematogenous spread.
  • Imaging:
    • CT Scan (Initial Choice): Shows hypodense oedema initially, progressing to a ring-enhancing mass as the abscess matures.
    • MRI (IOC): Identifies restricted diffusion
  • Management: (Mainstay: Surgery + Antibiotics)
    • Early Surgical Drainage: Essential for effective treatment.
    • Antibiotics: IV antibiotics are administered for approximately 6 weeks.
    • Prophylactic Anticonvulsants: Considered due to a high risk of seizures.
    • Multiple smaller abscesses: IV Antibiotics.
    • Steroids: Reduce oedema and alleviate symptoms of mass effect.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman has been complaining of patchy scalp hair loss for the past three weeks. Her past medical history is significant for vitiligo and thyroid disorders. On examination, she has a well-circumscribed area of hair loss over her occipital region, as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of the disease described?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Trichoclasis

 

Explanation:

This patient with a history of autoimmune diseases and patchy hair loss as described in the question and image is suggestive of alopecia areata.

Trichoclasis is a feature of a feature of trichorrhexis nodosa, not alopecia areata.

Trichoclasis:

  • It is a transverse break in the hair shaft through a node seen in Trichorrhexis nodosa.
  • It is a hair shaft disorder where the hair shaft is excessively fragile due to the presence of nodes.
  • The end of the hair resembles a small paint brush with cortical fibers extruding through the fracture as shown in the image.
  • The proximal end of the hair shaft is normal, unlike in alopecia areata.

 

  • It is associated with rare genetic diseases like argininosuccinate lyase deficiency.
  • Clinical features: Sparse, brittle, and lustreless hair
  • Diagnosis is through physical examination and hair shaft microscopy
  • Treatment includes avoiding trauma to the hair and management of the medical cause.

 

The features of alopecia areata include

  • Ophiasis is scalp hair loss in the occipital region, whereas sisaipho is the opposite of this variant, with scalp hair loss sparing the temporal and occipital areas.
Ophiasis Sisaipho


 

  • Exclamation mark hair
  • Turning grey syndrome: It is a feature of alopecia areata where white hair are typically spared by immune cells, leading to loss of black hair with sparing of white hair
  • Nail pitting: Regular, geometric pitting of the nail bed as shown below.

Note: Psoriasis shows irregular pitting.

Treatment depends on the extent of the disease. Topical therapy for limited disease is done using intralesional steroids and contact immunotherapy whereas systemic therapy, Levamisole or Cyclosporine is used for extensive disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of muscle weakness, fatigue, and frequent urination. Her blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. Investigations: Serum K+: 2.8 mEq/L, Serum Na+: 148 mEq/L, Plasma aldosterone: 35 ng/dL, Plasma renin activity: 0.2 ng/mL/h. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Conn’s syndrome

Explanation: The likely diagnosis from the given scenario is Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, which is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone, usually from an adrenal adenoma.

  • It is characterised by resistant hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.
  • Causes:
    • Aldosterone-producing adenoma (Conn's adenoma) - Most common.
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.
  • Symptoms often include muscle weakness, fatigue, headaches, and frequent urination.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Elevated plasma aldosterone levels
    • Suppressed plasma renin activity
    • High aldosterone-to-renin ratio
  • Treatment involves surgical removal of the adenoma and the use of mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, such as spironolactone and eplerenone.

Role of Aldosterone: It acts on the collecting duct to –

  • Increase sodium reabsorption via epithelial sodium channels (ENaC).
  • Enhance potassium secretion through potassium channels (ROMK).

Bartter's syndrome(Option A)

  • It is a genetic disorder,childhood-onset, affecting the kidneys, leading to abnormalities in electrolyte reabsorption.
  • Typically presents with low blood pressure, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, elevated renin levels, and high urinary calcium excretion (hypercalciuria).

Gitelman's syndrome:(Option B)

  • A genetic disorder affects the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, leading to hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and metabolic alkalosis.
  • Typically presents with low or normal blood pressure and low urinary calcium excretion (hypocalciuria).

Liddle's syndrome(Option D)

  • It is a genetic disorder caused by the increased activity of epithelial sodium channels (ENaC), leading to sodium retention and potassium excretion.
  • It has low aldosterone and renin levels and typically presents with hypertension.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with right-sided visual field loss in both eyes, resulting in a homonymous hemianopic defect. Neuroimaging and clinical examination suggest a lesion affecting the visual pathway. Based on the above findings, which anatomical location is most likely implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left optic tract

 

Explanation:

  • A lesion in the left optic tract would cause right (contralateral) homonymous hemianopia, where the right visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Location of the lesion

Characteristic features

Optic nerve
  • Marked loss of vision or complete blindness on the affected side associated.
  • Near (accommodation) reflex is present.

Optic chiasma
  • Bitemporal hemianopia

Optic tract
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
  • Contralateral hemianopic pupillary responses, i.e. Wernicke's reaction.

Optic radiations
  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia (pie in the sky)
    • Produced when the inferior fibres (Meyer’s loop) are involved in temporal lobe lesions)
  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor)
    • Produced when superior fibres (Baum’s loop) are involved in parietal lobe lesions.

Visual cortex
  • Homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing

questions.text:
Match the following actions of insulin with the correct category:

Categories:

a) Increased by insulin
b) Decreased by insulin

Insulin Action:


	Cell growth
	Reabsorption of K+, Na+, and phosphate from the kidney
	Food intake
	Entry of phosphate and magnesium into the cell
	Body weight
	Lipolysis
	Potassium uptake into cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) a)-1,2,4,5,7 & b)-3,6

Explanation: 

a) Increased by insulin

  • Cell growth: Insulin promotes cell growth and proliferation.
  • Reabsorption of K+, Na+, and phosphate from the kidney: Insulin enhances the reabsorption of these electrolytes in the kidneys.
  • Entry of phosphate and magnesium into the cell: Insulin facilitates the uptake of phosphate and magnesium into cells.
  • Body weight: Insulin can increase body weight due to its effects on fat storage increasing adipose tissue mass.
  • Potassium uptake into cells: Insulin promotes the movement of potassium into cells, which can lower blood potassium levels. Therefore is very useful in the management of acute renal failure. Insulin is considered a physiological regulator of plasma K+ concentration.

b) Decreased by insulin

  • Food intake: Insulin can promote satiety by increasing leptin levels in plasma, leading to decreased food intake. Also partly mediated by its inhibitory effect on neuropeptide Y release from the hypothalamus.
  • Lipolysis: Insulin inhibits lipolysis, which is the breakdown of fats into fatty acids and glycerol.

questions.text:
A patient undergoes a procedure affecting a delicate, thread-like structure extending from the conus medullaris to the coccyx as marked in the figure. Which of the following statements regarding this structure is correct?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: It is composed mainly of dura mater and contains no nerve fibers
Distal part of it is called the coccygeal ligament.
It does not extend beyond the sacral hiatus
It measures about 50 cm in length

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Distal part of it is called the coccygeal ligament.

 

Explanation:

The marked structure in the given image is the Filum terminale and it consists of 2 parts: filum terminale internum and the distal filum terminale externum, also known as the coccygeal ligament.

Filum terminale is a thread-like extension of the pia mater (Option A) measuring about 20 cm in length. (Option D)

 

  • Location: Extends from the tip of the conus medullaris to the base of the coccyx.
    • Pathway: Pierces the dural tube, traverses the sacral canal and sacral hiatus (Option C) and attaches to the dorsal surface of the first coccygeal vertebra.

  • Segments
    • Filum Terminale Internum: Approximately 15 cm long, located within the dural sac.
    • Filum Terminale Externum: About 5 cm long, situated outside the dura mater, below the second sacral vertebra.
  • Composition:
    • Primarily pia mater, with some nerve fibers from the second and third coccygeal nerves on its outer surface.
    • The central canal of the spinal cord extends into it for about 5 mm.

questions.text: A forensic team is called to investigate a case of judicial hanging in an obese individual. The victim was found suspended from a significant height with the knot positioned at the back of the neck. During the autopsy, a transverse tear in the carotid artery is observed, consistent with a long drop hanging. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amussat's Sign

Explanation:

The scenario describes the typical presentation of Amussat's Sign, which is characterized by transverse carotid artery tears, particularly in cases of long drop hangings with posteriorly placed knots, especially in obese victims.

 

  • While dribbling of saliva (Option A ruled out) and ligature marks (Option B ruled out) are significant, Amussat's Sign specifically indicates carotid artery injuries in hanging.
  • Simon's Sign indicates hemorrhages in the lumbar spine but is not directly linked to the mechanics of hanging. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with symptoms of urinary obstruction, including difficulty in starting urination, weak urinary stream, and frequent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, he has a history of trauma to the pelvic region. A retrograde urethrogram (RGU) reveals a stricture in the anterior urethra measuring more than 2 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

choices.text: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa

 

Explanation:

 

  • Urethroplasty (Surgical excision and reconstruction) is the gold standard for managing long strictures (greater than 2 cm).
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected stricture segment and reconstructing the urethra using a graft taken from the buccal mucosa.

 

Urethral Stricture

 

Definition

Abnormal narrowing of the urethra, causing partial or complete obstruction of urine flow, leading to discomfort and severe complications if untreated.

Causes

Trauma (Most common): Pelvic fractures, falls, accidents, or iatrogenic trauma from prolonged catheterization.

Infections: STIs like gonorrhea and chlamydia causing urethritis.

Medical Procedures: Urethral surgeries or radiation for pelvic cancers.

Inflammatory Conditions: Chronic inflammation from conditions like lichen sclerosus.

Investigations

Posterior Urethral Stricture: Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) to visualize the posterior urethra and bladder during voiding.

Anterior Urethral Stricture: Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU).


Emergency Evaluation: Both RGU and MCU may be used in trauma cases or acute urinary retention.

Management

Urethral Dilation: Temporary relief with dilators, often leading to recurrence. (Option A)

Optical Internal Urethrotomy (OIU): Endoscopic incision at the 12 o'clock position; effective for short bulbar strictures (<2 cm).(Option B)

Urethroplasty: Surgical excision and reconstruction; the gold standard for recurrent or complex strictures (Option C).

  • Strictures up to 2 cm: Excision with end-to-end anastomosis.
  • Strictures >2 cm: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa, bladder mucosa, or penile skin.

 

  • Urethral Stenting (Option D) involves placing a stent in the urethra to keep it open.
    • While stenting can relieve obstruction temporarily, it is not a definitive treatment for strictures and may be associated with complications, such as infection and migration of the stent.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not the content of carotid sheath?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) External jugular vein

 

Explanation :

Carotid Sheath: Condensation of the connective tissue around the great vessels of the neck, forming a tubular sheet of fascia.

 

Contents
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve.

Anatomical Details
  • The carotid sheath extends from the upper border of the thyroid cartilage down to the bifurcation of the carotid arteries.
  • The internal jugular vein is lateral to the carotid artery; the vagus nerve is located between and posterior to the vessels.

Anteriorly

The carotid sheath is covered by the pretracheal fascia.

Posteriorly

The carotid sheath is bordered by the prevertebral fascia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 12-day history of missed periods and a positive pregnancy test undergoes a procedure to empty her uterus. Identify the instrument used in this early pregnancy management procedure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Menstrual regulation syringe

Explanation:

The instrument shown above is a menstrual regulation syringe.    

Aspect

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
(Option B)

Menstrual Regulation (Option D)

Use

Uterine evacuation up to 12 weeks of pregnancy for medical termination.

Aspiration of endometrial cavity within 14 days of missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Instrument used

MVA Syringe: Has double pinchable valves

MR Syringe: Has a single pinchable valve

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia

Sedation or paracervical block

Indications

Medical termination of pregnancy, incomplete/missed abortion, molar pregnancy, blighted ovum, endometrial sampling/biopsy.

Missed period, failed abortion, molar pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy exclusion.

Uterine curette (Option A): Commonly used in D&C, a method for uterine evacuation, it is more invasive and typically used in later stages of pregnancy or for different indications.

Karman Cannula (Option C) is a component used in the MVA procedure but does not function independently as the evacuation instrument.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension visits your clinic for follow-up. Her blood pressure is 158/96 mmHg, despite being on lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Her serum creatinine and potassium levels are within normal limits. Which calcium channel blockers would be the most appropriate addition to her long-term blood pressure control treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Amlodipine is a long-acting dihydropyridine CCB, and it would be an appropriate choice to achieve better blood pressure control in the long term. It can be used as an add-on therapy with other antihypertensive agents, and its once-daily dosing improves patient compliance.

Mechanism of action of CCB (Dihydropyridines):

It blocks the entry of calcium ions through the L-type calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle cells, causing vasodilation and a reduction in peripheral vascular resistance.

 

Drug

Use

Rationale for Choice

Nifedipine (Option A) Short-acting

Primarily used for angina pectoris

Not recommended for long-term hypertension management due to its short duration of action and potential for reflex tachycardia.

Nicardipine (Option B) Short-acting

Commonly used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and perioperative hypertension or severe hypertension in the intensive care unit.

The short duration of action makes it less suitable for long-term hypertension management.

Clevidipine (Option C) Ultra-short-acting

Very short half-life makes it unsuitable for long-term hypertension management.

Amlodipine (Option D) Long-acting.

Recommended as a first-line or add-on therapy for the long-term management of hypertension

Preferred choice due to its long duration of action (up to 24 hours), once-daily dosing, and effectiveness in lowering blood pressure with good tolerability.

questions.text:
Q. Match the following:

 


	
		
			
			1. Randomisation
			
			
			a. Eliminates only the known confounders.
			
		
		
			
			2. Standardisation
			
			
			b. Eliminate the effect of age and gender.
			
		
		
			
			3. Restriction
			
			
			c. Eliminates both known and unknown confounders.
			
		
		
			
			4. Matching
			
			
			d. Limits the participation in the study to individuals who are similar concerning confounders.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

Explanation:

 

Techniques To Eliminate Confounders

Method

Description

Matching


 
  • Cases are matched with the control and should be similar to the control in every possible variable that can affect the study's outcome except the disease in question.
  • Done in a case-control study.
  • Eliminates only the known confounders.

Restriction
  • Limits participation in the study to individuals who are similar in terms of confounders.

Randomisation
  • The technique where every participant will get an equal and known chance of being allocated to either the treatment group or the control group.
  • Eliminates both known and unknown confounders.

Stratification (Segregate)
  • Stratify the participants of the study or segregate them.

Standardisation
  • Adjusting the results to a standard population to control for confounding variables often used in rate comparisons
  • Eliminate or control the effect of age and gender.

Multivariate regression models
  • Used when there are multiple confounders.

questions.text:
Which among the given statements is wrong regarding resuscitation of newborn?

 

a) The recommended pressure of suction is 80 mmHg

b) Correct order of suction: mouth followed by nose.

c) The recommended pressure should never exceed >80 mmHg

d) Correct order of suction: nose followed by mouth
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) c & d are wrong

 

Explanations:

Suction of airways:

  • The correct order of suction: is mouth followed by nose.
  • When suctioning the nose, vagal stimulation may induce the baby to take a deep breath, potentially resulting in aspiration, if oral secretions are present.
  • The recommended pressure of suction is 80 mmHg
  • It should never exceed >100 mmHg

questions.text: 32-year-old man presents with generalized oedema and frothy urine. Laboratory results show 24-hour urine protein: 8 g/day, serum albumin: 2.2 g/dL, serum cholesterol: 310 mg/dL and creatinine is 1.3 mg/dl. USG guided kidney biopsy was done and H and E image is shown. Electron microscopy shows widespread effacement of podocyte foot processes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:

  • The Light microscopy image shows segmental sclerosis and obliteration of normal histology of glomerulus seen in FSGS. The electron microscopy findings and age group align with this presentation. Option A is seen in children commonly and has normal glomerular appearance on histological examination.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps in the correct order as they occur in the process of drug development:


	Filing of an Investigational New Drug (IND) application.
	Start toxicity and safety testing based on GLP guidelines.
	Approval from Central Drugs Standard Control Organization (CDSCO).
	Start pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics testing based on GCP guidelines.
	Filing of an NDA application to CDSCO.
	Approval from the Committee for Control and Supervision of Experiments on Animals (CPCSEA)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 6, 2, 1, 4, 3, 5

Explanation:

Steps in drug development:

  1. Pre-clinical study CPCSEA approval: Ensuring the ethical treatment of animals in research.
  2. Initiate preclinical testing: Using GLP (Good Laboratory Practices) guidelines, animal studies are conducted to assess the safety and toxicity of drugs.
  3. IND application filing: Submit a new experimental drug application to CDSCO for a human clinical trial.
  4. Begin clinical trials: Conducted in four stages to evaluate the drug's efficacy and safety using the GCP guidelines (Good Clinical Practice).
  5. Approval from the Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO): To perform clinical studies and market the drug in India.
  6. NDA application filing: A new drug application is submitted to CDSCO for marketing.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with cough and breathing difficulty and was diagnosed with emphysema after radiographic examination. Which of the following genetic conditions should be suspected as a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

 

Explanation:

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic condition characterised by low levels or dysfunctional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the alpha-1 antitrypsin gene located on Chromosome 14.
  • The condition primarily affects the lungs, leading to panacinar emphysema and the liver, causing cirrhosis due to abnormal protein accumulation.

 

Cystic fibrosis (Option A) is a genetic disorder caused by CFTR gene mutations, leading to thick mucus, chronic lung infections, and bronchiectasis.

  • While it causes obstructive lung disease, emphysema is not typical.

 

Asthma (Option B) is a chronic inflammatory condition causing reversible airway obstruction and episodic wheezing, coughing, and breathlessness.

  • It does not typically result in emphysema or structural lung damage.

 

Bronchiectasis (Option D) is a condition of permanently dilated bronchi due to chronic infections or inflammation.

  • While it causes cough and sputum production, it does not primarily lead to emphysema.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is found deceased in her living room with a shotgun wound to the head. Considering the characteristics of the injury, what type of wound is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Contact shot wound

 

Explanation:

  • A contact shot wound shows a cruciate/ stellate entry wound, especially over thick bony areas like the skull, along with a muzzle impression and burning, blackening and tattooing in the surroundings.
  • Blowback phenomenon:
    • It occurs in contact gunshot wounds, particularly over thick, bony areas such as the skull.
    • It results from the high energy and expanding gases generated when a firearm is discharged at close range.
    • As the bullet penetrates the skin, the force of the gases creates a pressure wave that causes significant tissue displacement and injury.

 

Type of shotgun wounds

Circular

Multiple small pellet wounds with the mostly dispersed entry wound

Border of wound

Contused, Irregular and muzzled appearance

Clean-cut, irregular or lacerated

Abraded and scalloped borders

Irregular

Present around the margins and even inside the wound.

questions.text: Blood pressure of a 65-year-old male in the ICU crashes. ECG tracing shows Ventricular fibrillation. 200 J biphasic shock is given to patient. Which of the following is next best step for managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Start CPR  

Immediately after defibrillation, the rhythm takes some time to reset to normal. During this time, chest compressions must continue @30:2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with double vision, drooping of the right eyelid, and difficulty moving his right eye in multiple directions. On examination, the patient has normal visual acuity, ptosis, restricted eye movement, decreased sensation over the forehead, and absent corneal reflex on the same side. What is the most likely diagnosis and which cranial nerve is/are most likely affected in this condition?

choices.text: Superior orbital fissure syndrome; III, IV, V, and VI nerves
Tolosa Hunt syndrome; II, III and IV nerves

questions.solution:
Superior orbital fissure syndrome typically involves cranial nerves III (oculomotor), IV (trochlear), V1 (ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve), and VI (abducens), which pass through the superior orbital fissure. Clinical manifestation of ptosis (III), ophthalmoplegia (III, IV, VI), sensory loss over the forehead, and absent corneal reflex (V1) points towards the diagnosis of this syndrome.

 

Superior orbital fissure syndrome:

  • Also known as the Rochon-Duvigneaud syndrome. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is caused by compression of structures anterior to the orbital apex.

 

Etiology:

  • Most common cause is trauma
  • Idiopathic
  • Neoplasias
  • Meningitis, syphilis, sinusitis, herpes zoster
  • Inflammation - Lupus, sarcoidosis, Tolosa-Hunt syndrome (Episodes of unilateral orbital pain, cranial nerve involved and granulomatous inflammation)
  • Vascular phenomena - carotid-cavernous fistulas, retro-orbital hematoma, and carotid aneurysms

 

Pathophysiology: Involvement of the structures passing through the superior orbital fissure (III, IV, VI, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve). (Option A)

 

Clinical features:

  • Pain (retro-orbital ache)
  • Sensory loss in the distribution of ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve
    • Absent corneal reflex
    • Decreased sensation over the forehead
  • Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve involvement
  • Ptosis due to 3rd nerve paralysis

 

Investigations:

  • CT, MRI
  • Angiography- vascular causes of the syndrome

 

Orbital apex syndrome; optic nerve (Option B):

  • It is a symptom complex due to the involvement of structures present at the apex of the orbit (structures passing through the superior orbital fissure and the optic canal)
  • So the cranial nerves involved are II, III, IV, V, and VI
  • Optic nerve (II) involvement causes visual loss and afferent pupillary defect

 

Tolosa Hunt syndrome; II, III, and IV nerves (Option C):

  • It is idiopathic nonspecific granulomatous inflammation involving the cavernous sinus and orbital apex causing compression of surrounding nerves.
  • Commonly manifests as painful ophthalmoplegia and presents as superior orbital fissure syndrome or orbital apex syndrome depending upon the extent of involvement
  • Clinical manifestations in this scenario suggest there is no involvement of the optic nerve (II)

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a 4-year-old child is assessed using Waterlow's Classification. The child's height-for-age is found to be 85%, while weight-for-height is 85%. According to Waterlow's Classification, the nutritional status of this child would be categorized as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stunted

 

Explanation:

According to Waterlow’s criteria, Weight for height ≥ 80% and Height for Age < 90% is termed as Stunted.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a 20-year history of rheumatoid arthritis has a painless, progressively thinning area in the sclera of her left eye. The area appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type III hypersensitivity

Explanation:

The diagnosis in this scenario is Scleromalacia Perforans.

  • It is usually associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and presents with scleral thinning, appearing bluish and without signs of inflammation.
  • The underlying cause of scleral thinning is probably ischemia because of vessel damage (Type III hypersensitivity).

 

  • Type II hypersensitivity (Option B) involves antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction or destruction.
  • Type IV hypersensitivity (Option C): Scleromalacia perforans is caused by immune complex–mediated vasculitis, not delayed-type hypersensitivity.
  • Infective etiology (Option D): Scleromalacia perforans is a sterile, autoimmune complication of systemic diseases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with irritation and redness at both eye corners, foamy discharge, and skin maceration as shown below. He also has chronic nasal discharge. Which organism is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Moraxella axenfeld

Explanation:

  • The presence of localized inflammation, redness, and foamy discharge confined to the angles of the eyes, along with skin maceration around these areas, points towards the diagnosis of angular conjunctivitis.
  • The most common cause is Moraxella axenfeld.
  • Infection is transmitted from the nasal cavity to the eyes via contaminated fingers or handkerchiefs.
  • Treatment: 
    • Oxytetracycline (1%) eye ointment applied 2-3 times a day for 9-14 days.
    • Zinc lotion is instilled during the day, and zinc oxide ointment at bedtime to inhibit the proteolytic enzyme and reduce maceration.

questions.text: A multigravida G2P1L1 delivers a baby at 37 weeks of gestation by cesarean section. On assessment, the baby was completely cyanosed having slow and irregular breathing with a heart rate of 76 bpm, and he was showing slight flexion on stimulation along with a slight frown when stimulated by an orogastric tube. Calculate the APGAR score for the baby.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4

 

Explanation: Completely cyanosed -0, slow and irregular breathing-1, HR of 76 bpm-1, slight flexion-1, slight frown-1 =4

APGAR score

  • The APGAR score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn’s condition.
  • It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.
  • Resuscitation must be initiated before the 1 minute score is assigned, therefore, it is not used to guide the resuscitation.
  • The components, along with scores, are,
 

0

1

2

Appearance

Completely blue or pale

The body is pink, and the extremities are blue

Completely pink

Pulse rate

Absent

<100/min

>100/min

Grimace

No response

Grimaces only

Coughs/sneezes

Activity

Limp and flaccid

Some flexion present

Flexed posture and actively moving limbs

Respiratory effort

None

Slow and irregular

Normal/strong

 

Interpretation:

  • Normal APGAR score is ≥7
  • Maximum score = 10; Minimum score = 0
  • Score for severe birth asphyxia = 0 - 3

 

Therefore, the APGAR score for the above case is 4. This indicates moderate distress at birth.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus managed on metformin presents to the clinic with increased blood glucose levels. Routine investigations revealed haemoglobin of 11 g/dL, serum creatinine of 2.3, and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 30 mL/min/1.73 m2. Which of the following additional medications can be safely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Linagliptin

 

Explanation:

  • This patient should be started on linagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor that requires no dosage adjustment for renal impairment in this patient with type-2 diabetes and end-stage kidney disease (eGFR = 30 mL/min/1.73 m2).

 

 

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors:

MOA
  • Increase Incretin Levels: Prevents degradation of incretin hormones (GLP-1 and GIP)
  • Enhance Insulin Secretion from the pancreas in response to meals. (no risk of hypoglycemia)
  • Reduce Glucagon Secretion
  • Maintain neutral weight

Uses
  • Oral hypoglycemic drug (type-2 diabetes)

Drugs
  1. Linagliptin: Safe in renal failure
  2. Teneligliptin: Safe in renal failure
  3. Vildagliptin: Hepatotoxic
  4. Alogliptin
  5. Sitagliptin
  6. Saxagliptin: (Option B)
    1. Metabolised by CYP3A4, it has more drug interactions.
    2. Requires dose adjustment in renal impairment.
    3. Risk of congestive heart failure.

Side effects
  • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
  • Pancreatitis (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Risk of pancreatic and thyroid cancer (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Arthritis, Nasopharyngitis:
    • Increase interleukins and cytokines levels (similar structure to CD26)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions: Steven-Johnson syndrome, angioedema


 

Dapagliflozin (Option A), an SGLT-2 inhibitor, is not recommended for use to improve glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus whose eGFR is less than 45 mL/min/1.73 m2.

 

Exenatide (Option C), a GLP-1 analogue, is avoided in patients with end-stage renal disease or ischemic renal failure due to hypovolemia.

questions.text: A 37 year old woman presents for routine checkup with an ultrasound revealing a 3 cm asymptomatic endometrioma on the left ovary. She expresses that she does not wish to conceive in the future. She has regular cycles, with normal flow & mild spasmodic dysmenorrhea. Given the clinical scenario, what is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient's endometrioma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Follow-up 6 monthly with transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation:

In this scenario, the patient has a 3 cm asymptomatic endometrioma and does not desire future fertility. According to current guidelines, Follow-up 6 monthly with transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is the most appropriate management for endometrioma as surgical interventions are indicated only for cysts> 5cm.

Management of Endometrioma:

  • If the patient wants to conceive:
    • Expectant management is done, irrespective of the size of the endometrioma
  • If pregnancy is not desired:
    • Size < 5cm and Asymptomatic: Follow up six monthly / 1 yearly with TVS
    • Size >5cm: Laparoscopic cystectomy (Option A)
  • Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (Option B):
    • Done only in women > 40 years after completion of family.
    • Prevents the formation of new lesions and pain due to it.
  • Laparoscopy procedures include:
    • Adhesiolysis
    • Fulgration of implants
    • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) (Option C): It involves disrupting nerve pathways to alleviate pain associated with endometriosis, particularly pelvic pain. It is not indicated for the management of ovarian endometriomas.
  • After surgical procedures, patients require medical management
    • Adolescents <16 years: OCPs
    • Adolescents >16 years: OCPs / GnRH Agonists
    • Adults: OCPs / GnRH Agonists / Progesterone

questions.text:
At your community medicine posting, a farmer arrives complaining of multiple nodules over his right leg after being pricked by a thistle. Examination findings are given in the image below. What would you expect to find on a microscopic examination of tissue from one of his lesions?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Asteroid Bodies

Explanation:

The patient’s presentation, along with the linear distribution of nodules, is suggestive of sporotrichosis/ Rose Gardner’s disease caused by Sporothrix schenckii.

  • It is a Subcutaneous fungal infection that typically occurs after the fungus is traumatically inoculated into the skin, often through thorn pricks, splinters, or scratches from contaminated plant materials.
  • Enzymes secreted by fungus, such as serine & aspartate proteinases help in local invasion.
  • Sporothrix schenckii has a tendency to spread along lymphatics.
  • Risk factors: Walking barefoot, farmers & gardeners.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Incubation period: 3 weeks
    • Types:

Lympho-cutaneous
  • M/C type (80%)
  • Painless modulo-ulcerative lesions along the lymphatics.
  • Lymph nodes can become enlarged, suppurative & indurated and have cord-like feeling on palpation.

Osteoarticular

  • Seen in alcoholics.

Pulmonary
  • Can be seen in underlying COPD.

Disseminated
  • Seen in immunocompromised patients.

Fixed cutaneous
  • Single nodule, less progressive & not spread by lymphatics.
  • Laboratory diagnosis:
    • KOH mount: Elongated yeast cells of 3-5 𝜇m in diameter (low sensitivity).
    • Histopathological staining with methenamine silver reveals cigar-shaped asteroid bodies comprising a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating eosinophilic extensions composed of antigen-antibody complexes. This eosinophilic halo is known as the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.
    • ​​​​​​​Culture is the most definitive test for diagnosis.

The image below shows the culture of S. schenckii:

The image below shows the asteroid body and Splendour Hoeppli phenomenon:

Treatment of Sporotrichosis:

  • Itraconazole is the drug of choice for all forms except disseminated sporotrichosis.
  • Amphotericin B is the preferred treatment for disseminated sporotrichosis.
  • Potassium iodide can also be used.

 

Black Granules (Option B) are classically associated with mycetoma/ Madura foot, caused by the organism M. mycetomatis. It can also be caused by the Actinomycetes bacteria, where there is the formation of yellow/ sulphur granules and discharging sinuses.

Madura foot:

Histopathology of Actinomycotic mycetoma:

Muriform bodies (Option C) are seen in chromoblastomycosis, which also occurs in farmers with a history of thorn or thistle pricks. It shows slow-growing, polymorphic, verrucous (m/c type) lesions and sclerotic bodies (muriform cells/medlar bodies).

Spherules containing endospores (Option D) are characteristic of coccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection.
