questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing surgery and is given repeated doses of suxamethonium for muscle relaxation. After some time, his muscle response starts to fade despite continuous stimulation. This is most likely due to the development of a phase II block. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of phase II block with suxamethonium?

choices.text: It is associated with a fade in muscle response during repetitive nerve stimulation
It can be influenced by prolonged exposure to suxamethonium
It responds predictably to cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine
Fast-twitch muscle fibres are more susceptible to phase II block than slow-twitch fibres

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It responds predictably to cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine

Explanation:

The response to cholinesterase inhibitors is unpredictable and may even worsen the block.

 

Phase II Block (accommodation):

It occurs with continuous or repeated exposure to depolarizing muscle relaxants, particularly suxamethonium, and is characterised by a gradual fade in muscle response. (Option A ruled out)

Mechanisms Behind Phase II Block:

  • Prejunctional effects: High concentrations of suxamethonium can block prejunctional acetylcholine receptors (AChRs), affecting acetylcholine synthesis and release.
  • Postjunctional effects: Fade may also stem from changes in postjunctional AChR sensitivity or kinetics, resulting in reduced response despite the continued presence of the relaxant.

TOF of Phase II depolarizing block

 

Factors Influencing Phase II Block:

  • Duration of exposure: Prolonged exposure to suxamethonium increases the chance of developing Phase II block. (Option B ruled out)
  • Drug concentration: Higher suxamethonium concentrations make Phase II block more likely.
  • Muscle type: Fast-twitch muscle fibres are more susceptible to Phase II block than slow-twitch fibres. (Option D ruled out)
  • Interaction with other agents: Anesthetics or other drugs can affect the development of Phase II block.

Reversal of Phase II Block:

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine): Not recommended as the response is unpredictable and could worsen the block. (Option C).

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a history of bloody diarrhea followed by decreased urine output, lethargy, and paleness. Laboratory tests reveal hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated creatinine levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Typical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)

Types and Causes
  • STEC-HUS: Caused by E. coli O157 (Shiga toxin)
  • Atypical HUS: Caused by genetic mutations, immune issues, pregnancy, cancers, medications

Pathophysiology and Pathology
  • Shiga toxin damages blood vessels in kidneys and brain

Clinical Features
  • Typical HUS: Bloody diarrhea, decreased urine output, paleness, lethargy, seizures
  • Atypical HUS: No bloody diarrhea, High blood pressure, mild breathing difficulties (Option C).

Diagnosis and Laboratory Investigations

Triad:

  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Acute kidney injury
 

Blood tests: Anemia, low platelet count, elevated creatinine

Stool cultures for E. coli O157 in STEC-HUS

Complications
  • Acute: Seizures, stroke, heart failure, death
  • Chronic: Chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Differential Diagnosis
  • ITP: Affects platelets only, lacks hemolytic anemia and kidney injury (Option A).
  • DIC: Widespread clotting and bleeding, different clinical features (DIC) (Option B)

Treatment
  • Supportive care
  • Plasma exchange for aHUS
  • Antibiotics not recommended for STEC-HUS

questions.text:
Match the parts of the Papez circuit with their correct functions:


	
		
			
			Part of Papez Circuit
			
			
			Function
			
		
		
			
			1) Cingulate Gyrus
			
			
			A) Conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory
			
		
		
			
			2) Parahippocampal Gyrus
			
			
			B) Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing
			
		
		
			
			3) Hippocampus
			
			
			C) Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain
			
		
		
			
			4) Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus
			
			
			D) Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 - B, 2 - D, 3 - A, 4 - C

Explanation:
The Papez circuit is a neurocircuitry of the limbic system involved in learning and memory, emotion, and social behavior.

 

It has the following components:

Part of Papez Circuit

Function

Cingulate Gyrus

Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing.

Parahippocampal Gyrus and Entorhinal Cortex

Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space.

Hippocampus

Responsible for the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory.

Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus

Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following components is most accurately matched with its contribution to the total volume of semen?

choices.text: Seminal vesicles contribute 20% of the total volume.
Prostate contributes 60% of the total volume.
Bulbourethral glands contribute the majority of the semen volume.
Seminal vesicles contribute 60% of the total volume.

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Seminal vesicles contribute 60% of the total volume.

 

Explanation:

The seminal vesicles are responsible for producing approximately 60% of the total volume of semen. The fluid from the seminal vesicles is rich in fructose and other substances that provide energy and aid in the motility of sperm.

Sperm Maturation:

  • Spermatogenesis: Begins during adolescence; takes ~74 days.
  • Initial Mobility: Sperm are not fully mobile upon leaving the testes.
  • Maturation: Occurs in the epididymis where sperm gain motility.
  • Motility Mechanism: Involves activation of cation channel proteins (CatSper family) in the sperm tail.
  • Alkaline Sensitivity: CatSpers form an alkaline-sensitive Ca2+ channel, activated as sperm transition from acidic vagina to alkaline cervical mucus.

Sperm Capacitation

  • Location: Occurs in the isthmus of the uterine tubes.
  • Purpose: Prepares sperm for the acrosome reaction and increases motility.

Contents of Semen

  • Composition: Sperm and fluids from seminal vesicles, prostate, Cowper glands, and potentially urethral glands.
  • Volume: 2.5–3.5 mL per ejaculation after several days of abstinence.
  • Sperm Count: About 100 million sperm per mL.
  • Fluid Source:
    • Seminal vesicles: 60% (Option A) (Option D)
    • Prostate: 20% (Option B)
    • Bulbourethral glands: Remaining portion (Option C)

Surface Proteins: Sperm contain proteins like fertilin for egg cell membrane fusion

questions.text:
In a recent census survey conducted in a developing country, the government aims to measure the literacy levels among its population accurately. The survey team decides to calculate both the crude literacy rate and the effective literacy rate to gain a comprehensive understanding.

What distinguishes the effective literacy rate from the crude literacy rate?

choices.text: It provides a broad measure of literacy across all age groups.
It focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.
The literacy rate is calculated using the total population as the denominator.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.

Explanation: The Effective Literacy Rate focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.

Crude Literacy Rate

Effective Literacy Rate

Definition: The literacy rate is calculated using the total population as the denominator. (Option C)

Definition: The literacy rate is calculated using the population aged 7 years and above as the denominator.

Includes the entire population. (Option D)

Focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.

Provides a broad measure of literacy across all age groups. (Option A)

Offers a more specific measure of literacy among individuals more likely to have completed basic education.

questions.text: A patient underwent genetic testing after being diagnosed with colon cancer. Testing reveals a mutation associated with Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). Which of the following genes is defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MLH1 and MSH2

Explanation:

 

Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome, is caused by inherited mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes - MSH2 and MLH1.

Genes mutation

Manifestation

MLH1, MSH2 (Option D)

Results in microsatellite instability

Causes cluster of cancer: Colorectal, Endometrial, Ovarian, Pancreatic cancers

Colon cancer develops at a young age and it usually occurs in the right side

SMAD4 and BMPR1

(Option A)

Juvenile polyposis syndrome

STK11 (Option B)

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

APC gene (Option C)

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis(FAP), sporadic colon cancer, Gardner syndrome and Turcot syndrome

MUTYH (Option C)

MUTYH-associated polyposis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Few hours to 3 days

Explanation:

The above clinical scenario shows a blue-colored bruise that can be considered to be around a few hours to 3 days old.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is found unresponsive and without a pulse. Emergency responders are activated, and advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocols are initiated. Which of the following steps should be prioritized immediately after confirming cardiac arrest?

choices.text: Ensure proper airway management using bag-mask ventilation
Initiate high-quality chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Initiate high-quality chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute

 

Explanation:

  • Initiate high-quality chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute: High-quality chest compressions should be started immediately after confirming cardiac arrest to improve chances of survival.

ACLS Steps

Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) is crucial for managing cardiac arrest and cardiovascular emergencies, following the 2016 guidelines.

Key Steps in ACLS

Step

Description

1. Early Recognition and Activation

Identify cardiac arrest signs quickly and alert emergency services.

2. High-Quality Chest Compressions (Option C)

Initiate compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, with a depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm) for adults, allowing full chest recoil.

3. Early Defibrillation (Option D ruled out)

Deploy an AED promptly; follow prompts for defibrillation if a shockable rhythm is present.

4. Airway Management (Option B ruled out)

Ensure airway patency using techniques like bag-mask ventilation or advanced airway placement; provide oxygen to support ventilation.

5. Drug Administration (Option A ruled out)

Administer epinephrine (1 mg every 3-5 minutes); consider antiarrhythmics like amiodarone for shock-resistant VF/pulseless VT.

6. Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Assess for reversible causes ("H's and T's"):

Hypoxia

Hypovolemia

Acidosis (Hydrogen ion)

Hyper/hypokalemia

Hypothermia

Tension pneumothorax

Cardiac tamponade

Toxins

Thrombosis (pulmonary/coronary)

7. Post-Resuscitation Care

Provide comprehensive care after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), including monitoring and supportive therapies.

8. Continuous Quality Improvement

Assess and enhance resuscitation efforts, focusing on minimizing interruptions in compressions and following protocols.

questions.text:
A clinical trial of 4 new drugs was conducted, and the following graph was obtained. Based on this graph, which of the following statements is/are correct?



a) Drug A has the highest efficacy as well as the highest potency.

b) Drug A has the highest efficacy but the lowest potency.

c) Drug D has the highest efficacy as well as the highest potency.

d) Drug B is more potent than drug C.

choices.text: Statements a and d are correct
Statements b and d are correct
None of the statements are correct

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Statements a and d are correct

 

Explanation:

Drug A has the highest efficacy with the highest potency.

Drug B is more potent than drug C.

  • Efficacy is the maximal effect a drug can produce, represented by the Vmax /y-axis value. The higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy.
  • Potency is the amount of drug required to produce a given effect. The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency.
  • Both are independent of each other; efficacious drugs can have high or low potency and vice versa.
  • The first graph helps us estimate the efficacy of the drugs (the higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy). Thus, Drug A > B >C >D.
  • The second graph helps us estimate the drugs' potency (The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency). The left shift of the graph indicates an increase in potency. Thus Drug D > B > C > A.

questions.text: A new drug designed to lower cholesterol levels is being tested. The testing involved 1000 participants. The null hypothesis is that "the new drug does not affect cholesterol levels". After analysing the data, the researchers conclude that the drug doesn't work, but in reality, it does have a small but clinically significant effect. What type of error has occurred?

choices.text: Both Type I and Type II errors

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type II error

Explanation:

This scenario describes a Type II error, also known as a "false negative."

  • Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis.
  • In this case, a potentially beneficial drug might be overlooked.
  • Type II errors are particularly important in medical research, as they can lead to overlooking potentially beneficial treatments.
  • The power of a statistical test (1 - probability of Type II error) is crucial in designing studies to minimise this risk.

Type I error (Option A) occurs when you reject a true null hypothesis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has been complaining of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and swelling in his ankles and legs over the past few months. On physical examination, you notice hepatomegaly and proteinuria. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum creatinine levels and microscopic hematuria. Which of the following types of amyloid is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C

Explanation:

  • AL amyloidosis, also known as primary systemic amyloidosis, is characterized by the deposition of amyloid fibrils derived from monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains (lambda or kappa) produced by clonal plasma cells.
  • In this type of amyloidosis, the deposited amyloid fibrils can infiltrate various organs and tissues, including the kidneys, leading to organ dysfunction.
  • Clinical manifestations commonly include
    • Renal involvement causing proteinuria and renal impairment
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Peripheral oedema due to cardiac involvement.

 

AA amyloidosis (Option A):

  • AA amyloidosis, also known as secondary systemic amyloidosis, occurs secondary to chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, or chronic infections.
  • In AA amyloidosis, the amyloid fibrils are derived from serum amyloid A protein, an acute-phase reactant synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes in response to inflammation.

AB amyloidosis (Option B):

  • AB amyloidosis is not a recognized subtype of amyloidosis.
  • Amyloid fibrils derived from A Beta peptide are associated with Alzheimer's disease, but they are not a primary cause of systemic amyloidosis involving multiple organs.

ATTR amyloidosis (Option D):

  • ATTR amyloidosis, also known as transthyretin amyloidosis, occurs due to the deposition of amyloid fibrils derived from transthyretin protein, a transporter of thyroxine and retinol-binding protein.
  • It can be hereditary (caused by mutations in the transthyretin gene) or acquired (due to wild-type transthyretin protein).
  • It typically affects the heart and peripheral nerves, leading to cardiomyopathy and peripheral neuropathy, respectively.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a 1-week history of worsening eye pain and redness. On examination, a constricted pupil, a hazy anterior chamber, and deposits on the back of the cornea as shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterior Uveitis

 

Explanation:

  • Anterior uveitis is characterized by the presence of fine, grey keratic precipitates (KPs) on the corneal endothelium, a hazy anterior chamber (aqueous flare), and a constricted pupil.

 

Anterior Uveitis

Definition: Most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

 

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle

  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Koeppe's Nodules

 

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil

 

  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

 

Herpes Simplex Keratitis (Option A):

  • Presents with dendritic corneal ulcers, not fine, grey keratic precipitates or a hazy anterior chamber.
  • It also usually does not involve a constricted pupil.

Conjunctivitis (Option B):

  • Does not cause keratic precipitates , hazy anterior chamber and a constricted pupil.

Acute Angle Closure Glaucoma (Option D):

  • Presents with a mid-dilated or fixed, mid-dilated pupil, severe pain, redness, and vision changes.

questions.text: 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department after ingesting a large quantity of over-the-counter cough syrup in a suicide attempt. He complains of severe abdominal pain and confusion. ABG shows high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Urinalysis microscopy is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fomepizole:

  • The clue in the question is the image “dumbbell-shaped crystals” which are characteristic of calcium oxalate monohydrate.
  • Calcium oxalate crystalluria suggests ethylene glycol poisoning which can be present in over-the-counter local company manufactured cough syrups. The metabolites like glycolate will cause severe metabolic acidosis that causes CNS depression due to high anion gap metabolic acidosis. The antidote is fomepizole.

questions.text: On the Thyroid function test, TSH is suppressed, Free T4 level is normal, and Free T3 is increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) T3 thyrotoxicosis

  • The patient's clinical presentation suggests T3 thyrotoxicosis, which is supported by the suppressed TSH, normal Free T4 and increased Free T3 level.
  • T3 thyrotoxicosis occurs due to increased peripheral Deiodinase enzyme activity, which converts free T4 to free T3.

 

Thyroid Function Test interpretation:

Condition

TSH

↓ (<0.1 mIU/L)

↑

Normal

↓

Normal

Normal

Secondary hypothyroidism

↓ or approximately normal

↓

↓

T3 thyrotoxicosis

↓

Normal

↑
Euthyroid sick syndrome Normal Normal ↓

 

Additional Tests for Aetiology:

  • Anti-TPO (thyroid peroxidase) antibodies: Positive in Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • TRAb (TSH receptor antibody) or TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) (Option C)
    • For Graves' disease diagnosis
    • Used to predict remission after antithyroid drug treatment
    • Important in pregnancy to assess risk of fetal/neonatal thyrotoxicosis
  • Thyroglobulin (Tg)
    • Elevated in all types of thyrotoxicosis except factitia
    • Main use: follow-up of thyroid cancer patients post-treatment

Imaging Studies:

  • Thyroid Ultrasound 
  • Radioactive iodine uptake scan: While useful in differentiating causes of hyperthyroidism (e.g., Graves' disease vs. thyroiditis), it is not the immediate next best step. It is the next step after TFT shows a hyperthyroid picture.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy has been assessed for cognitive abilities, and his mental age is determined to be 9 years. What is the IQ based on the provided information?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 60

 

Explanation:

The child’s IQ calculated using the formula is 60, indicating significant limitations in intellectual functioning.

  1. Using the IQ formula:
    IQ=(Mental Age/Chronological Age)×100
  2. Substituting the ages:
    • Mental Age: 9 years
    • Chronological Age: 15 years
  3. IQ = (9/15)×100 = 60 (Options B, C, and D)

 

Intellectual Disability

  • Significant limitations in both:
    • Intellectual functioning –reasoning, learning, problem-solving.
    • Adaptive behaviour – conceptual, social, and practical skills.
  • Onset before 18 years.

 

Intelligence quotient

  • Intelligence is usually measured by calculating IQ.
  • IQ is an intelligence quotient.
  • IQ = (Mental age ÷ Chronological age) x 100
    • Chronological age - Age calculated from the date of birth.
    • Mental age - The age of one's intellect.
    • Various tests are done to calculate mental age.
  • Normal IQ: 90-109
  • Borderline IQ: 80-89
  • Mental retardation: IQ < 70

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student reports a persistent, irrational fear of blood. She states that seeing blood, even in movies, makes her feel faint and nauseous. This has caused her to avoid medical procedures and prevented her from volunteering for first aid training, which is required for her degree. Her symptoms have been present since childhood. Which of the following would be the most effective initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Behavioral therapy with exposure therapy

Explanation:

Behavioral therapy with exposure therapy is the most effective treatment for specific phobias, including blood phobia (hemophobia). In exposure therapy, the individual is gradually exposed to the feared object or situation in a safe, controlled manner, helping to reduce the intensity of the fear response over time.

 

Specific phobias

  • Strong, persistent, irrational fear of a specific object/situation.
  • Specific phobia is the persistence of this fear for 6 months or more.

 

Symptoms:

  • Exposure to the object/situation causes immediate fear, panic, and/or anxiety.
  • Avoidance behaviors: of the object or situation.
  • The fear/anxiety is out of proportion to the likely threat.
  • Marked distress or impairment psychosocially.
  • DSM-5
    • Animal (e.g., Dogs, Cats, Spiders)
    • Natural environment (e.g., Water, heights)
    • Blood-Injection-Needle (e.g., Needles, Invasive Medical Procedures)
    • Situational (e.g., Closed places, Planes)
    • Others

 

Common phobias

Acrophobia

Fear of height

Ailurophobia

Cats

Cynophobia

Dogs

Claustrophobia

Closed spaces

Mysophobia

Dirt and Germs

Hydrophobia

Water

Thanatophobia

Death

Nyctophobia

Dark

Xenophobia

Strangers

Pyrophobia

Fire

Hemophobia

Blood

Arachnophobia

Spiders


 

Treatment:

Psychosocial therapy:

  • The strategy of choice is behavioral therapy (Option A)
    • Exposure therapy - systematic desensitization
    • Reinforcing the realization that the phobic stimulus is safe and not dangerous.
    • Techniques to deal with anxiety - relaxation and breathing control.
    • The patients keep moving up the scale until the most anxiety-provoking stimuli no longer elicit any fear or anxiety (Desensitized).
    • Flooding (Implosion): Increasing exposure to the stimulus to induce habituation and decrease anxiety- no longer preferred.
  • Virtual therapy
  • Hypnosis
  • Supportive therapy
  • Family therapy

Pharmacological therapy:

  • Treat comorbid conditions.
  • For example, beta-blockers and benzodiazepines for panic attacks.

 

Serotonin-Norepinephrine reuptake Inhibitor (SNRI) (Option B): They are used in treating generalized anxiety disorders, depression, and panic disorders, but they are not first-line treatments for specific phobias. Medications are generally not as effective for treating specific phobias as psychotherapy, particularly exposure-based techniques. This option is incorrect.

 

Short-term benzodiazepines (Option C): They can be used for temporary relief of acute anxiety in phobia-related situations, but they are not considered a long-term treatment or the most effective approach for specific phobias. This option is incorrect.

 

Antipsychotic medication (Option D): They are used as second-line drugs to treat anxiety-related disorders. They are not indicated for the treatment of specific phobias such as hemophobia. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes a split-thickness skin graft for a large wound on his leg. Three days postoperatively, the graft appears swollen with fluid accumulating underneath it. Which of the following complications is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hematoma or seroma formation

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the accumulation of fluid beneath the graft is indicative of hematoma or seroma formation.
  • This complication can prevent proper adherence of the graft to the wound bed, leading to graft failure if not addressed promptly.
  • Hematomas are collections of blood, while seromas are accumulations of clear fluid. Both can occur when there is inadequate hemostasis or when there is excessive movement or pressure on the graft site post-operatively.

 

Complications of Skin Grafting:

  1. Graft Failure (Option A ruled out):
    • This occurs when the graft does not survive or integrate with the recipient site, due to poor vascularization or improper placement.
    • It is not characterized by fluid accumulation beneath the graft.
    • It can be prevented by ensuring good contact between the graft and the wound bed and avoiding movement or pressure on the graft.
  2. Infection (Option C ruled out):
    • Infection typically presents with redness, warmth, and pus rather than just fluid accumulation.
    • Strict sterile techniques during surgery and the use of prophylactic antibiotics can help prevent infections.
  3. Hematoma or Seroma Formation (Option B):
    • Occur when blood or fluid collects under the graft.
    • Proper hemostasis during surgery and the use of drains can prevent this issue.
  4. Poor Cosmetic Outcome (Option D ruled out): 
    • If the graft does not match the recipient site's skin texture or thickness, or if it is not placed correctly, the cosmetic result may be unsatisfactory.
    • Careful selection of graft thickness and meticulous placement can help achieve a better aesthetic outcome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient has hypertension and hypokalemia. His blood pressure is consistently elevated despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. Laboratory tests reveal elevated plasma aldosterone concentration and suppressed plasma renin activity. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an adrenal adenoma. Which is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Spironolactone

 

Explanation :

  • Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome) is characterised by excessive production of aldosterone from the adrenal glands, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia.
  • Spironolactone, an aldosterone antagonist and a potassium-sparing diuretic, is the most appropriate drug of choice.

Spironolactone:

  • Aldosterone combines with an intracellular mineralocorticoid (MR) receptor and induces the formation of aldosterone-induced proteins (AIPs), which promote Na+ reabsorption.
  • Spironolactone acts as a competitive antagonist and inhibits the formation of AIP by combining with MR.
  • This prevents aldosterone from promoting sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, which are the primary mechanisms by which aldosterone increases blood pressure and causes hypokalemia.

Lisinopril (Option A) is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that reduces aldosterone levels by inhibiting the production of angiotensin II.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option B) is a thiazide diuretic that inhibits the reabsorption of sodium and potassium; thus, hyperaldosteronism-induced hypokalemia will be worsened.

Amlodipine (Option C) is a calcium channel blocker that works by relaxing the smooth muscle.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with a history of abdominal surgery performed 3 days ago. She reports worsening abdominal distension and has not passed stool since the surgery. On examination her abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels 

Explanation:

This presentation is consistent with Paralytic Ileus, a condition where impaired peristaltic activity results in decreased bowel motility.

  • Characterized by:
    • Impaired intestinal motility due to failure of peristaltic wave transmission.
    • Collection of food and fluid in the bowel (Option A).
    • Abdominal distension.

Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia) (Option D ruled out).
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Investigations

IOC: Abdominal X-ray. (Option C ruled out)

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with fever, offensive vaginal discharge, and lower abdominal pain following a spontaneous abortion at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, she has uterine tenderness. Ultrasound shows no evidence of spread beyond the uterus. What is the most likely clinical grade of her septic abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Grade I

Explanation:

Grade I septic abortion involves localized infection confined to the uterus. In this case, the absence of spread beyond the uterus on ultrasound and the patient's symptoms suggest a localized infection.

 

  • Septic abortion includes both spontaneous and induced abortions in pregnancies under 20 weeks gestation complicated by severe uterine infections like endometritis and parametritis.
  • Clinical Criteria: Includes fever ≥100.4°F (38°C), foul vaginal discharge, lower abdominal pain and tenderness.
  • Presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Chills, tachycardia, and malaise are also common.

 

Grade

Description

Management

I

(Option A)

Localized infection in the uterus

Hospitalization, Antibiotics, Uterine evacuation post-antibiotics if indicated

II

(Option B)

The infection spreads beyond the uterus (parametrium, tubes, ovaries)

Broad-spectrum antibiotics, Analgesics, Anti-tetanus serum, Clinical monitoring, Delayed evacuation

III

(Option C)

Generalized peritonitis or shock, often from illegal abortions

Intensive antibiotics, Supportive therapy, Emergency surgery if needed

questions.text: During a dermatology demonstration on the Koebner phenomenon, the professor also discusses the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon.Which of the following conditions typically shows a pseudo-Koebner response?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Warts

Explanation: Koebner phenomenon (isomorphic response): Appearance of new lesions at sites of skin trauma in diseases like psoriasis and lichen planus.
Pseudo-Koebnerization: Seen in warts (verruca vulgaris) due to autoinoculation from trauma or seeding of microorgaisms 

Types of Koebnerisation
 

Category

Cause

Examples

Images

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Development of lesions at sites of trauma.
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus (Option A)
  • Vitiligo

Psoriasis

 

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Non-immunological and occurs due to auto-inoculation and not trauma.
  • Verruca vulgaris (warts)
  • Molluscum

Warts

 

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

The phenomenon is infrequent or occurs only in specific circumstances.
  • Darier disease
  • Erythema multiforme (Option D).

Erythema multiforme

 

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Limited evidence or conflicting reports regarding the role of trauma in lesion formation.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B)
  • Lupus erythematosus

Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with difficulty performing fine voluntary movements of his right hand following a midbrain stroke. Neurological examination suggests involvement of pathways controlling distal limb muscles. Which of the following extra-pyramidal tracts contributes to the motor pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rubrospinal tract

 

Explanation:

  • The rubrospinal tract is part of the lateral motor pathway that controls distal muscles and fine voluntary movements, making it responsible for the deficits observed.
 

Lateral motor pathway

Medial motor pathway

Comprises of:
  • Corticospinal tract
  • Rubrospinal tract
  • Reticulospinal tract
  • Vestibulospinal tract
  • Tectospinal tract

Pathway and control
  • Terminates in the dorsolateral area of spinal gray matter and controls distal muscles
  • Terminates in ventromedial area of spinal gray matter and controls axial and proximal muscles

Function
  • Fine, skilled, voluntary motor movements
  • Maintaining erect posture

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with confusion and lethargy. His medical history includes cirrhosis. Physical examination reveals peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory tests show:
Serum sodium: 128 mEq/L
Serum creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
Total protein: 5.5 g/dL (low)
Albumin: 2.8 g/dL (low)

Which of the following best describes the type of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypervolemic hyponatremia

Explanation:
The patient has signs of fluid overload (edema, ascites), indicating hypervolemic hyponatremia. Cirrhosis is one of the causes of hypervolemic hyponatremia.

Causes of Hyponatremia

Hypovolemic

(Option A)
  • GI/skin losses
  • Renal losses:
    • Intake of diuretics
    • Underlying renal conditions:
      • Nephronophthisis
      • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
      • Cerebral salt wasting syndrome: Sodium loss through urine

Euvolemic

(Option B)
  • SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone)
  • Glucocorticoid deficiency
  • Hypothyroidism

Hypervolemic
  • Conditions with lots of third spacing or edema
  • Total fluid in body is increasing but fluid in intravascular compartment may not be much
  • Specific conditions:
    • Cardiac failure
    • Cirrhosis of liver
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Hypoalbuminemia
    • Renal failure

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with symptoms including skin thickening on her fingers, fatigue, and shortness of breath with episodes of painful swelling in her fingertips and difficulty swallowing. During her examination, a specific immunofluorescence test is performed, revealing the presence of several autoantibodies. Which of the following auto-antibodies is most likely associated with severe skin involvement and interstitial lung disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms, including skin thickening, fatigue, and shortness of breath, suggest systemic sclerosis with severe skin and pulmonary involvement.
  • Topoisomerase I (Scl-70) is associated with diffuse cutaneous SSc and linked to severe skin involvement, interstitial lung disease (ILD), and renal crisis.

Auto-Antibody

SSc Subset

Prominent Characteristic

Topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

dcSSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • Tendon friction rubs, digital ischemic ulcers, scleroderma, extensive skin involvement, early ILD, cardiac involvement, scleroderma renal crisis

Centromere proteins

lcSSc
  • Discrete speckled (centromere) pattern
  • Digital ischemic ulcers, calcinosis cutis, isolated PAH; renal crisis rare (Option A ruled out)

RNA polymerase III

dcSSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • Rapidly progressive skin involvement, tendon friction rubs, joint contractures, GAVE, renal crisis, contemporaneous cancers; digital ulcers rare (Option C ruled out)

U3-RNP (fibrillarin)

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • PAH, ILD, scleroderma renal crisis, GI tract involvement, myositis

Th/To

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • ILD, PAH

PM/Scl

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • Calcinosis cutis, ILD, myositis overlap

Ku

overlap
  • Speckled pattern
  • SLE, myositis overlap

U1-RNP

dc/lc SSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • PAH, inflammatory arthritis, myositis overlap (Option D ruled out)

U11/U12 RNP

dc/lc SSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • ILD

Note:

  • Dc SSc- Diffuse cutaneous SSc
  • Lc SSc- Limited cutaneous SSc

questions.text: A Pap smear from the transformation zone shows cells with blue-green nuclei, orange-red cytoplasm, and pink superficial cells. Which stain components are responsible for the cytoplasmic colors seen?

choices.text: Bismarck brown and light green SF
Orange green 6 and light green SF

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Eosin Y and orange green 6

 

Explanation:

 

Contents of a Pap Stain:

  1. Hematoxylin: Stains nuclei blue.
  2. Eosin Y: Stains acidophilic cytoplasm cells pink to red. 
  3. Bismarck brown: Stains basophilic cells blue-green. 
  4. Orange green 6: Stains keratin and erythrocytes orange-red 
  5. Light green SF: Stains keratin orange-red. 

Eosin Y + Orange G 6 = cytoplasmic stains in Pap smear.

 

Normal Pap Smear

Abnormal Pap Smear
  • Superficial and squamous cells are typically seen in a normal Pap smear.
  • When stained appears as, 
    • Nuclei: Blue
    • Cytoplasm: Orange-red

 
  • Cellular atypia, presents as,
    • Nuclear enlargement
    • Irregular nuclear shape
    • Increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratios
    • Abnormal cell arrangements.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an inhibitor of Carnitine Acyl Transferase-1 (CAT-1)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) AMPK

Explanation:

AMPK activation leads to increased fatty acid oxidation by promoting mitochondrial biogenesis and improving fatty acid metabolism. It is a metabolic regulator that often enhances Carnitine Acyl Transferase-1 (CAT-1)/ Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-1 CPT-1 activity rather than inhibiting it.

 

CARNITINE ACYL TRANSFERASE-1 (CPT-1)

STIMULATORS

INHIBITORS
  • Starvation
  • FFA (Free Fatty Acids)
  • AMPK (Adenosine Monophosphate-Activated Protein Kinase)
  • Glucagon
  • Well fed state
  • Malonyl-CoA (Option B ruled out)
  • Sulfonylureas (Option A ruled out)
  • Insulin (Option D ruled out)
  • Etomoxir
  • Oxfenicine
  • Perhexiline
  • PPARα antagonist

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of SLE presents with fatigue, decreased urine output, and facial swelling. Lab tests show elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination image is attached. Which statement is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.
More the number of crescents, better the prognosis.
Crescents are composed solely of endothelial cells.

questions.solution:
Answer: A) >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.

 

Explanation:

The provided clinical scenario and the histopathological image suggest a Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) diagnosis in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Crescentic glomerulonephritis (or RPGN) is characterised by the presence of crescents in more than 50% of glomeruli on renal biopsy.

 

More the number of crescents, the better the prognosis (Option B)

In RPGN, more crescents generally indicate a poor prognosis

 

Crescents are composed solely of endothelial cells (Option C)

Crescents are composed of fibrin, leucocytes, parietal and visceral layers of Bowman capsule.

 

Primarily caused by bacterial infections (Option D)

RPGN Type I, II, III can be due to varied causes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of supraventricular tachycardia. The electrophysiologist plans to perform catheter ablation. Which of the following structures is most likely to be found at the apex of Koch's triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrioventricular node

Explanation:

The Triangle of Koch is situated on the right atrial aspect of the interatrial septum.

Boundaries:

  1. Opening of the coronary sinus
  2. The Tendon of Todaro - a collagenous subendocardial band - runs from the central fibrous body to the Eustachian ridge - a part of the fibrous skeleton of the heart.
  3. Septal tricuspid leaflet

Importance:

It helps to localize the AV node - present at the apex of Koch’s triangle.

Localising the AV node is important to safely perform radiofrequency catheter ablation within the right atrium in cases of AVNRT.

 

Sinoatrial node (Option A) is located in the upper part of the right atrium, near the opening of the superior vena cava, not in Koch's triangle.

 

While the bundle of His (Option C) is anatomically close to the AV node, it is not typically found at the apex of Koch's triangle.

  • It emerges from the AV node and penetrates the cardiac skeleton.

 

Right bundle branch (Option D) is a continuation of the bundle of His and is found in the interventricular septum, not in Koch's triangle.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with persistent pain in his right leg, which is worse at night and relieved by ibuprofen. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no swelling or warmth over the affected area. An X-ray of the right leg is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Osteoid Osteoma

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presenting with persistent pain, relieved by NSAIDs and an X-ray showing a characteristic lesion with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus, points towards an Osteoid Osteoma.

 

Osteoid Osteoma

A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone

Demographics
  • Sex: Males > Females
  • Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30.

Location
  • The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.
  • It can also occur in the spine, particularly the posterior arches.

Pathophysiology

The nidus releases prostaglandins which cause the characteristic pain that relieves on taking NSAIDs

Symptoms
  • Characterized by pain, often worse at night (Night crises), and relieved by NSAIDs (Therapeutic test).
  • When near joints, it may cause stiffness and effusion.
  • In the spine, it can lead to muscle spasms and scoliosis.

Radiology

X-Ray:

  • Dense sclerosis with a small, rounded area of osteolysis, often obscured by the surrounding sclerosis.
  • The characteristic lesion is less than 1.5 cm in diameter with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus.

Isotope bone scans (Best investigation) are positive

Histology
  • Consists of a mesh of woven bone, osteoblastic rimming, osteoclasts, and dilated capillaries.
  • The mature osteoid forms the nidus, surrounded by dense, reactive bone and soft tissue with inflammatory changes.

Treatment
  • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus (gold standard)

 

Simple bone cyst (Option A):

  • It is usually asymptomatic and occurs in the metaphysis.
  • On X-rays, it appears as a well-marginated, unilocular lytic lesion with a thin rim of sclerosis.

 

Brodie’s Abscess (Option C):

  • It is a subacute form of osteomyelitis that presents with localized pain, often associated with low-grade infection.
  • It can also have a radiolucent lesion but is usually accompanied by systemic signs like fever and swelling.

 

Ewing's Sarcoma (Option D):

  • It usually presents with systemic symptoms like fever and shows a characteristic onion-skin periosteal reaction on X-ray.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with recurrent painful swelling and discharge at the natal cleft. He has coarse hair and reports worsening after prolonged sitting. On examination, a tender fluctuant swelling with a midline pit is noted.What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Complete surgical excision of the sinus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Drainage through a midline incision

Explanation:

Drainage through a midline incision is the most appropriate initial management for an acute pilonidal abscess.

  • It involves creating a small incision to drain the abscess and clean the cavity.
  • Pilonidal sinuses are found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair.

 

Treatment Options:

  • Conservative:
    • Cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance.
    • Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser
  • Acute Abscess Treatment:
    • Drainage through a small longitudinal incision over the abscess (Option C ruled out).
  • Surgical: 
    • Laying open sinus tracks (with/without marsupialisation)
    • Complete excision (with/without primary closure)
    • Off-midline closure techniques (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedures).
    • Bascom Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus cavity, excise midline pits, and leave lateral wounds open to heal secondarily.
    • Flap Procedures: If initial treatments fail or if the sinus recurs

 Pilonidal sinus excision and repair by rhomboid flap

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The most recent platelet count is 32,000/μL, and the child does not exhibit any signs of active bleeding. What is the appropriate next step in management for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Wait and watch

 

Explanation:

 

The child doesn’t have severe thrombocytopenia and/or any life-threatening bleeding. Hence in this case the child only requires close observation.

 

Management of Immune thrombocytopenic purpura in children.

Based on platelet count
  • Platelet Count >30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding- Monitor closely
  • Platelet Count < 30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding + Platelet Count ≥ 5,000 cells/μL: Glucocorticoids (e.g., Prednisone, Dexamethasone) (Option A)
  • Platelet Count < 5,000 cells/μL or Severe Bleeding: IVIg + Glucocorticoids

Other modalities
  • Immediate Need to Raise Platelet Count, like surgery or trauma- Platelet Transfusion (Option B)
  • Persistent or Severe Cases- Monitor with intermittent IVig, If Necessary, Consider Splenectomy (Option C)

Alternative Medications
  • Anti-CD20 Antibody: Rituximab
  • TPO Receptor Agonists: Romiplostim, Eltrombopag

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the image given?

choices.text: Can help identify the white-coat effect in patients
Continuous readings for a full 24-hour period
Measures both awake and sleep averages

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Used to investigate hypertension only

Explanation:

The image depicts Ambulatory BP Monitoring (ABPM). ABPM is used to investigate hypotensive episodes along with hypertension. These hypotensive episodes can occur due to autonomic dysfunction.

Parameter

Ambulatory BP Monitoring (ABPM)

Home Blood Pressure Monitoring (HBPM)

Device Type

Oscillometric

Oscillometric

Operation

Worn by patient, preprogrammed, fully automatic

Self-administered by the patient

Monitoring Duration

24 hours

7 days (morning and evening)

Mean Overall BP

Present in report

Average of 6 days if > 135/85 mmHg

Mean Awake BP

Present in report

Average of readings during the day

Mean Sleep BP

Present in the report (Option C ruled out)

Not typically calculated

Clinical Applications

-White-coat hypertension (Option A ruled out)

-Confirm hypertension in children

-Resistant hypertension

-Labile hypertension

-Hypotensive episodes (Option D)

Self-monitoring for hypertension management

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presented with headache, blurring of vision, weakness and loss of balance. His radiological investigations suggested hydrocephalus and pheochromocytoma. A tumour is detected whose radiograph is given below. Which of the following genetic syndromes is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) VHL syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The above features suggest Hemangioblastoma and the associated genetic disorder is VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome.
  • Hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular tumour of the central nervous system associated with VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome, which consists of the following,
    • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma.
    • Retinal hemangioma
    • RCC(Renal Cell Carcinoma)
    • Renal cyst
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Epididymal/ broad ligament cyst adenoma
    • Endolymphatic sac tumours
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors

 

  • MRI in hemangioblastoma shows a cystic tumour with a non-enhancing wall and enhancing mural nodule, which is managed by surgical resection.

questions.text: What is the primary objective of the Kishori Shakti Yojana?

choices.text: Promoting higher education among adolescent girls
Ensuring maternal healthcare for pregnant women
Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education
Providing financial assistance for marriage expenses

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education

Explanation:

Kishori Shakti Yojana aims to empower adolescent girls through nutrition and health education.

  • Part of the existing ICDS scheme
  • Targets adolescent girls 11-18 years
  • Provides education on health, hygiene, and nutrition
  • Encourages girls to be in school

questions.text: Below is a graph showing the results of a screening test. If the cut-off point is reduced from point B to A, what will be its effect on this screening test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sensitivity increases

 

Explanation:

 

  • In a screening test, if the cut-off value that differentiates normal and diseased populations is changed from point B to point A on the curve [ie. Value reduced] the test's sensitivity will be increased [i.e. high true positives], but specificity will be reduced [high false positives].
  • If the cut-off is increased from point A to point B, sensitivity is reduced, and specificity is increased.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden confusion, fever, and seizures over the past 24 hours. Her partner reports memory loss and difficulty recognising faces. Examination reveals a fever of 102°F, disorientation, and mild aphasia. PCR is positive for HSV. Which feature is not associated with the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mollaret meningitis

Explanation:

  • The scenario presenting with seizures, aphasia, disorientation, confusion, fever, and positive PCR testing for HSV indicates a diagnosis of herpes simplex virus encephalitis caused by HSV-1.
  • Mollaret meningitis is recurrent aseptic meningitis associated with HSV-2, not HSV-1.

Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus

  • Cutaneous:
    • Site:
      • Face (cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead)
      • Buttocks (infants as napkin rash)
    • 'Fever blister' or herpes febrile or cold sores (viral reactivation in febrile patients)
    • Herpetic whitlow: Occupational variety seen in doctors, dentists, and nurses.
    • Eczema herpeticum: Generalised crops of vesicles appear in the affected area with widespread ulceration, as seen in children with eczema.
    • Herpes gladiatorum (Wrestler’s herpes): In athletes who play skin-to-skin contact sports like wrestlers.
    • Herpes multiforme (red, raised, target-like lesions on skin)

 

  • Mucosal
    • Site: Buccal mucosa (most common)
    • Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis (primary infection) (Option A)
    • Recurrent herpes labialis (Option B)
  • Ophthalmic
    • Dendritic corneal ulcers (Option D)
    • Corneal blindness and conjunctivitis are also observed
    • Chorioretinitis and acute necrotising retinitis are rare.
  • Nervous system
    • Encephalitis (HSV Encephalitis)
      • Caused by HSV-1
      • Most common cause of sporadic acute viral encephalitis
      • Affected site: Temporal lobe
    • Meningitis
      • Most commonly caused by HSV-2
      • Mollaret meningitis (recurrent lymphocytic meningitis) (Option C)
      • HSV can result in Bell's palsy.
  • Visceral
    • Symptoms like dysphagia, substernal pain and weight loss.
    • Tracheobronchitis and pneumonitis (lung involvement)
  • Genital infections
    • Mostly seen in HSV type 2
    • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions
    • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy
    • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
      • Male: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
      • Female: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum.
  • Congenital
    • If a pregnant woman has genital lesions during labour, the risk of infection can be mitigated by performing a cesarean section.
    • Neonatal herpes: A disseminated disease involving multiple organs, with or without encephalitis. The mortality rate is high, and survivors may have neurological impairments.
    • Transplacental infections leading to congenital malformations are rare.

questions.text: Patient is undergoing endoscopy for epigastric pain. Report shows giant duodenal ulcer in duodenal cap and second one is noted in second part of duodenum. Which investigation should be done next in this patient
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Secretin study

  • Secretin study is indicated to diagnose Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which can present with multiple or giant duodenal ulcers due to excessive gastric acid secretion. It entails fasting gastrin levels and then levels few minutes after secretin injection. 
  • Breath urea test only detects H. pylori infection, not causes of multiple/giant ulcers.
  • Somatostatin scintigraphy identifies neuroendocrine tumors but is not diagnostic for acid hypersecretion.
  • Endoscopic ultrasound visualizes lesions but does not assess gastric secretory function.

questions.text: A 32 year old man presents to the clinic with a rash on his neck and upper chest area after spending the day on his farm in hot and humid weather. He describes the rash as itchy and prickly. On examination, there are numerous small, erythematous papules present, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Miliaria rubra


Explanation:

Miliaria rubra (prickly heat or heat rash) arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts at the level of stratum spinosum in hot, humid conditions, resulting in sweat leakage into the epidermis.

It is characterized by small, red papules or vesicles accompanied by itching or a prickling sensation. It typically occurs in areas of the body prone to sweating and friction during hot and humid weather.

 

Miliaria crystallina (Option A)

Miliaria profunda (Option C)

Miliaria pustulosa (Option D)
  • Obstruction of eccrine sweat duct at the level of stratum corneum.
  • Seen in infants and are characterized by clear fluid thin vesicles that may rupture easily, leaving behind superficial peeling or desquamation.
  • Obstruction of eccrine sweat duct at Dermo-epidermal junction.
  • It is characterized by firm, flesh-coloured lesions or bumps beneath the skin's surface.
  • It follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra.

 
  • It is an infected variant of miliaria rubra by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by pustules or pus-filled lesions in addition to the typical features of miliaria rubra.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with diabetes mellitus presents with fatigue and abdominal discomfort. He denies any history of alcohol consumption. Laboratory tests show elevated serum AST and ALT levels. Imaging reveals hepatic steatosis. Which of the following is consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) AST/ALT < 1 with diabetes mellitus

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is consistent with Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, characterised by AST/ALT < 1.

 

Features

NASH

(Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis)

Alcoholic steatohepatitis

Risk factors

Obesity 

Diabetes mellitus (Option C)

Dyslipidemia (Option D ruled out)

Alcohol intake

AST/ALT Ratio

AST/ALT < 1 (Option A and B ruled out)

AST/ALT > 2

GGT levels

Normal

Increased

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain and is diagnosed with acute appendicitis. The surgical team plans to perform an appendectomy. Which of the following correctly represents the type of Incision used in appendicectomy?



 

a-Lanz
b-Rutherford Morrison
c-McBurney’s
d-Paramedian
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

Explanation:

The Incisions typically used for appendicectomy are given in the table below:

McBurney's incision
  • Centered on McBurney's point, perpendicular to the umbilical ASIS line
  • Junction of lateral 1/3 from umbilicus & medial 2/3 from ASIS
  • McBurney's point corresponds to the base of the appendix
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Aka Grid iron incision / McArthur incision

Lanz incision

Placed transversely 2 cm below the umbilicus on the line joining the midpoint of the clavicle to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Cosmetically better incision
  • Aka Modified McBurney's incision / Rocky Davis incision / Bikini incision (good cosmetic appearance)

Rutherford-Morrison incision
  • Extension of McBurney's incision for retrocecal appendicitis
  • Upward & laterally by cutting conjoint tendon
  • Muscle cutting incision
  • Preferred for retrocecal appendix
